title: The Effects of Pensions and Retirement Policies on Retirement in Higher Education
author: Alan L. Gustman, Thomas L. Steinmeier
context: This paper studies retirement decisions of tenured male arts-and-sciences faculty at 26 high-quality private U.S. colleges (COFHE) using employment observed as of December 31, 1975 and retirements during 1973–78, with pension plan details reported in 1979 (and 1989 for simulations). Institutional variation includes mandatory retirement ages (65–70), normal and early-retirement eligibility, pension accruals and early-retirement supplements, and Social Security rules. The authors estimate a structural life-cycle retirement model and use Monte Carlo simulations to predict effects of raising/eliminating mandatory retirement and offering early-retirement incentives.
identification_methods: others; other cross-sectional regressions

Institutional variation includes mandatory retirement ages (65–70), normal and early-retirement eligibility, pension accruals and early-retirement supplements, and Social Security rules. title: Is Inequality Harmful for Growth? Theory and Evidence
author: Torsten Persson, Guido Tabellini
context: Combining a politico‑economic growth model with empirical tests, the paper examines whether initial income inequality reduces subsequent per‑capita GDP growth. It uses two complementary data sets: a historical panel of nine now‑developed countries divided into 20‑year episodes covering primarily 1830–1970, and a post‑war cross‑section of about 67 countries over 1960–85. Units are country (or country‑period) observations; key covariates are pre‑period inequality (top‑20% share or top20/bottom40 ratio), schooling, franchise restrictions, and initial GDP per capita, exploiting cross‑country and over‑time variation in institutions and redistribution.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; IV

title: The Evolution of Buyout Pricing and Financial Structure
author: Steven N. Kaplan, Jeremy C. Stein
context: This paper studies 124 large U.S. management leveraged buyouts (MBOs) completed 1980–1989. Using transaction-level data from SEC proxy/14D filings, Mergerstat, CRSP and Compustat, the authors analyze firm-level pricing, projected cash flows, and capital-structure terms (bank term loans and revolvers, subordinated public/private debt, deferred-interest instruments, principal schedules) within the 1980s LBO/junk-bond market and evolving bank loan-sales and interest-rate environment to assess how valuation and financing changed over the decade.

title: The Evolution of Buyout Pricing and Financial Structure

outcome: Cash flow to total debt obligations
context: This triplet concerns a subset of the paper's sample: 90 of the 124 U.S. management leveraged buyouts (MBOs) completed 1980–1989 that report bank principal repayment schedules. title: The Socioeconomic Consequences of Teen Childbearing Reconsidered
author: Arline T. Geronimus, Sanders Korenman
context: This paper uses U.S. longitudinal survey data — primarily the National Longitudinal Survey of Young Women (women aged 14–24 in 1968, followed through 1982 and observed at ages 28–38) with robustness checks using sister samples from the PSID (observed in 1985) — to estimate how timing of first birth affects later socioeconomic outcomes. The unit of analysis is individual women and sibling pairs within families across the United States; analyses exploit shared family background to address unobserved heterogeneity in causal inference.

author: George J. Borjas, Richard B. Freeman, Lawrence F. Katz
outcome: Effective supply of high school dropouts
context: This paper studies U.S. labor-market effects of rising import competition and immigration from the late 1960s through the 1980s (analyses focus on 1967–1985 trade flows and immigrant stocks 1980–1988). title: Growth in Cities
author: Edward L. Glaeser, Hedi D. Kallal, Jose A. Scheinkman, Andrei Shleifer
context: Using County Business Patterns data for 170 U.S. SMAs, the paper analyzes the top six 2‑digit industries in each city over 1956–1987. The wage-growth regressions (dependent variable: industry wage growth over 1956–1987) are estimated on the subset of 834 city‑industry observations with exact payroll data. The treatment is local competition measured as firms per worker relative to the national industry average. Regressions include controls for 1956 log employment and log wage in the city‑industry, a southern‑city dummy, and national industry employment change.

title: Growth in Cities
author: Edward L. Glaeser, Hedi D. Kallal, Jose A. Scheinkman, Andrei Shleifer
context: Using County Business Patterns employment, payroll, and establishment data for 170 U.S. Standard Metropolitan Areas, the paper examines growth of the top six 2‑digit industries in each city between 1956 and 1987 (≈1,016 city‑industry observations). It assesses how local specialization, competition (establishments per worker), and urban variety predict 30‑year employment and wage growth, controlling for initial employment and wages, southern location, and national industry trends, to test MAR, Porter, and Jacobs theories of knowledge spillovers.

title: Short and Long Run Externalities
author: Eric J. Bartelsman, Ricardo J. Caballero, Richard K. Lyons
context: Using U.S. manufacturing data for 450 four-digit industries from 1958–1986 (with a 1977 input–output matrix to construct interindustry weights), the paper analyzes how external economies transmit through customer (output-weighted) and supplier (input-weighted) linkages. Units are four-digit manufacturing industries; the study distinguishes short-run (fluctuation-oriented) effects from longer-run (growth-oriented) effects and conducts robustness checks for capacity utilization and alternative activity measures (value added vs. gross production). Identification exploits variation across industries and over time in the postwar U.S. manufacturing sector.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: How Computers Have Changed the Wage Structure: Evidence From Microdata, 1984-1989
author: Alan B. Krueger

title: Monetary Policy, Business Cycles and the Behavior of Small Manufacturing Firms
author: Mark Gertler, Simon Gilchrist
outcome: Small firm sales growth (relative to large)
context: The paper analyzes U.S. manufacturing (quarterly data, primarily 1958:Q4–1990:Q3; some series from 1965) using the Quarterly Financial Report aggregated into small (≤$25m assets) and large firm sales series. title: Estimating the Effect of Training on Employment and Unemployment Durations: Evidence From Experimental Data
author: John C. Ham, Robert J. LaLonde
context: Using the National Supported Work (NSW) Demonstration randomized experiment (volunteers randomized in 1976–77) across seven U.S. sites (Atlanta, Chicago, Hartford, Newark, New York City, Oakland, and Wisconsin locations), the paper analyzes post-baseline employment and unemployment spell durations for AFDC recipient women over roughly 26 months of semi-monthly follow-up. The program provided 9–18 months of subsidized work; eligibility required recent unemployment and volunteer enrollment, and random assignment ensures exogenous treatment variation.
identification_methods: RCT; others

title: Changes in Relative Wages, 1963-1987: Supply and Demand Factors
author: Lawrence F. Katz, Kevin M. Murphy
treatment: Allocation of labor across industries and occupations
outcome: Relative wages of college graduates and females
context: Analyzes U.S. wage-structure changes from 1963–1987 using 25 consecutive March CPS supplements. Units are demographic labor groups (sex × education × experience, aggregated into 320/64 cells) with full-time weekly wages and total hours in efficiency units. The paper evaluates how shifts in relative supplies (education cohorts, age structure, female labor supply) and demand shifts — both within- and between-industry/occupation (skill-biased technology, product demand, trade) — generated movements in the college premium, experience returns, gender gaps, and within-group inequality.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: Anatomy of Financial Distress: An Examination of Junk-Bond Issuers
author: Paul Asquith, Robert Gertner, David Scharfstein
treatment: Higher industry leverage / lower industry Tobin's q
context: This analysis uses the sample of 102 U.S. publicly traded firms that issued high‑yield bonds in the 1970s–1980s and experienced financial distress, focusing on actions around the onset of distress (t‑1 to t+1). For this triplet the outcome is a binary indicator (probit cross‑section regressions) equal to one if the firm sells at least 20% of its assets; the key regressors are industry‑level leverage and industry Tobin's q measured using 4‑digit SIC industry medians in non‑financial industries.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Sectoral Shifts and Unemployment in Interwar Britain
author: S. Lael Brainard
treatment: Cross-section variation in industry excess returns
context: This paper examines causes of persistent high unemployment in interwar Britain (1921–1938), using annual industry-level stock returns and employment data for 103 firms across 11 industries to assess sectoral reallocation shocks' impact on aggregate unemployment. Units include industries (and firm stock indices) and the aggregate unemployment rate. The institutional setting includes the 1925 return to sterling parity and the 1931 abandonment of the gold standard, large export contractions during the Great Depression, and modest aggregate growth; the analysis controls for monetary, fiscal, and benefit-to-wage changes to isolate sectoral shocks.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: State Infrastructure and Productive Performance
author: Catherine J. Morrison, Amy Ellen Schwartz
context: This paper studies the effect of public infrastructure (state-level public capital) on manufacturing firms' costs and productivity using annual state-level manufacturing data for the 48 contiguous U.S. states over 1970–1987. Units of observation are state manufacturing sectors (output and inputs: private capital, public capital, production and nonproduction labor, energy). The institutional setting is U.S. state public capital investment across regions (Northeast, North, South, West); the authors estimate a structural variable-cost model with state fixed effects to quantify shadow values and scale effects of public capital.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; others

title: Geographic Localization of Knowledge Spillovers as Evidenced by Patent  Citations
author: Adam B. Jaffe, Manuel Trajtenberg, Rebecca Henderson
context: This paper uses U.S. patent citation data for cohorts of patents applied in 1975 and 1980, tracking citations through 1989, to assess geographic localization of knowledge spillovers at the country, state, and SMSA levels. The units are patents (originating patents from universities, large R&D corporations, and other corporations) and their citing patents, with inventor addresses used to assign geography. title: Detection of Bid Rigging in Procurement Auctions
author: Robert H. Porter, J. Douglas Zona
context: This empirical study analyzes sealed-bid New York State Department of Transportation highway procurement auctions in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, Long Island, using paving contracts from April 1979–March 1985. Units are firm-level bids and auction outcomes (116 paving projects, 575 bids). The institutional setting is the DOT's lowest-responsible-bidder rule, public announcement of bidders and bids, and plan-buyer lists. Motivated by allegations that five local firms engaged in phantom/complementary bid rigging, the paper compares bidding behavior of alleged cartel members to other firms.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Do Gasoline Prices Respond Asymmetrically to Crude Oil Price Changes?
author: Severin Borenstein, A. Colin Cameron
context: This empirical study examines asymmetric transmission of crude oil price changes to gasoline prices using weekly and semi‑monthly data from January 1986–December 1990. It covers U.S. markets east of the Rocky Mountains (WTI crude, Gulf Coast/New York spot gasoline, city terminal branded/unbranded prices averaged across ~17 cities, and retail unleaded regular self‑service averages from 42 cities). Units are market prices at different stages of the refinery–terminal–retail distribution chain. The paper evaluates inventory‑cost and imperfect‑competition explanations using error‑correction/time‑series analysis.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Relative-Price Changes as Aggregate Supply Shocks
author: Laurence Ball, N. Gregory Mankiw
context: This paper analyzes U.S. postwar inflation from 1949–1989 by linking annual cross‑sectional distributions of four‑digit PPI industry price changes to aggregate PPI inflation. Working from a menu‑cost model of nominal rigidity, the authors argue that skewness in relative‑price changes (for example, large oil shocks) shifts the short‑run Phillips curve. Empirically they compute yearly moments (weighted and unweighted) of industry price changes, estimate AR(1) time‑series and Phillips‑curve regressions including detrended unemployment, and examine historical episodes.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Measuring the Cyclicality of Real Wages: How Important is Composition Bias
author: Gary Solon, Robert Barsky, Jonathan A. Parker
context: Using U.S. data from roughly 1967–87 (PSID interviews 1968–88 covering calendar years 1967–87) and aggregate BLS/GNP time series, the paper studies individual- and cohort-level real wage responses over the business cycle. Units are workers/household heads (micro panel observations) and aggregate wage series; cycle indicators include the civilian unemployment rate and real GNP growth. The authors investigate how composition shifts in hours worked (more low-skill hours in expansions) bias aggregate measures and compare balanced/unbalanced PSID panel estimates to decompose true real-wage procyclicality.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Measuring the Cyclicality of Real Wages: How Important is Composition Bias
author: Gary Solon, Robert Barsky, Jonathan A. Parker
context: Using PSID microdata for calendar years 1967–87 (interviews 1968–88), this triplet refers specifically to a balanced sample of 355 prime-age men (household heads) with year-to-year observations totaling 7,100 person-year changes. title: Wages, Profits and Rent-Sharing
author: David G. Blanchflower, Andrew J. Oswald, Peter Sanfey
context: This paper analyzes US manufacturing wage determination using CPS March microdata for roughly 400,000 workers aggregated into 19 industry-by-year cells over 1964–1985. Industry-level profit and unemployment series (profit data available 1958–1985, aggregated to 2-digit SIC) are merged with cell means of individual characteristics to test rent-sharing versus competitive and contract models. Estimations use dynamic panel specifications with year dummies and both fixed- and random-effects to trace contemporaneous and lagged profit effects on mean wages.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: A Tax-Based Test of the Dividend Signaling Hypothesis
author: B. Douglas Bernheim, Adam Wantz
context: Analyzes U.S. publicly traded firms’ dividend-increase announcements during 1962–1988 (with focused analyses 1978–1988), using daily CRSP returns and Compustat bond ratings. Unit of observation is the firm-announcement; the study exploits temporal variation in dividend taxation (Poterba’s THETA and major U.S. tax reforms around 1981 and 1986) and cross-firm differences in bond ratings as proxies for marginal dividend costs. The main outcome is three-day cumulative abnormal returns around dividend announcement windows to assess how tax and financial conditions affect market responses.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Generics and New Goods in Pharmaceutical Price Indexes
author: Zvi Griliches, Iain Cockburn
context: This paper uses monthly IMS America wholesale transaction data on U.S. prescription pharmaceuticals—focusing on cephalexin and cephradine—from the mid-1980s through 1990 (patent expirations in April 1987). It analyzes how patent expiration, FDA therapeutic-equivalence certification, and subsequent generic entry and diffusion across product-presentations affect wholesale prices, market shares, and official CPI/PPI-style price indexes. Units are product-presentations (packages), quantities, and revenues; the institutional setting emphasizes FDA rules, patent timing, and statistical agency index construction.
identification_methods: IV; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

context: This paper uses monthly IMS America wholesale transaction data on U.S. prescription pharmaceuticals—focusing on cephalexin and cephradine—from the mid-1980s through 1990 (patent expirations in April 1987). It analyzes how patent expiration, FDA therapeutic-equivalence certification, and subsequent generic entry and diffusion across product-presentations affect wholesale prices, market shares, and official CPI/PPI-style price indexes. Units are product-presentations (packages), quantities, and revenues; the institutional setting emphasizes FDA rules, patent timing, and statistical agency index construction.
identification_methods: IV; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: Heterogeneity, Stratification, and Growth
author: Roland Benabou
context: This triplet comes from a theoretical comparative‑statics analysis of economies with heterogeneous agents interacting via local public goods and economy‑wide linkages. The paper compares integrated (mixed) versus segregated local communities—using examples like local versus national school funding—and evaluates short‑run and long‑run effects on aggregate output and productivity. Units are families/communities and aggregate economies in a general (non–country‑specific) setting, with emphasis on long‑run output/productivity under varying local and global complementarities.
identification_methods: others

title: Tobin's Q, Corporate Diversification and Firm Performance
author: Larry H.P. Lang, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper studies U.S. publicly traded firms using Compustat segment data over 1978–1990 (focus year 1984), examining how corporate diversification (number of reported segments under SFAS No.14) relates to firm value measured by Tobin’s q (replacement‑cost adjusted). The unit of observation is the firm (sample restricted to firms with average assets > $100 million). Analyses adjust for industry composition via a “chop‑shop” pure‑play counterfactual and control for size, R&D intensity, and capital‑market access in the U.S. institutional setting.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Monopolistic Competition and International Trade: Reconsidering the Evidence
author: David Hummels, James Levinsohn
context: This paper empirically tests monopolistic‑competition trade models using bilateral trade and intra‑industry trade data for OECD country‑pairs (primarily 1962–1983; 91 pairs, 2,002 country‑pair‑years) and a NOECD developing‑country sample (through 1977). Units are country‑pair-year (and industry-year using 4‑digit SITC). The authors construct GDP, capital stocks and per‑worker income (Penn World/PWT and World Bank) and exploit cross‑sectional, panel, and IV variation to assess how relative country size and factor differences shape trade under balanced‑trade and monopolistic‑competition assumptions.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Does Head Start Make a Difference?
author: Janet Currie, Duncan Thomas
context: This paper uses the US National Longitudinal Survey of Youth Child–Mother data (children of the 1979 NLSY cohort, surveyed in 1986–1990) to estimate effects of participation in the federal Head Start preschool program on children’s cognitive scores, grade repetition, immunizations, and height, and on longer‑run outcomes for women. Units are children (and mothers with sister comparisons); the sample is national with oversamples of African‑Americans and Hispanics. Identification relies on within‑family comparisons to address time‑invariant family confounders.

title: Employment-Based Health Insurance and Job Mobility: Is There Evidence of Job-Lock?
author: Brigitte C. Madrian
context: This paper uses the 1987 National Medical Expenditure Survey (United States) to examine whether employer‑provided health insurance reduces voluntary job turnover (“job‑lock”) among married men ages 20–55. It exploits variation in coverage sources and expected medical costs—spousal/other non‑employment coverage, family size, and pregnancy—against a backdrop of widespread preexisting‑condition exclusions and COBRA continuation rules in the 1980s. The unit of observation is individual married men and analyses compare mobility for those with and without employer‑sponsored group insurance.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Sticking it Out: Entrepreneurial Survival and Liquidity Constraints
author: Douglas Holtz-Eakin, David Joulfaian, Harvey S. Rosen
context: This empirical study uses U.S. federal tax records to estimate how inheritance-driven increases in personal assets affect the probability that sole proprietors survive and, conditional on survival, their firms' receipts. It matches estate tax returns for decedents who died in 1982–83 to beneficiaries' individual income tax returns in 1981 and 1985, focusing on relatively high-wealth estates (sample oversamples estates above $300,000). The unit of observation is individual beneficiaries (Schedule C filers); inheritances are treated as plausibly exogenous liquidity shocks within the U.S. tax/inheritance institutional setting.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: The Effect of Marginal Tax Rates on Taxable Income: A Panel Study of the1986 Tax Reform Act
author: Martin Feldstein
context: This paper uses a U.S. panel of matched individual income tax returns to estimate how the 1986 Tax Reform Act's reductions in marginal income tax rates affected taxable income. It compares taxpayers' returns in 1985 and 1988 (pre/post reform), focusing on married joint filers (mostly under age 65) in a Treasury random sample of roughly 4,000–5,000 returns, and accounts for contemporaneous rule changes (capital gains inclusion, Subchapter C→S conversions, passive loss limits) to isolate behavioral responses in labor, compensation form, portfolio choices, deductions, and reporting.
identification_methods: DiD

title: Minimum Wages and Employment: A Case Study of the Fast Food Industry in New Jersey and Pennsylvania
author: David Card, Alan B. Krueger
context: This paper evaluates the causal effect of New Jersey's April 1, 1992 minimum-wage increase (from $4.25 to $5.05) on fast-food establishments, comparing 410 franchised Burger King, KFC, Wendy's and Roy Rogers restaurants in New Jersey to outlets in eastern Pennsylvania. Authors surveyed establishments before (Feb–Mar 1992) and after (Nov–Dec 1992) the policy, and complement establishment-level DiD analyses with state-level regressions on McDonald's openings (1986–91) and teenage employment, amid a concurrent regional recession.
identification_methods: DiD; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Trade Policy, Exchange Rates and Growth
author: Sebastian Edwards
context: This triplet concerns Latin American case studies of trade liberalization and their sector-level effects: it focuses on manufacturing‑sector labor productivity responses to reduced tariffs and non‑tariff barriers. The paper reports that Chilean manufacturing labor productivity rose an average 13.4% annually between 1978 and 1981, while Mexico saw more modest post‑reform gains (an index rising from 92.7 to 105.1 and a reported 2.3% annual increase excluding maquiladoras). The institutional setting is trade reforms that increased foreign competition.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Trade Policy, Exchange Rates and Growth
author: Sebastian Edwards
context: This paper examines how trade policy and exchange-rate regimes affect total factor productivity and growth using a 54-country cross-country dataset (mainly 1971–82) and detailed case studies of Latin American trade liberalizations from the 1970s through early 1990s (Chile, Mexico, Argentina, Uruguay, Bolivia, Costa Rica, etc.). Units are countries; outcomes are TFP growth and export performance. The institutional setting emphasizes tariff and non‑tariff barrier reductions, exchange‑rate devaluations and sequencing of reforms during structural adjustment episodes.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions

The setting emphasizes oligopolistic rents in durable-goods sectors, spillovers across local labor markets, and rising 1980s wage inequality.

title: Saving Babies: The Efficacy and Cost of Recent Expansions of Medicaid   Eligibility for Pregnant Women
author: Janet Currie, Jonathan Gruber
context: This triplet uses state-year panel data across 49 states plus DC (1979–1990) on Medicaid payments reported to HCFA—physician, clinic, and inpatient/outpatient hospital expenditures for non-disabled children and non-disabled/non-elderly adults—normalized by each state's 15–44 female population. The authors regress annual per-woman Medicaid expenditures on simulated state Medicaid eligibility for pregnant women (disaggregating targeted vs. broad expansions), including state and year fixed effects (Arizona excluded). Estimates report about $232 per additional eligible woman overall and $449 per woman for targeted expansions.

title: The Welfare State and Competitiveness
author: Alberto Alesina, Roberto Perotti
context: Combines a theoretical two-country model with panel evidence (1960–1990) for 14 OECD countries at the country-year level. Studies how redistributive fiscal policies—labor income, social security and payroll taxes financing transfers to retirees and the unemployed—affect competitiveness (manufacturing unit labor costs), relative nontradable prices, and employment. Exploits cross-country/time variation in tax rates, Calmfors–Driffill labor‑market centralization, productivity and controls under an open‑economy setting with unionized wage setting.

title: Sticky Prices: New Evidence from Retail Catalogs
author: Anil K. Kashyap
context: This paper analyzes semiannual catalog list prices for twelve staple retail goods sold by three U.S. mail-order firms (L.L. Bean, Orvis, REI) from 1953–1987 (with some items shorter), using item-by-item price series as the unit of observation. The institutional setting is U.S. mail-order retailing where firms publish Spring/Fall catalogs—prices are typically fixed six months—and includes a high-inflation episode (≈1968–1982). context: This paper studies the U.S. prescription anti‑ulcer (H2‑antagonist) drug market from Tagamet’s 1977 launch through May 1993 using monthly IMS product‑level data. The unit of observation is product‑month (patient‑days, real price per patient‑day, detailing minutes, medical‑journal advertising, FDA indications, and product attributes) for Tagamet, Zantac, Pepcid and Axid. The institutional setting features patent‑timed entry, FDA approval timing (notably GERD), and physician detailing/journal advertising as the main marketing channels; analyses distinguish industry‑expanding versus rivalrous marketing effects.
identification_methods: IV; other time-series regressions; other panel regressions

- 'None': No statistically significant effect.

# Context
This paper studies the U.S. prescription anti‑ulcer (H2‑antagonist) drug market from Tagamet’s 1977 launch through May 1993 using monthly IMS product‑level data. The unit of observation is product‑month (patient‑days, real price per patient‑day, detailing minutes, medical‑journal advertising, FDA indications, and product attributes) for Tagamet, Zantac, Pepcid and Axid. The institutional setting features patent‑timed entry, FDA approval timing (notably GERD), and physician detailing/journal advertising as the main marketing channels; analyses distinguish industry‑expanding versus rivalrous marketing effects.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair

Outcome: Market size

title: The Roles of Marketing, Product Quality and Price Competition in the Growth and Composition of the U.S. Anti-Ulcer Drug Industry
author: Ernst R. Berndt, Linda Bui, David Reiley, Glen Urban
context: This triplet is estimated at the monthly industry level for the U.S. H2‑antagonist (anti‑ulcer) retail market from August 1977 through May 1993. The outcome is total industry quantity (patient‑days) constructed as a Fisher‑Ideal quantity index; the treatment is cumulative medical‑journal advertising measured as deflated pages (BLS professional‑journal index) and accumulated into market‑structure‑specific stocks (monopoly/duopoly/triopoly/four‑firm). Estimation is by nonlinear two‑stage least squares (NL‑2SLS), controlling for price, cumulative detailing stocks, a GERD FDA‑approval dummy, and marketing‑stock depreciation.
identification_methods: IV; other time-series regressions; other panel regressions

title: High Wage Workers and High Wage Firms
author: John M. Abowd, Francis Kramarz, David N. Margolis
context: This paper uses linked employer–employee panels for France to decompose total annual compensation into worker- and firm-level components. It follows roughly a 1/25 sample of private-sector workers (about 1 million observations, 1976–1987) and a probability sample of firms (≈20,000 firms followed 1978–1988, with firm-level data linked via SIREN), measuring real annual compensation (wages plus benefits). The setting is French private employment and social‑security reporting; analyses exploit within-person mobility and firm averages to relate high‑wage workers and high‑wage firms to productivity, capital intensity and survival.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: The Effect of Credit Market Competition on Lending Relationships
author: Mitchell A. Petersen, Raghuram G. Rajan
outcome: Initial loan interest rates for new firms
context: This paper examines how local bank-market concentration affects lending relationships using the 1988–89 National Survey of Small Business Finances (firms in operation as of Dec 1987), a cross-sectional sample of 3,404 U.S. small non‑financial, non‑farm firms (≤500 employees) across counties/MSAs. It exploits cross-market variation in FDIC deposit Herfindahl indices (categorized <0.10, 0.10–0.18, >0.18) and state banking regimes (branching/unit‑banking) to compare credit availability, trade‑credit behavior, and interest‑rate dynamics. Institutional context: small firms rely on local banks and regulators limit banks’ equity claims.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Contagion and Bank Failures During the Great Depression: The June 1932  Chicago Banking Panic
author: Charles W. Calomiris, Joseph R. Mason
outcome: Unwarranted bank failures during the panic
context: This paper examines bank failures during the Great Depression, focusing on the June 1932 Chicago banking panic. Using individual Chicago bank-level observations (stock prices, balance sheets, income statements, liability composition, and failure dates) from 1931–1932, the authors compare banks that failed during the panic, banks that failed outside the panic window, and survivors. Institutional context includes absence of deposit insurance, clearing-house and correspondent arrangements, Reconstruction Finance Corporation interventions, municipal fiscal stress and major corporate failures (Insull), and episodes of fraud (Bain chain).
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: The Causes and Effects of Liability Reform: Some Empirical Evidence
author: Thomas J. Campbell, Daniel P. Kessler, George B. Shepherd
context: This paper analyzes the effects and determinants of state-level tort liability reforms in the United States over 1969–1990. The authors compile a new panel of state tort statutes and judicial decisions matched to industry–state–year data (17 local industries plus manufacturing) from the BEA, and study how adoption of eight reforms (e.g., damage caps, contingency-fee limits, joint-and-several, comparative negligence, prejudgment interest) affected industry productivity and employment. Units are state-industry-year observations; authors exploit staggered cross-state adoption and use political/professional variables (lawyers/doctors per capita, party control, ADA scores) as instruments.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions

title: Using Electoral Cycles in Police Hiring to Estimate the Effect of Policeon Crime
author: Steven D. Levitt
context: The evidence concerns staffing changes in police forces of the paper’s sample of large cities (unit of observation: cities). Section II documents an electoral cycle: increases in sworn police officers are disproportionately concentrated in gubernatorial and mayoral election years (mean % changes: 2.6% gubernatorial, 2.2% mayoral, 0.4% non-election years). Results are reported conditional on a variety of demographic, socio-economic, and economic controls.

title: Supply-Side Economics in a Global Economy
author: Enrique G. Mendoza, Linda L. Tesar
treatment: Replacing income taxes with consumption taxes
context: The paper analyzes welfare effects of replacing income (capital) taxes with consumption taxes in a calibrated, open-economy framework (home and foreign countries) using a benchmark reflecting current G-7 fiscal policies. It compares closed- and open-economy outcomes (including cases with and without taxes on foreign assets), reports welfare gains for countries as percent deviations from the baseline, and computes transitional equilibrium dynamics numerically using a modified King–Plosser–Rebelo algorithm augmented with shooting routines.

author: Lisa M. Lynch, Sandra E. Black
context: The analysis examines the effect of employer-provided training on establishment-level productivity in the manufacturing sector, using establishment observations measured at two points in time (including 1993). title: Local Labor Markets and Welfare Spells: Do Demand Conditions Matter?
author: Hilary Williamson Hoynes
context: This paper analyzes how local labor market conditions affected AFDC welfare spells in California using the administrative Longitudinal Database (10% sample) of monthly records, January 1987–December 1992, at the AFDC case/family level (AFDC-FG and AFDC-UP). County- and zip-code–level labor market measures (unemployment, employment, employment/population, sector earnings from UI/202 data) and 1990 Census neighborhood controls are used. For this triplet, the reported effect on the AFDC caseload is a simulation derived from the estimated discrete-time duration (logit hazard) model with county fixed effects, summarizing the implied permanent caseload change under the assumption of constant entry rates.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Performance Pay and Productivity
author: Edward P. Lazear
context: This paper analyzes a 19-month panel (Jan 1994–July 1995) of installers at Safelite Glass Corporation (Columbus, Ohio), using monthly person-month observations (≈31,000 good observations on ~3,700 installers) to study effects of a phased shift from hourly wages to piece-rate pay with a wage guarantee (≈$11/hr, ≈$20 per unit) instituted after a management change. The setting is commercial auto‑glass installation, with firm administrative data on units per associate per day, pay, hours, and separations; implementation was staggered across workers allowing within-worker before–after comparisons.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Federal Reserve Private Information and the Behavior of Interest Rates
author: Christina D. Romer, David H. Romer
context: This paper studies U.S. monthly data on Federal Reserve internal "Green Book" forecasts (1965–1991) and commercial forecasts (Blue Chip, DRI, SPF), focusing empirically on periods 1974:9–1979:9 and 1984:3–1991:12. Units are monthly forecast observations and forecast errors for the GDP deflator and real GDP; institutional setting is FOMC policy meetings, federal funds rate target changes, and press-reported Fed actions. The analysis tests whether Fed private information is signaled by monetary actions and causes revisions in market inflation expectations and the term structure.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Technology, Factor Supplies and International Specialization: Estimating the Neoclassical Model
author: James Harrigan
context: Using a panel of OECD manufacturing data (roughly 1970–1988, some series to 1990) for ten industrialized countries, the paper studies country×industry×year variation in sector GDP shares to estimate how Hicks‑neutral technology differences and relative factor supplies (capital, labor by education, land) jointly determine international specialization. Data sources include OECD ISDB, Penn World Tables, and Barro‑Lee; the empirical setting assumes small open economies, competitive markets, constant returns, and industry-level translog revenue functions.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; IV

title: Are Medical Prices Declining?
author: David M. Cutler, Mark McClellan, Joseph P. Newhouse, Dahlia Remler
treatment: Improvements in AMI treatment and survival
context: This paper empirically evaluates medical price trends for acute myocardial infarction (AMI) care in the United States using detailed itemized charge and accounting-cost data from a major teaching hospital (1983–1994) and national Medicare claims for elderly AMI patients (1984–1991). Units are AMI treatment episodes and patients; the institutional backdrop includes shifting payment systems (fee-for-service, Medicare prospective payment/DRGs), rising use of invasive procedures (catheterization, angioplasty, bypass), and evolving list vs. transaction prices alongside quality (survival) improvements.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: The Determinants of Technological Change in Heart Attack Treatment
author: David M. Cutler, Mark McClellan
context: Using U.S. Medicare hospital claims for elderly acute myocardial infarction (AMI) episodes between 1984 and 1991, the paper studies hospital- and patient-level adoption and use of intensive cardiac technologies (angioplasty, catheterization, bypass). title: Disability Insurance Benefits and Labor Supply
author: Jonathan Gruber
context: This triplet evaluates social-welfare effects of the January 1987 increase in CPP disability benefits (≈36% relative to Quebec's QPP). Gruber uses elasticity estimates of labor‑force non‑participation (0.25–0.32) from April SCF data on men aged 45–59 (1985–89) and conducts simulations with a utilitarian CES social‑welfare function, two groups (workers and the disabled), tax financing of the benefit increase, and parameters for crowd‑out and risk aversion to assess net welfare gains.
identification_methods: DiD; IV; other panel regressions; others

title: Abortion Legalization and Child Living Circumstances: Who is the Marginal Child?""
author: Jonathan Gruber, Phillip Levine, Douglas Staiger
context: The paper examines how abortion legalization in the United States in the early 1970s — legal changes in five states around 1970 and nationwide after Roe v. Wade (1973) — affected average living standards of birth cohorts. The unit of analysis is cohorts of children born immediately before and after legalization across US states; identification compares cohorts over time and across places where the legal status changed versus where it did not. Outcomes include measures of family structure, poverty, welfare receipt, and infant mortality, with fiscal impacts measured through 1994.
identification_methods: DiD

title: Abortion Legalization and Child Living Circumstances: Who is the Marginal Child?""
author: Jonathan Gruber, Phillip Levine, Douglas Staiger
context: The paper estimates how U.S. state-level abortion legalization affected government welfare expenditures by tracking birth cohorts exposed to legalization (defining the “year after legalization” as 1971 in repeal states and 1976 in non-repeal states). Using cohort-level outcomes through 1994 (payments expressed in 1995 dollars), it attributes a 13,868-family reduction in the welfare caseload per cohort and computes aggregate savings (about $90 million per cohort per year and roughly $14 billion in welfare savings through 1994). Units are U.S. states, birth cohorts, families, and government welfare payments.
identification_methods: DiD

title: Social Security and Retirement in Germany
author: Axel Borsch-Supan, Reinhold Schnabel
context: This triplet refers to the 1972 German social security reform (enacted in early 1973) that introduced early retirement at full benefits—eligibility at age 63 without a health test. The outcome is the annual average retirement age of all new social security claimants, observed for 1970–1980. The paper documents a sharp post‑1973 decline in that average (about 63 to 58.5), driven by composition changes between disability and old‑age retirement.

title: Is Free Trade Good for the Environment?
author: Werner Antweiler, Brian R. Copeland, M. Scott Taylor
treatment: Trade liberalization (1% rise in GDP per capita)
context: This paper investigates how international trade openness affects urban sulfur dioxide (SO2) concentrations using panel data from the Global Environment Monitoring System (GEMS) covering 1971–1996. The unit of observation is site‑year SO2 median concentrations for 293 monitoring sites in 109 cities across 44 countries. The analysis links site‑level pollution to country‑level GDP per km2, capital–labor ratios, lagged GDP per capita, and trade openness (exports+imports/GDP), controlling for site fixed effects, weather, and time trends to decompose scale, composition and technique effects.

title: Prospective Deficits and the Asian Currency Crisis
author: Craig Burnside, Martin Eichenbaum, Sergio Rebelo
treatment: Increase in present value of future deficits
context: The triplet refers to a theoretical setting: in a simple dynamic general-equilibrium model of a fixed exchange-rate regime, at time 0 agents learn that the present value of future government deficits has risen. Given the government's intertemporal budget constraint, a speculative attack on the peg becomes inevitable (regardless of initial foreign reserves or debt). The units are the government and forward-looking agents; the mechanism is the prospect of higher future deficits forcing seignorage choices and triggering an attack.
identification_methods: others

- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
The triplet refers to a theoretical setting: in a simple dynamic general-equilibrium model of a fixed exchange-rate regime, at time 0 agents learn that the present value of future government deficits has risen. Given the government's intertemporal budget constraint, a speculative attack on the peg becomes inevitable (regardless of initial foreign reserves or debt). The units are the government and forward-looking agents; the mechanism is the prospect of higher future deficits forcing seignorage choices and triggering an attack.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Increase in present value of future deficits
Outcome: Speculative attack occurrence

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Displaced Capital
author: Valerie A. Ramey, Matthew D. Shapiro
context: This paper studies reallocation of specialized physical capital following aerospace plant closures in the post–Cold War downsizing of the late 1980s–1990s. It uses confidential auction records from three Southern California aerospace plants that discontinued operations; the unit of observation is used capital items/lots, their transaction prices, buyers (assigned to 4-digit SIC codes), and rebuild histories. The institutional setting features declining U.S. defense demand, thin resale markets, private liquidation sales versus public auctions, and geographic dispersion of buyers.

title: An Account of Global Factor Trade
author: Donald R. Davis, David E. Weinstein
context: This study tests Heckscher-Ohlin-Vanek predictions using mid-1980s (circa 1985) input-output, trade, and endowment data for ten OECD countries (Australia, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Netherlands, United Kingdom, United States) and an aggregated Rest of World. The unit of observation is country-by-industry sectors and bilateral trade flows. The authors estimate country-specific Hicks‑neutral productivity, sectoral input coefficients, and gravity-based bilateral import demand to assess departures from factor-price equalization, specialization in tradables, and the role of trade costs in net factor service trade.

title: Individual Risk and Intergenerational Risk Sharing in an Investment-Based Social Security Program
author: Martin Feldstein, Elena Ranguelova
context: This paper studies, for a U.S. birth cohort aged 21 in 1998 (simulated 1998–2077), the distributional risk of retirement income under investment-based Personal Retirement Accounts (PRAs) for a representative individual contributing 3.1–9% of earnings to a continually rebalanced 60:40 equity–debt portfolio and annuitizing at age 67. For this triplet, results are illustrated under a nonstochastic 5.5% real log return: e.g., saving 3.1% funds the benchmark benefits, while saving 6% yields a median annuity 2.1× the benchmark and only a 17% chance of falling below it.
identification_methods: others

title: Pricing Heart Attack Treatments
author: David M. Cutler, Mark McClellan, Joseph P. Newhouse, Dahlia Remler
context: This paper empirically examines changes in the price and welfare of medical care for acute myocardial infarction (AMI) in the United States using detailed charge data from a major teaching hospital (1983–1994) and national Medicare claims (1984–1994). The unit of analysis is the individual AMI patient (with demographic adjustment focusing on elderly Medicare beneficiaries). The institutional setting includes evolving Medicare reimbursement, diffusion of procedures (catheterization, PTCA, CABG), and changing CPI billing practices; analyses decompose spending, construct SPIs and a COL, and evaluate survival improvements.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; RCT; others

title: The Returns to Skill in the United States across the Twentieth Century
author: Claudia Goldin, Lawrence F. Katz
context: This empirical study examines U.S. wage structure and returns to schooling across the long twentieth century (roughly 1890–1995), combining individual-level data (the 1915 Iowa State Census sample, IPUMS 1940–1960), matched manufacturing wage distributions (1890 vs. c.1940), and county-level agricultural outcomes (1915–1925). The units are workers, occupations, industries, and counties in the United States (with an Iowa case study). Analyses situate changes amid the high-school expansion, WWI, the Great Depression, WWII, immigration shifts, union activity, and labor-market regulation (e.g., FLSA).
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Learning and Forgetting:  The Dynamics of Aircraft Production
author: C. Lanier Benkard
context: This paper analyzes unit-level direct labor hours for all 250 Lockheed L-1011 commercial airliners produced in the United States (Burbank and Palmdale plants) between 1970 and 1984. Using plane-level completion dates and model type (-1/-100/-200 versus -500), the author studies how cumulative production, production rates, union "displacement rights" and model introductions affect learning-by-doing, organizational forgetting (experience depreciation), and within-firm spillovers. The setting is a volatile commercial aircraft market with union rules, simultaneous multi-model production, and large sunk development costs that shape production scheduling and productivity dynamics.
identification_methods: IV; other time-series regressions; others

title: Information Technology, Workplace Organization and the Demand for Skilled Labor:  Firm-Level Evidence
author: Timothy F. Bresnahan, Erik Brynjolfsson, Lorin M. Hitt
context: This paper examines how information technology, workplace organization, and human capital jointly affect firm-level labor demand and productivity in the United States. It uses a matched dataset: a 1995–96 cross-sectional survey of organizational practices for ~416 large U.S. firms (≈55% manufacturing) combined with firm-level IT capital panels covering 1987–1994 and Compustat output data. The analysis focuses on firms as the unit of observation and situates results in the context of falling IT prices and IT-enabled organizational change driving skill-biased technical change.

title: Participation in Heterogeneous Communities
author: Alberto Alesina, Eliana La Ferrara
context: Using pooled General Social Survey cross-sections (1974–1994) matched to MSA/PMSA characteristics, the paper tests how 1990 Census–based racial fragmentation at the metropolitan level affects individual membership in voluntary groups. Units are individual GSS respondents nested in MSAs/PMSAs; racial fragmentation is measured from the 1990 Census (probability two randomly drawn residents differ in race) and treated as time-invariant. title: Multinational Firms:  Reconciling Theory and Evidence
author: James R. Markusen, Keith E. Maskus
context: This paper empirically examines how parent- and host-country characteristics shape foreign affiliate production (local sales versus export sales) using annual panel data for 1986–1994 on non-bank manufacturing affiliate sales between the United States and 36 other countries. The unit of observation is country-pair–year affiliate sales (inward and outward series). The analysis is embedded in a knowledge-capital multinational framework and uses covariates such as GDP and GDP differences, skilled-labor shares, trade and investment-cost indices, distance, and interaction terms to capture scale, endowment, and transaction-cost effects.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: What is Social Capital?  The Determinants of Trust and Trustworthiness
author: Edward L. Glaeser, David Laibson, Jose A. Scheinkman, Christine L. Soutter
context: This paper uses laboratory and field-style experiments conducted with Harvard undergraduates in the late 1990s (recruited during the first week of an introductory economics course, with experimental sessions 3–4 weeks later) in Cambridge, MA. Units are individual students (N≈258 surveyed, ≈196 in experiments). Subjects played a monetary trust game (senders chose $0–$15; amounts doubled; recipients decided returns) and an envelope-drop valuation ($10 envelope dropped in public places). The design includes a randomized promise treatment and surveys measuring social ties and demographics.

context: This paper uses plant-level data from U.S. Census quinquennial Censuses (primarily 1972–1992) and 1992 PACE data to study how county ozone non-attainment designations under the Clean Air Act (post‑1977/1978) affected industrial organic chemicals (SIC 2865–9) and miscellaneous plastics (SIC 308) plants across U.S. counties. title: Asset Pricing with Heterogeneous Consumers and Limited Participation: Empirical Evidence
author: Alon Brav, George M. Constantinides, Christopher C. Geczy
context: Using U.S. household data reconstructed from the Consumer Expenditure Survey (CEX), the paper tests consumption-based asset-pricing Euler equations for non-durables and services across households. It examines heterogeneity and limited capital market participation by comparing infra-marginal and marginal asset holders, relaxes complete consumption insurance, and studies implications for the equity premium and its correlation with cross-sectional consumption-variance. The analysis includes Monte Carlo simulations to assess measurement error and small-sample properties of test statistics.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: Does Aid Matter? Measuring the Effect of Student Aid on College Attendance and Completion
author: Susan M. Dynarski
context: This empirical study exploits the 1981–82 U.S. policy shock that eliminated the Social Security Student Benefit Program to estimate effects of grant-like student aid on college attendance and completed schooling. Using NLSY cohorts (high-school seniors 1979–81 versus 1982–83) and follow-up through 1996, the unit of observation is individuals (youth/households), comparing children of Social Security beneficiaries (proxied by deceased fathers) to others in the United States to identify causal impacts of generous monthly survivor benefits (avg ≈$5,400).

title: Peer Effects with Random Assignment: Results for Dartmouth Roommates
author: Bruce Sacerdote
context: This study analyzes Dartmouth College freshmen (primarily the classes of 1997–1998) using individual-level administrative records and incoming-freshman survey data. title: The Effects of Urban Concentration on Economic Growth
author: J. Vernon Henderson
context: This paper uses a cross-country panel of about 80–100 countries over 1960–1995 (five-year intervals) to estimate how national urban concentration—measured by primacy (the largest metro area’s share of national urban population)—affects economic growth. The unit of observation is the country-period; analyses control for income, human capital, investment, fertility, openness, federalism, and transport infrastructure (road and waterway density). The study exploits panel GMM/differenced estimation to address endogeneity while also examining policy levers that shape primacy.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Is Addiction Rational"? Theory and Evidence"
author: Jonathan Gruber, Botond Koszegi
context: The paper analyzes U.S. cigarette consumption responses to state excise tax changes, using legislative enactment and effective dates from 1973–1996, monthly state-level sales (1982–1996), and Vital Statistics natality smoking measures (1989–1996). Units are state-month aggregates and births (mothers) aggregated to state-month cells. The institutional setting is staggered state cigarette excise-tax increases across U.S. states; identification exploits announced-but-not-yet-effective tax hikes and short-run monthly variation to test forward-looking (anticipatory) behavior relative to rational-addiction models.

author: Claudia Goldin, Lawrence F. Katz
context: This study analyzes U.S. women — particularly college-educated cohorts born roughly in the late 1930s through the mid-1950s — across the 1960s–1970s. It exploits state-level variation in laws that lowered the age of majority and extended “mature minor”/family-planning rights which enabled diffusion of the oral contraceptive. Units are individual women observed in national surveys (NHIS, NSFG, NSYW/NSAF) and IPUMS/Census; outcomes include pill use, age at first marriage, fertility, and entry into professional schools, with controls for cohort and state effects and abortion-law changes.
identification_methods: DiD; other cross-sectional regressions

title: U.S. Banks, Crises, and Bailouts: From Mexico to LTCM
author: Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper studies daily stock-return responses of U.S. commercial banks (Datastream U.S. retail banking index, ~78 banks) to major emerging-market currency crises (Mexico 1994–95, Korea 1997–98, Russia 1998, Brazil 1998–99) and the LTCM episode (Sept 1998). It compares banks reporting positive exposures to crisis countries with non-exposed banks using portfolio event-study regressions controlling for U.S. market returns and short-term interest-rate changes to assess the impact of crises and IMF/market bailouts on bank valuations.
identification_methods: event studies

title: Capital Gains Realizations of the Rich and Sophisticated

title: Contractibility and Asset Ownership: On-Board Computers and Governance in U.S. Trucking
author: George P. Baker, Thomas N. Hubbard
context: This triplet refers to regressions of fuel economy using 1992 TIUS individual truck observations (diesel tractor‑tractors) in the U.S. trucking industry. The analysis regresses miles‑per‑gallon on on‑board computer (trip recorder and EVMS) indicators interacted with driver ownership status, controlling for truck make/model, engine, usage (distance, trailer type, load, single/double/triple), maintenance arrangements, and odometer. Results are reported separately by distance (short/medium/long-haul) and show OBC-related MPG gains concentrated in long‑haul trucks, especially for trip recorders and company drivers.

title: Can Falling Supply Explain the Rising Return to College for Younger Men? A Cohort-Based Analysis
author: David Card, Thomas Lemieux
treatment: Age-group specific relative supply of college workers
context: This paper analyzes labor-market data from the United States (1959–1996), the United Kingdom (1974–1996), and Canada (1981–1996), using repeated cross-sections (Census, CPS, GHS) of male workers by 5-year age/cohort groups to study how inter-cohort changes in college versus high‑school relative supply affected the college–high school wage gap. Focusing mainly on men ages 26–60 (and robustness including women), the authors combine a CES production model with age, year, and cohort fixed‑effects regressions to estimate substitution elasticities and attribute the rise in the college premium for younger cohorts to a post‑1950 slowdown in cohort educational attainment.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: Investment-Cash Flow Sensitivities are not Valid Measures of Financing Constraints
author: Steven N. Kaplan, Luigi Zingales
context: This paper examines whether investment–cash flow sensitivities credibly indicate financing constraints using firm-level theory and empirical evidence for U.S. publicly traded firms primarily in the 1980s–1990s. Units are firms/firm-years; analyses compare investment responses to internal cash flow across groups (e.g., Microsoft, Hewlett‑Packard) and consider heterogeneity in external finance costs, cash holdings, and distress. The institutional setting is corporate finance markets and firm-level liquidity decisions in the U.S., with emphasis on models of external finance costs and empirical sample splits to infer causal links.

title: The Power of Suggestion: Inertia in 401(k) Participation and Savings Behavior
author: Brigitte C. Madrian, Dennis F. Shea
context: Analyzes employee-level 401(k) behavior at a large U.S. Fortune 500 health insurance company using administrative data from June 1997–June 1999 around an April 1, 1998 policy change. Units are individual employees grouped into hiring cohorts (OLD, WINDOW, NEW). The firm switched from one-year eligibility with affirmative enrollment to immediate eligibility with automatic enrollment (default 3% contribution into a money-market fund, opt-out possible) while keeping economic plan features (match, fund menu) unchanged, exploiting this quasi-experiment to estimate effects on participation, contributions, and allocations.

title: A Dynamic Analysis of the Market for Wide-Bodied Commercial Aircraft
author: C. Lanier Benkard
context: This paper studies the global market for wide-bodied commercial jet aircraft from the late 1960s through the 1990s (primarily 1972–1994), using firm- and model-level production, price, cost, and delivery data. Units of observation include aircraft models, manufacturers/firms and annual market size; the setting is an oligopolistic, capacity-constrained commercial aircraft industry with learning-by-doing (organizational forgetting), large development costs, and entry/exit. The paper combines structural estimation and dynamic simulation to evaluate pricing, industry dynamics, and counterfactual antitrust/industrial policies.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: The World Technology Frontier
author: Francesco Caselli, Wilbur John Coleman II
context: This paper analyzes cross-country differences in factor-specific efficiencies and the choice of "appropriate" technologies using a cross-section of 52 countries in the late 1980s (GDP and capital for 1988, schooling 1985). The unit of observation is the country (per-worker GDP, physical capital, skilled/unskilled labor aggregates). The authors combine PPP-adjusted GDP and perpetual-inventory capital estimates (Summers–Heston/Hall–Jones), Barro–Lee schooling, and Bils–Klenow returns to structurally estimate a technology-frontier model while assuming a common world interest rate and country-specific adoption barriers.
identification_methods: others

title: On the Nature of Capital Adjustment Costs
author: Russell W. Cooper, John C. Haltiwanger
context: This paper analyzes a balanced panel of about 7,000 U.S. manufacturing plants continuously operating from 1972–1988 (Longitudinal Research Database). The unit of observation is the plant-year with detailed real gross expenditures and retirements used to construct capital stocks and investment rates. title: Liquidity Risk and Expected Stock Returns
author: Lubos Pastor, Robert F. Stambaugh
context: This result is estimated using U.S. common stocks (NYSE, AMEX, NASDAQ) over 1966–1999. The authors construct a monthly aggregate liquidity innovation from signed-volume return-reversal regressions, predict stock-level liquidity betas, and form annual decile portfolios by predicted liquidity beta. title: Worms: Education and Health Externalities in Kenya
author: Edward Miguel, Michael Kremer
outcome: School participation among untreated pupils in treated schools
context: This empirical study evaluates a randomized, phased-in school-based deworming program in Budalangi and Funyula divisions of Busia District, western Kenya, during 1998–1999 (with a later rollout in 2001). title: The Impacts of Environmental Regulations on Industrial Activity: Evidence from the 1970 & 1977 Clean Air Act Amendments and the Census of Manufactures
author: Michael Greenstone
context: This paper studies the effects of the 1970 and 1977 U.S. Clean Air Act Amendments on manufacturing using plant-level Census of Manufactures data from 1967–1987. title: Estimation of a Dynamic Auction Game
author: Mireia Jofre-Bonet, Martin Pesendorfer
context: This paper estimates a dynamic first-price repeated procurement auction with capacity constraints using California Department of Transportation highway paving auction data from May 1996 to May 1999. Units are bidders (classified as regular and fringe) and contract-level sealed bids across 2,207 awarded projects. Institutional features include reserve prices, sealed-bid awarding to the low bidder, multi-month contract durations creating backlog and capacity effects, and observable contract characteristics. The authors use a structural two-stage estimator and reduced-form regressions to quantify backlog effects and efficiency losses.

author: Dora L. Costa, Matthew E. Kahn

title: The Q-Theory of Mergers
author: Boyan Jovanovic, Peter L. Rousseau
context: The paper develops a Q-theory of mergers and tests it on U.S. exchange-listed firms using Compustat and CRSP. context: This paper studies how local financial development within Italy during the late 1980s–1990s affects entrepreneurship, firm entry, competition, firm growth, and regional GDP growth. Using household survey data (SHIW 1989–98) on loan rejection/discouragement, province-level firm registers, and firm balance-sheet data (Centrale dei Bilanci) across Italian provinces/regions, the authors analyze individual, firm, and regional outcomes in a politically and regulatorily unified national market, exploiting cross-regional variation and instruments such as judicial inefficiency and social capital.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Estimating the Knowledge-Capital Model of the Multinational Enterprise: Comment
author: Bruce A. Blonigen, Ronald B. Davies, Keith Head
context: The paper empirically reanalyzes multinational enterprise activity using bilateral parent–host country–year observations: primarily pooled U.S. inbound and outbound affiliate sales (1986–1994), plus robustness samples extending 1983–1992 for an expanded U.S. sample and 1982–1992 for an OECD FDI-stock sample. Units are country-pair–year affiliate sales or FDI stock. The setting is cross-country MNE investment between developed countries, testing how skill endowment differences, GDP/size disparities, and trade/investment costs affect affiliate activity (horizontal vs. knowledge-capital/vertical motives).
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Micro Effects of Macro Announcements: Real-Time Price Discovery in Foreign Exchange
author: Torben G. Andersen, Tim Bollerslev, Francis X. Diebold, Clara Vega
context: This empirical paper analyzes 5‑minute interbank spot exchange‑rate returns for the U.S. dollar versus the German mark, British pound, Japanese yen, Swiss franc and euro using Reuters quotes from January 1992–December 1998. Units are 5‑minute returns around scheduled U.S. and German macroeconomic announcements (including FOMC) paired with real‑time MMS survey forecasts and realized releases. The institutional setting is the global interbank FX market; analyses focus on immediate price discovery and volatility responses to announcement “surprises” across currencies and announcement types.

title: Women, War and Wages: The Effect of Female Labor Supply on the Wage Structure at Mid-Century
author: Daron Acemoglu, David H. Autor, David Lyle
context: The paper exploits World War II as an exogenous shock (primarily 1940–1950, with checks into 1947–1960) across the continental U.S. to study how wartime male mobilization altered female labor supply and thereby affected female and male weekly wages, skill premia, and male inequality. Using individual-level IPUMS Census samples (1940, 1950, 1960), CPS/Social Security match data, and state-level aggregates for ~47 states, the authors leverage cross-state differences in draft/enlistment rates (and their demographic predictors) with state fixed-effects comparisons to identify causal impacts.
identification_methods: IV; DiD; other panel regressions

title: Using Mandated Speed Limits to Measure the Value of a Statistical Life
author: Orley Ashenfelter, Michael Greenstone
outcome: Hours required to travel a mile
context: Study examines the effect of states' adoption of a 65 mph maximum speed limit (the 1987 federal change that allowed states to raise rural interstate limits) on hours required to travel a mile (the reciprocal of average speed times vehicle miles traveled). Using state-by-roadtype-by-year panel data for 1982–93 and focusing on rural interstates (including 21 adopting states with complete post-1987 speed data), the paper fits the reduced-form equation (12b) on pooled years and finds about a 4% decrease in hours per mile on rural interstates after adoption, with no effect on urban interstates or rural arterials.
identification_methods: DiD

title: In Search of the Holy Grail: Policy Convergence, Experimentation, and Economic Performance
author: Sharun Mukand, Dani Rodrik
context: Analyzes post-socialist countries’ policy choices and economic performance after the collapse of socialism (early 1990s onward), using countries as the unit of observation. Empirical tests focus on former socialist European countries transitioning to market institutions, taking Western Europe (proxied by Brussels) as the leader to emulate; geographic distance to Brussels is used as an inverse proxy for suitability of European-style institutions. Background: a theoretical model of policy imitation versus experimentation, transparency and corruption; outcomes include post-transition growth, reform indices, and corruption measures with controls for other determinants.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Human Capital Spillovers in Manufacturing: Evidence from Plant-Level Production Functions
author: Enrico Moretti
treatment: Share of college graduates in city
context: This paper studies human-capital spillovers across US manufacturing plants using plant-level production functions estimated on a unique firm–worker matched dataset (Census of Manufacturers linked to the Census of Population). Heterogeneity by industry technology intensity and interplant interaction is examined.

title: PPP Strikes Back: Aggregation and the Real Exchange Rate
author: Jean Imbs, Haroon Mumtaz, Morton O. Ravn, Helene Rey
context: This empirical study uses monthly Eurostat sectoral CPI price indices (19 goods across ≈13 European countries; about 222 country–sector series) and aggregate CPI real exchange rates versus the US dollar over roughly 1975–1996. Units are country–sector monthly relative prices and country-level aggregate real exchange rates. The paper examines how cross‑sector heterogeneity in autoregressive dynamics biases pooled and aggregate estimates of real‑exchange‑rate persistence (half‑lives), comparing fixed‑effects, Anderson‑Hsiao/Arellano‑Bond dynamic panels, aggregate ARs and a Random Coefficient Model, with Monte‑Carlo simulations; motivation is the PPP puzzle, arbitrage frictions and nominal rigidities.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: Equity market liberalizations as country IPOs
author: Rodolfo Martell, Rene M. Stulz
context: The paper studies equity-market liberalizations in emerging-market countries roughly from the late 1970s through September 2000, using country-level S&P EMDB total-return indices for liberalizing countries (about 15 with 5-year pre/post windows around liberalization months from Bekaert & Harvey and Henry). title: What Can Be Learned from Skeletons that Might Interest Economists, Historians and Other Social Scientists?
author: Richard H. Steckel
context: This paper analyzes 12,520 skeletons from 65 localities across the Western Hemisphere over the past several millennia (including 4,078 individuals from 23 pre‑Columbian sites in North, Central and South America). Using individual skeletal measures aggregated to community/locality level, it constructs a seven‑component morbidity-based health index (age-weighted using a Model West reference life table) and compares health across settlement types (mobile, village, urban) and historical environments to assess how settlement size and related conditions affected community health.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Consumption Risk and Expected Stock Returns
author: Jonathan A. Parker
context: Using U.S. quarterly data (1947 Q2–1998 Q1), the paper evaluates how aggregate and household-level consumption risk (real per‑capita chain‑weighted nondurable consumption) relates to expected stock returns (value‑weighted NYSE market returns and Fama–French portfolios). Within a (C‑)CAPM framework it contrasts contemporaneous and long‑horizon consumption betas (S quarters ahead) and examines consumption of stockholders using the Consumer Expenditure Survey. The institutional setting is U.S. financial markets with the three‑month T‑bill as the risk‑free rate, emphasizing consumption smoothing and limited stock‑market participation.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Are Idle Hands the Devil's Workshop? Incapacitation, Concentration and Juvenile Crime
author: Brian A. Jacob, Lars Lefgren
context: This paper analyzes daily incident- and arrest-level crime data (NIBRS) for 29 U.S. jurisdictions during 1995–1999, merged with school-district calendars. The unit of observation is city-day counts of juvenile offenders; the setting is U.S. public school calendars (teacher in-service days, holidays, breaks, summer). The study exploits plausibly exogenous variation in in-service and idiosyncratic break days to estimate short-run effects of school being in session on juvenile property and violent crime, controlling for city*year*month and day-of-week effects and testing robustness with NCVS checks and weekly aggregation.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; event studies

title: The Labor Demand Curve is Downward Sloping: Reexamining the Impact of Immigration on the Labor Market
author: George J. Borjas
context: Using U.S. microdata (1960–1990 Decennial Census PUMS and pooled 1999–2001 CPS), the paper studies how immigration altered wages and labor supply of prime‑age men (ages 18–64) grouped by education and experience across U.S. labor markets (nationally and by state/region) over 1960–2000. It exploits variation in immigrant shares across schooling‑experience cells, assumes similarly educated workers with different experience are imperfect substitutes, and combines reduced‑form regressions with structural CES demand exercises to quantify wage and employment effects.

title: The Regulation of Labor
author: Simeon Djankov, Rafael La Porta, Florencio Lopez-de-Silane, Andrei Shleifer, Juan Botero
context: This paper analyzes cross-country variation in labor-market regulation using detailed indices of employment law, collective-bargaining law, and social‑security law measured around 1997 for 85 countries. Units are countries; political controls use the fraction of years that executives and legislatures were left/center between 1975–1995 (and robustness to 1928–1995). title: Judicial Checks and Balances
author: Rafael LaPorta, Florencio Lopez-de-Silane, Cristian Pop-Eleches, Andrei Shleifer
context: This paper studies 71 non-transition countries (sample based on Maddex 1995), relating constitutional provisions — judicial independence (tenure of supreme and administrative judges, case law) and constitutional review (rigidity, judicial review) — to mid-1990s measures of economic and political freedom (property rights c.1997, business entry procedures, employment regulation, government bank ownership c.1995, democracy and human/political rights mid-1990s). title: Is the Social Security Trust Fund Worth Anything?
author: Kent Smetters
context: This paper analyzes U.S. federal fiscal accounts using annual data from 1949–2002 to test whether Social Security off‑budget surpluses reduced debt held by the public or instead financed larger on‑budget spending/tax cuts. The unit of observation is yearly national budget aggregates (on‑budget and off‑budget primary surpluses, trust fund assets), in the U.S. institutional setting that includes the 1969–70 adoption of a unified budget, payroll‑tax increases starting in 1983, and Social Security Trustees’ projections through the 2010s–2040s.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: A New Measure of Monetary Shocks: Derivation and Implications
author: Christina D. Romer, David H. Romer
context: This paper analyzes U.S. monetary policy during 1969–1996. It constructs exogenous monetary shocks from intended federal-funds-rate changes around FOMC meetings using Federal Reserve Greenbook forecasts, internal expected-funds memos, and FOMC narrative records. Units of analysis are FOMC meetings and monthly macro series (industrial production, PPI). The institutional setting is Federal Reserve policymaking across Burns–Volcker–Greenspan eras, exploiting meeting-timed policy intentions and residualized shocks to estimate causal effects of monetary policy on output and prices.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: How Do Hospitals Respond to Price Changes?
author: Leemore S. Dafny
context: Using U.S. Medicare inpatient data (20% MedPAR sample) from 1985–1991, this paper studies hospital responses to an exogenous 1988 HCFA reform that removed the “age over 69” qualifier from DRG definitions under Medicare’s Prospective Payment System. The analysis uses Medicare hospital discharges and aggregated hospital-DRG-year cells to examine changes in DRG prices, coding (upcoding), intensity of care, and admissions following the shock to diagnosis-specific reimbursement.

title: Why the Apple Doesn't Fall Far: Understanding Intergenerational Transmission of Human Capital
author: Sandra E. Black, Paul J. Devereux, Kjell G. Salvanes
context: This analysis uses Norwegian administrative and census registers linking parents (born 1947–1958) to the municipality in which they grew up to estimate how the 1960–1972 staggered reform that raised compulsory schooling from 7 to 9 years affected parental educational attainment. The reform was implemented at the municipality level and primarily increased attainment in the lower tail: the share with fewer than 9 years fell from about 12% to under 3%, producing a spike at 9 years.

title: Why the Apple Doesn't Fall Far: Understanding Intergenerational Transmission of Human Capital
author: Sandra E. Black, Paul J. Devereux, Kjell G. Salvanes
context: This estimate uses Norwegian administrative and census data exploiting the staggered 1960–1972 municipal implementation of a reform raising compulsory schooling from 7 to 9 years as an instrument for parental education. It focuses on parents born 1947–1958 (linked to their municipality of upbringing) and their adult children (aged 20–35 in 2000); the causal IV (2SLS) estimates for fathers are primarily identified using the reform's effects on parents in the lower tail (≤9 years) of the education distribution.
identification_methods: IV; DiD; other panel regressions

title: What Mean Impacts Miss: Distributional Effects of Welfare Reform Experiments
author: Marianne Bitler, Jonah Gelbach, Hilary Hoynes
context: This estimate uses MDRC’s randomized Jobs First waiver experiment in Connecticut (New Haven and Manchester), with random assignment April 1996–February 1997 and follow‑up through December 2000, for 4,803 welfare cases (women). title: What Mean Impacts Miss: Distributional Effects of Welfare Reform Experiments
author: Marianne Bitler, Jonah Gelbach, Hilary Hoynes
context: This triplet is estimated using MDRC’s randomized Jobs First waiver experiment in Connecticut (New Haven and Manchester; random assignment April 1996–February 1997; follow-up through December 2000) on 4,803 welfare cases (women).
