title: Air Pollution and Infant Health: What Can We Learn From California's Recent Experience
author: Janet Currie, Matthew Neidell
context: This paper analyzes individual-level birth, fetal-death, and infant-mortality records in California over the 1990s (approximately 1989–2000), linking pregnancies and infants (by maternal 5-digit ZIP) to ambient pollution measures for four criteria pollutants (O3, CO, PM10, NO2) from monitoring stations. The institutional setting is California during a period of declining pollution and active air-quality regulation. The authors exploit within–ZIP-code temporal variation (controlling for ZIP fixed effects, month/year seasonality, weather) to estimate prenatal and postnatal pollution impacts on birth outcomes and infant mortality.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Are Americans Saving Optimally" for Retirement?"
author: John Karl Scholz, Ananth Seshadri, Surachai Khitatrakun
outcome: Acquiring more wealth than the optimal target

title: What do Aggregate Consumption Euler Equations Say about the Capital Income Tax Burden?
author: Casey B. Mulligan
context: This paper uses U.S. aggregate annual data (primarily 1947–1997) to study how capital income taxation affects the wedge between expected pre-tax returns on the capital stock and consumption growth. Units are national aggregates—BEA measures of pre-tax and after-tax capital returns, per-capita nondurable and services consumption, and capital-income tax revenue (federal, state, local). The analysis relies on consumption Euler equations, VARs to form expectations, and TSLS estimates to infer capital supply elasticity and tax incidence in the mid-to-late 20th century United States.
identification_methods: IV; other time-series regressions

title: Thirty Years of Current Account Imbalances, Current Account Reversals and Sudden Stops
author: Sebastian Edwards
context: Using annual country-year data for 157 countries over 1970–2001, this paper studies current-account imbalances, large deficit “reversals,” and “sudden stops.” The unit of observation is the country-year across six regions (industrial, Latin America/Caribbean, Asia, Africa, MENA, Eastern Europe). Analyses relate lagged external debt, reserves, short-term debt, and credit growth to reversal probability and estimate reversal impacts on GDP growth, contextualized by 1970s oil shocks, the 1980s debt crisis, 1990s currency crises, IMF programs, and varying exchange-rate/dollarization regimes.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; others

title: Business Cycle Accounting
author: V.V. Chari, Patrick J. Kehoe, Ellen McGrattan
context: This paper analyzes U.S. aggregate business cycle episodes — principally the Great Depression (1929–39), the 1982 recession (1979–85), and the postwar period (1959:1–2004:3) — using national-level time series on output, labor, investment and government consumption. It maps frictions (credit, sticky wages, monopoly power) into four time-varying wedges (efficiency, labor, investment, government consumption) within a stochastic growth prototype, estimates a vector AR(1) process for wedges from macro data, and feeds measured wedges into calibrated structural models to assess their contributions to fluctuations.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: The Impact of Nearly Universal Insurance Coverage on Health Care Utilization and Health: Evidence from Medicare
author: David Card, Carlos Dobkin, Nicole Maestas
context: This paper analyzes U.S. microdata—pooled NHIS (1992–2001) and BRFSS (1998–2002) surveys, state hospital discharge records (California and Florida, 1995–1999/2000), and national death files—to study individuals and hospital admissions around the Medicare eligibility cutoff. Exploiting the institutional rule that most people become eligible for Medicare at age 65 (Part A/B availability subject to work-history rules), the authors estimate how the near-universal jump in coverage at 65 affects access, utilization, procedures, and self-reported and mortality outcomes for people just below and above 65.
identification_methods: RDD; IV

title: Which Countries Have State Religions?
author: Robert J. Barro, Rachel M. McCleary
context: This paper analyzes determinants of official state religions for 188 countries using historical indicators of state-religion status in 1900 and observed outcomes in 1970 and 2000. The unit is the country; analyses account for major regime changes (independence, territorial splits, adoption/ending of Communism), measures of religious adherence concentration and faith shares, colonial and legal origins, and macro controls (per-capita GDP, region). The focus is on persistence and causal effects shaping establishment, removal, and reintroduction of state religions over the 20th century.

title: Measuring Self-Control
author: John Ameriks, Andrew Caplin, John Leahy, Tom Tyler
context: This paper analyzes survey data from U.S. TIAA‑CREF participants (main survey fielded Feb 2003, with earlier SPF Jan 2000 and FAB Jan 2001) covering about 1,520 respondents (net-worth regressions use a smaller subsample). It elicits self‑control via a two‑period “free dinner” certificate allocation framed by the Gul–Pesendorfer temptation model and links measured self‑control and personality (Big Five, especially conscientiousness) to cross‑sectional variation in net worth and asset composition (liquid vs retirement).

title: Earnings Manipulation and Managerial Investment Decisions: Evidence from Sponsored Pension Plans
author: Daniel Bergstresser, Mihir A. Desai, Joshua Rauh
context: Studies US publicly traded firms sponsoring defined-benefit pension plans over 1991–2002 (≈3,247 firms, 19,325 firm‑years), using Compustat, SDC M&A data, ExecComp, Pensions & Investments and IRS Form 5500. It examines firms’ assumed long‑term pension asset return (LTROR), CEO option exercises, and acquisition timing under U.S. pension accounting (SFAS 87) where managers have discretion over LTROR and gain/loss amortization. Units are firm‑years (and CEOs for option analyses); identification exploits timing variation, within‑firm changes, and instruments to link opportunistic LTROR choices to pension allocations and reported earnings.

title: Asymmetric Cycles
author: Boyan Jovanovic
treatment: Random adjustment costs in technology adoption
context: The paper develops and estimates a structural model of technology adoption with costly retooling using U.S. data. It fits the model to U.S. real GDP per capita from 1790–2000 (five- and ten-year intervals) to estimate growth dynamics and uses plant-level TFP conditional distributions (e.g., 1982–1987 manufacturing plant data) to illustrate cross-sectional skewness. Units of analysis are the aggregate economy (per-capita GDP) and individual firms/plants; the framework assumes technological commitment, random adjustment shocks to required skills, and costly within-firm skill retooling.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: The Gift of the Dying: The Tragedy of AIDS and the Welfare of Future African Generations
author: Alwyn Young

title: Systemic Crises and Growth
author: Romain Ranciere, Aaron Tornell, Frank Westermann
context: Using cross-country annual data (primarily 1961–2000, sample of ~58 countries aggregated into non‑overlapping decades), the paper links systemic financial risk—proxied by skewness of real bank‑credit growth and multiple crisis indexes—to per‑capita GDP growth and investment. The unit of analysis is countries (and country‑decades); key institutional contrasts are financial liberalization (de facto and de jure indexes) and contract enforceability (1984 law‑and‑order index). The empirical tests exploit cross‑country and decade variation to evaluate a theoretical model where liberalization plus moderate enforceability and bailout guarantees induce systemic risk‑taking.

title: Cost-Effective Policies to Reduce Vehicle Emissions

title: From Education to Democracy?
author: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, James A. Robinson, Pierre Yared
context: This paper studies country-level panels (about 108 countries) over the postwar period (mainly 1965–2000 at five-year intervals, with 10-year checks) to test whether increases in average years of adult schooling lead to democratization. Units are countries; democracy is measured by Freedom House, Polity, and Przeworski-based indices and schooling by Barro–Lee. title: Lucky Stores, Gambling, and Addiction: Empirical Evidence from State Lottery Sales
author: Jonathan Guryan, Melissa S. Kearney
treatment: Sale of a winning jackpot ticket
context: Using weekly store-level lottery-sales data for all Texas retailers from January 2000 to June 2002, this paper examines how the sale of winning tickets in three lotto games (Lotto Texas, Texas Two-Step, Cash 5) affects subsequent ticket sales. Units are retail outlets and 5/9-digit zip codes; the institutional setting is the Texas Lottery Commission’s statewide lotto system with publicly posted winner locations and jackpots. The random assignment of winners (conditional on contemporaneous sales) provides exogenous shocks exploited to study demand responses, spatial substitution, demographic heterogeneity, and persistence/habit-formation (addiction).

title: Measuring the Implications of Sales and Consumer Inventory Behavior
author: Igal Hendel, Aviv Nevo
context: This paper uses household-level scanner data from June 1991–June 1993 (104 weekly observations) in two submarkets of a large Midwestern U.S. city (nine supermarkets) to study laundry-detergent purchases. The unit is the household-week decision over brand and container size; the data record prices, promotions (feature/display), store visits and quantities for roughly 1,000 panel households (estimation sample ~221). The authors structurally estimate a dynamic consumer-inventory model with stochastic prices and promotions to recover long-run own- and cross-price elasticities accounting for stockpiling.

title: The Marginal Product of Capital
author: Francesco Caselli, James Feyrer
outcome: Heterogeneity in marginal product of capital
context: Cross-country analysis using a cross-section of about 53 countries circa 1996–2000 (Penn World Tables 6.1 for GDP/capital; World Bank wealth data ~2000; Bernanke & Gurkaynak capital shares). title: From the Cradle to the Labor Market?  The Effect of Birth Weight on Adult Outcomes
author: Sandra E. Black, Paul J. Devereux, Kjell Salvanes
context: This paper studies Norwegian births 1967–1997 (with adult outcomes for earlier cohorts, e.g., men born 1967–1987 observed into 2002–2005), linking the Medical Birth Registry to administrative education, tax/earnings, and military exam records. title: Surviving Andersonville: The Benefits of Social Networks in POW Camps
author: Dora L. Costa, Matthew E. Kahn

context: This paper analyzes Union Army prisoners of war during the American Civil War (primarily 1863–1865), focusing on individual POWs held in Confederate prison camps—most prominently Andersonville (GA)—using a longitudinal sample of soldiers from 303 companies and a near-census cross-section of ≈35,000 Andersonville inmates. title: Technological Revolutions and Stock Prices

title: Life-Cycle Variation in the Association between Current and Lifetime Earnings
author: Steven Haider, Gary Solon
context: The paper uses Social Security earnings histories (1951–1991) linked to the Health and Retirement Study for U.S. men born 1931–1933 to estimate Tobit-based joint distributions and simulate uncensored lifetime earnings. Applying these estimates to the intergenerational mobility regression (son’s log lifetime earnings on father’s log lifetime earnings), the paper shows that right-side measurement error from using short-run proxies for fathers’ lifetime earnings induces attenuation (downward bias) in OLS; this conclusion is based on estimated θ_t (figures 2–3).
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: The Quiet Revolution that Transformed Women's Employment, Education, and Family
author: Claudia Goldin
treatment: Increase in divorce and later age at marriage

title: Dividend Taxes and Firm Valuation: New Evidence
author: Alan J. Auerbach, Kevin A. Hassett
treatment: Higher probability of dividend tax cut extension
context: This paper analyzes US publicly traded firms (CRSP/Compustat universe, 2002 onward) to study market valuation responses to the 2003 Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Act—which cut top dividend tax rates from 35% to 15% effective through 2008—and the uncertain prospect of its extension around the 2004 Presidential election. title: Democracy and Development: The Devil in the Details
author: Torsten Persson, Guido Tabellini
context: The paper uses annual country-year data on about 150 countries (main analyses 1960–2000; extended 1850–2000 for expectation analysis) to study effects of regime changes on log per-capita income and investment. It exploits episodes of democratization, autocracy, and economic liberalization (Polity2; Sachs–Warner liberalization), variation in forms of government and electoral rules (presidential vs parliamentary; majoritarian vs proportional), and controls for wars and former Soviet-bloc transitions; expected regime-change hazards (democratic capital) are modeled.

context: Using AHA hospital panel data for fiscal years 1980–1986 (four pre and three post years), the paper studies U.S. hospitals (≈6,200 annually, excluding MA/NY/MD/NJ waivers) to assess how the October 1983 Medicare Prospective Payment System (PPS) — a shift from full cost to partial cost reimbursement (prospective payments for operating costs while capital remained cost‑reimbursed) — affected hospitals’ input mix, technology adoption, length of stay, and nurse skill composition. Identification leverages pre‑PPS Medicare share of patient days interacted with post‑PPS timing.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Disease and Development: The Effect of Life Expectancy on Economic Growth
author: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson
context: This cross-country study analyzes country-level effects of the mid-20th-century “international epidemiological transition” (primarily 1940–1980) across about 59 countries (decadal country-year observations). The unit is the country; outcomes include life expectancy, population, total births, GDP and GDP per capita. Identification exploits exogenous timing of global health interventions (e.g., antibiotics, DDT, WHO campaigns) interacted with pre-1940 disease-specific mortality rates. The core institutional background is the global diffusion of medical and public-health technologies after WWII and resulting differential mortality declines by baseline disease burden.
identification_methods: IV; event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Sources of Advantageous Selection: Evidence from the Medigap Insurance Market
author: Hanming Fang, Michael P. Keane, Dan Silverman
context: This study (Fang, Keane, Silverman, 2006) analyzes selection into Medigap supplemental insurance among U.S. Medicare beneficiaries (age 65+) using Medicare Current Beneficiary Survey data (circa 1999–2001/2000–2001) and Health and Retirement Study waves (2000–2002). The unit of analysis is individual Medicare beneficiaries across U.S. states where Medigap pricing and standardized plans and a six-month open-enrollment rule limit risk-based pricing. The paper leverages detailed medical expenditure records, rich health measures, and HRS measures (income, cognition, risk aversion, expectations) to study why healthier or lower-risk seniors purchase Medigap.

title: The Effect of Female Education on Fertility and Infant Health: Evidence from School Entry Policies Using Exact Date of Birth
author: Justin McCrary, Heather Royer
context: This study uses individual natality records from California (1989–2002) and Texas (1989–2001) on first-time mothers (focus on women ≤23) born in those states. It exploits state school-entry cutoffs (California: Dec 1; Texas: Sep 1) that create a discontinuity in schooling by exact date of birth to instrument for maternal education. The paper estimates effects of female education on fertility outcomes, prenatal behaviors, birthweight, prematurity, and infant mortality, leveraging local RD/IV methods and administrative birth and death records.
identification_methods: RDD; IV

title: The Effect of Court-Ordered Hiring Quotas on the Composition and Quality of Police
author: Justin McCrary
outcome: Fraction African American among newly hired officers
context: This paper studies the effects of 1969–1999 class-action and DOJ litigation that imposed court-ordered racial hiring quotas on municipal police departments across the United States. Using a panel of 314 large U.S. cities (a 120-city “long” sample with data back to 1960) and administrative EEOC and department records (detailed Chicago hiring data), the unit is city/police department. The institutional setting is civil-service rank-order hiring via entrance exams, disparate-impact litigation, and judge-imposed hiring quotas; outcomes include workforce composition, hiring shares, arrests, clearance rates, and city crime.

title: Stature and Status: Height, Ability, and Labor Market Outcomes
author: Anne Case, Christina Paxson
context: This paper uses longitudinal cohort and cross-sectional data from the UK and US to link childhood height, cognitive ability, and adult labor-market outcomes. It analyzes British 1958 and 1970 birth cohorts (tests at ages 5–11, earnings at ages 30–42), US datasets including NHIS (1986–1994 occupations/heights), PSID (1988–1997 men), and the Fragile Families birth cohort (early childhood), with individuals as units. The setting is developed-country labor markets; the analysis leverages measured childhood cognition, parental background, and height trajectories to assess how early-life health/nutrition correlates with occupational sorting and earnings.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: The Returns to Currency Speculation
author: Craig Burnside, Martin Eichenbaum, Isaac Kleshchelski, Sergio Rebelo
context: This triplet is evaluated using the paper’s monthly (non‑overlapping) interbank spot and 1‑ and 3‑month forward quotes (Jan 1976–Dec 2005) for nine developed‑country currencies quoted versus the British pound. The analysis of transactions‑costs uses a dealer “currency pricing matrix” (Table 12) and a linear order‑size bid‑ask spread schedule, with a concrete illustration for USD/GBP (e.g. 300m USD orders). Price‑pressure effects are incorporated using empirical order‑flow price‑impact estimates (Evans & Lyons; Berger et al.), applied to currency‑pair payoffs, portfolios and simulated traders.

title: Peers at Work
author: Alexandre Mas, Enrico Moretti
context: Using scanner data from a national supermarket chain’s six stores in one U.S. metropolitan area (2003–2006), the paper studies individual cashiers’ productivity measured as items scanned per second in ten-minute intervals. Units are cashier–ten-minute observations; setting is unionized stores with fixed hourly wages, unsystematic bi‑weekly scheduling, known register locations and orientations. Causal analyses exploit within‑day changes in co‑worker composition from staggered shifts and spatial monitoring to identify peer effects.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; event studies

title: Temporary Investment Tax Incentives: Theory with Evidence from Bonus Depreciation
author: Christopher House, Matthew D. Shapiro
context: This paper studies U.S. temporary bonus-depreciation tax incentives enacted in the 2002 (JCWAA) and 2003 (JGTRRA) laws—30% then 50% first-year bonus (retroactive to Sept 11, 2001; largely expiring end-2004)—and concurrent Section 179 expensing changes. Using quarterly BEA investment and price series matched to IRS/MACRS schedules for 36 capital-good types (panel 1959–2005, focus 2001–2005), it exploits cross-sectional eligibility (MACRS recovery ≤20 years) and time variation to identify effects on investment spending and observed investment prices in the U.S.

title: Tracing the Impact of Bank Liquidity Shocks: Evidence from an Emerging Market
author: Atif Mian, Asim Ijaz Khwaja
context: This paper studies how bank liquidity shocks following the unanticipated May 1998 India–Pakistan nuclear tests affected corporate lending and firm distress in Pakistan. Using the State Bank of Pakistan loan-level panel (July 1996–March 2000) covering ~22,000 loans to ~18,600 firms and 42 commercial banks, the authors exploit cross-bank variation in exposure to dollar deposit accounts and pre/post comparisons to isolate bank lending and firm borrowing channels. Key institutional features include central-bank exchange‑rate insurance of dollar deposits and the government-imposed partial freeze on dollar withdrawals.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions; IV; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Debt Enforcement Around the World

treatment: Extensive appeals and suspension during appeals
context: This paper empirically studies debt enforcement for an identical hypothetical insolvent hotel ("Mirage") using detailed survey responses from 344 insolvency practitioners and judges across 88 countries (sampled and benchmarked to January 2006; surveys 2003–2006). title: Backing, the Quantity Theory, and the Transition to the U.S. Dollar, 1723-1850
author: Peter L. Rousseau

title: The Spike at Benefit Exhaustion: Leaving the Unemployment System or Starting a New Job?
author: David Card, Raj Chetty, Andrea Weber
context: Using Austrian social security administrative records for involuntary job losses from 1981–2001, the paper analyzes about 92,969 individuals aged 20–50 to study exit hazards around unemployment insurance (UI) benefit exhaustion. Austria’s UI rules provide 20 or 30 weeks of benefits depending on months worked in the prior five years (36-month threshold), alongside severance pay rules and means-tested post-exhaustion assistance. The analysis contrasts registered-unemployment duration and time-to-next-job (including recalls) to assess whether spikes at benefit expiration reflect true re-employment or exits from the register.
identification_methods: RDD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Cementing Relationships: Vertical Integration, Foreclosure, Productivity, and Prices
author: Ali Hortacsu, Chad Syverson
context: This paper studies U.S. cement (upstream) and ready-mixed concrete (downstream) plants and firms using Census of Manufactures microdata from 1963–1997, constructing market-year observations (CEAs and USGS/EAs). Units are individual plants and markets; analyses exploit variation in vertical integration, multi-plant firms, firm entry/exit, and changing antitrust enforcement regimes and local construction demand. The setting features high transport costs, localized markets, and policy shifts in FTC/DOJ scrutiny of vertical mergers, allowing causal assessment of integration’s effects on prices, quantities, productivity, and turnover.

title: E-ZTax: Tax Salience and Tax Rates
author: Amy Finkelstein
context: This paper studies how adoption and diffusion of electronic toll collection (ETC, e.g. E‑ZPass) affected toll rates across 123 publicly owned U.S. toll facilities (roads, bridges, tunnels) in 22 state‑level jurisdictions. title: Estimating Trade Flows: Trading Partners and Trading Volumes
author: Elhanan Helpman, Marc Melitz, Yona Rubinstein
context: Using bilateral trade data for 158 countries over 1970–1997 (with focused analyses for 1986 and the 1980s), the paper examines exporter–importer country-pair outcomes (whether a link exists and export volumes). It embeds a heterogeneous‑firms model with fixed and variable export costs to decompose effects of trade frictions (distance, tariffs, WTO/FTA membership, common language, borders, currency unions, entry regulation) into intensive (exports per exporter) and extensive (number of exporters) margins. Empirical identification exploits exporter/importer fixed effects, a Probit selection for trading links, Heckman corrections, and structural counterfactuals.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Identifying Technology Spillovers and Product Market Rivalry

context: This paper empirically separates technology spillovers from product-market rivalry using a panel of U.S. publicly listed firms (715 firms) matched between Compustat (accounting/segment data, 1980–2001) and USPTO patent data (patents 1963–1999). title: The Power of TV: Cable Television and Women's Status in India
author: Robert Jensen, Emily Oster
context: Using a three-year panel (2001–2003) of 2,700 households in 180 clusters across five Indian states (rural Bihar, Goa, Haryana, Tamil Nadu and urban Delhi), the paper studies how the rapid rollout of cable/satellite television—typically installed by local entrepreneurs—affected women’s status. Units are individual women (15+) and children in sampled households; outcomes include autonomy, attitudes toward domestic violence and son preference, female school enrollment and fertility. Identification exploits within-individual changes as villages gain cable amid broader, state-level variation in penetration.

title: Intra-Industry Foreign Direct Investment
author: Laura Alfaro, Andrew Charlton
context: This paper uses Dun & Bradstreet WorldBase establishment-level data (2004–2005) covering roughly 650,000 multinational subsidiaries across about 90 countries and 400 four-digit SIC industries to study FDI motives. title: The Bidder's Curse

context: This paper analyzes forecasts and policy decisions of the U.S. Federal Reserve over 1979–2001 (forecast data through 2001; monetary-shock series through 1996). The unit of observation is twice-yearly FOMC-member and Board staff forecasts (Greenbooks and Monetary Policy Reports) and realized macro outcomes for inflation, unemployment, and real GDP growth. The institutional setting is the FOMC process in which members see staff forecasts and may revise forecasts after meetings; the paper examines whether policymakers’ forecast deviations predict subsequent federal funds rate surprises.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Using Tax Expenditures to Achieve Energy Policy Goals
author: Gilbert E. Metcalf
context: This paper analyzes U.S. federal and state energy tax expenditures, focusing on ethanol policy and its impacts in 2005–2006. title: Reference Prices and Nominal Rigidities
author: Martin Eichenbaum, Nir Jaimovich, Sergio Rebelo
context: This paper uses weekly scanner data (2004–2006) from a large U.S. food-and-drug retailer (sample: 243 stores and ~405,000 UPC-store pairs after restrictions) with supplementary Dominick's grocery data (1989–1997). The unit of observation is weekly UPC-store-level prices, quantities, and vendor replacement-costs, aggregated into product categories and quarterly reference prices. title: Life Expectancy and Human Capital Investments: Evidence From Maternal Mortality Declines
author: Seema Jayachandran, Adriana Lleras-Muney
context: Study of Sri Lanka during 1946–1953 exploiting a sharp 70% decline in maternal mortality across 19 districts to estimate effects on female life expectancy, literacy, years of schooling and fertility. Units: district-gender-year cells and birth cohorts/individuals (treated cohorts ages 5–19 in 1953), using vital statistics and 1946/1953 censuses (and 1971 census sample). Background: post‑WWII expansion of maternal health services, malaria eradication, free ambulances, and national education reforms; men serve as a plausibly unaffected control group.

title: Pass-Through in Retail and Wholesale
author: Emi Nakamura
context: This empirical study uses weekly scanner price and quantity data from AC Nielsen covering all twelve months of 2004 for roughly 7,000 U.S. grocery stores (members of 33 chains) across 50 major cities. title: Moral Hazard vs. Liquidity and Optimal Unemployment Insurance
author: Raj Chetty
context: This paper studies U.S. job losers using SIPP panels (1985–2000) and Mathematica surveys (Pennsylvania 1991; 25-state 1998), focusing on prime‑age unemployed individuals (mostly males) who claimed UI. title: Liquidation Values and the Credibility of Financial Contract Renegotiation: Evidence from U.S. Airlines
author: Efraim Benmelech, Nittai K. Bergman
outcome: Actual lease payments relative to contracted payments
context: This paper studies lease renegotiation by U.S. passenger airlines using firm-year data on 25 publicly traded carriers (1995–2005) and a case study of American’s 2001 acquisition of TWA. The institutional setting is the U.S. aircraft-leasing market and bankruptcy law (Section 365/Chapter 11), where lessors can repossess aircraft quickly. The authors exploit variation in airline financial distress, fleet “redeployability” (a proxy for liquidation value), bankruptcy episodes, and the 9/11 demand shock to estimate effects on lease payments.

title: What's News in Business Cycles
author: Stephanie Schmitt-Grohe, Martin Uribe
context: This paper estimates a structural DSGE model for the postwar U.S. economy using quarterly data from 1955:Q1–2006:Q4. The unit is the aggregate U.S. economy (per-capita GDP, consumption, investment, government spending, the relative price of investment, and hours worked). The model (an RBC framework with habit formation, investment adjustment costs, and variable capacity utilization) is driven by stationary and permanent TFP shocks, investment-specific shocks, and government spending shocks; Bayesian estimation separates anticipated from unanticipated innovations.

title: Understanding Bank Runs:  The Importance of Depositor-Bank Relationships and Networks
author: Rajkamal Iyer, Manju Puri
context: This paper studies depositor behavior around a March 2001 cooperative-bank failure in Gujarat, India. Using minute-by-minute transaction records (Jan 2000–Jan 2002) for deposit and loan accounts at a nearby cooperative bank headquarters, the unit of analysis is individual deposit accounts/households. The institutional setting includes India’s cooperative-banking rules (introducer requirement), flat deposit insurance (Rs100,000), no ATMs, and a localized run after a large bank’s fraud-induced collapse (event window March 9–15, 2001). Analyses exploit variation in account balances, account age, loan linkages, neighborhood/introducer networks, and withdrawal timing.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; event studies

title: Fetal Exposure to Toxic Releases and Infant Health
author: Janet Currie, Johannes F. Schmieder
context: Using U.S. data from roughly 1988–1999, the paper matches the EPA’s Toxic Release Inventory (TRI) to national Vital Statistics Natality and Mortality files to estimate effects of prenatal exposure to airborne toxic releases on gestation, birth weight, and infant mortality. title: Imported Intermediate Inputs and Domestic Product Growth: Evidence from India
author: Pinelopi K. Goldberg, Amit Khandelwal, Nina Pavcnik, Petia Topalova
context: This paper studies India’s 1991 trade liberalization and its effects on firm product scope during 1989–1997. Using a panel of ~2,927 manufacturing firms (Prowess) with firm–product data and detailed HS import data (1987–2000) mapped via India’s 1993–94 input–output matrix, the authors analyze how differential, unanticipated declines in input tariffs across industries affected imports of intermediate varieties and domestic firms’ new product introductions. The setting exploits sudden tariff cuts, industry heterogeneity, and firm fixed effects to identify causal links between imported input variety/prices and domestic product growth.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; IV

title: An Anatomy of International Trade: Evidence from French Firms
author: Jonathan Eaton, Samuel Kortum, Francis Kramarz
context: This paper studies French manufacturing firms using firm-level sales in 1986 for 229,900 firms (34,035 exporters) across 113 destinations (including France). It examines export entry, sales distributions, and how firm efficiency, fixed entry costs, and bilateral trade barriers shape participation and sales, combining customs and administrative manufacturing data. The authors estimate a heterogeneous‑firms trade model (Melitz-style) by the method of simulated moments and run general‑equilibrium counterfactuals (e.g., lower trade barriers or entry costs) to quantify effects on firm sales, exits, and welfare.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Information, Liquidity, and the (Ongoing) Panic of 2007
author: Gary B. Gorton
treatment: ABX information and lack of location information
context: This paper examines the U.S. subprime mortgage market and repo intermediation during the 2006–2008 housing downturn and the 2007 panic. Using daily ABX.HE index prices (launched January 2006), dealer-bank cash-tranche spreads, and repo-market indicators, it analyzes market-level units (RMBS tranches, ABX indices, dealer counterparties) in U.S. wholesale repo and shadow-banking settings. The institutional background includes securitization chains with limited secondary markets, tripartite repo intermediation, and shifts in repo haircuts and fails amid falling house prices and surging demand for credit protection.

title: Risk Preferences in the PSID: Individual Imputations and Family Covariation
author: Miles S. Kimball, Claudia R. Sahm, Matthew D. Shapiro
treatment: Imputing risk tolerance (accounting for response error)
context: This empirical study analyzes U.S. household survey data—primarily the 1996 Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID) gamble responses and repeated Health and Retirement Study (HRS) waves (1992–2002)—for working respondents aged 20–69. context: This triplet refers to country-level cross-sectional regressions (Table 2) that relate currency depreciation in 2008 — measured as the percent change in the local currency price of $1 from 12/31/2007 to 12/15/2008 — to explanatory variables observed in 2007. author: Hamish Low, Costas Meghir, Luigi Pistaferri

context: This result comes from estimating the wage process using the 1993 SIPP panel of U.S. male workers (ages 22–61), stratified by education. title: The Demarcation of Land and the Role of Coordinating Institutions
author: Gary D. Libecap, Dean Lueck
context: This paper examines long-run causal effects of two land demarcation regimes—metes-and-bounds (MB) versus the Rectangular Survey (RS)—using historical variation from the late 18th century onward and mid-19th-century data. It studies a 39-county region in Ohio containing the Virginia Military District (MB) adjacent to RS areas created by the 1785 Land Ordinance. Units include parcels, townships, counties and farm-level observations drawn from 1850–1870 censuses, land conveyance records, maps and court cases; the institutional setting provides exogenous assignment of demarcation systems to identify impacts on parcel geometry, transactions, roads, litigation, and land values.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Stepping Off the Wage Escalator: The Effects of Wage Growth on Equilibrium Employment
author: Michael W. L. Elsby, Matthew D. Shapiro

title: The organization of firms across countries
author: Nicholas Bloom, Raffaella Sadun, John Van Reenen
context: This triplet is estimated using plant-level survey data on ~3,660 medium-sized manufacturing firms (100–5,000 employees) interviewed in summer 2006 across 12 countries in Europe, North America and Asia. title: The 2007 Subprime Market Crisis Through the Lens of European Central Bank Auctions for Short-Term Funds
author: Nuno Cassola, Ali Hortacsu, Jakub Kastl
context: This paper analyzes weekly ECB one‑week repo auctions in the euro area during 2007 (January–December), focusing on the abrupt market disruption after August 9, 2007. The unit of observation is individual banks (bidder identities) participating in ECB primary liquidity auctions. Using detailed bid schedules and auction outcomes, the authors recover bank-level willingness‑to‑pay for central‑bank liquidity and relate it to interbank secured/unsecured rates, collateral availability, CDS spreads, reserve requirements and country of origin to study heterogeneous funding stress during the subprime turmoil.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Asset Return Dynamics under Bad Environment Good Environment Fundamentals
author: Geert Bekaert, Eric Engstrom
context: The paper studies U.S. aggregate consumption and asset markets using monthly data (primarily January 1990–March 2009, with longer annual consumption series back to the Great Depression for robustness). Units are aggregate consumption (PCE nondurables and services), the S&P 500 (prices/dividends/returns), option-implied risk-neutral variance (VIX), and 30-day T-bills. title: On the Size Distribution of Macroeconomic Disasters
author: Robert J. Barro, Tao Jin
context: This paper analyzes long-run national-account annual per-capita consumption and GDP for up to 36 countries (data back to as early as 1870 through 2006) to identify macroeconomic “disasters” (peak-to-trough contractions ≥10%) and characterize their size distribution. Using country-level disaster observations (99 consumption and 157 GDP events) the authors fit single and double power-law tails by MLE with bootstrap, then calibrate a representative-agent rare-disasters asset-pricing model to infer the coefficient of relative risk aversion consistent with the historical equity premium.
identification_methods: others

title: Monetary Policy Shifts and the Term Structure
author: Andrew Ang, Jean Boivin, Sen Dong, Rudy Loo-Kung
context: This paper analyzes U.S. quarterly macro and bond market data from June 1952–December 2007, using three-month T-bill rates, zero-coupon Treasury yields, the output gap, and inflation. title: Spring Cleaning: Rural Water Impacts, Valuation and Property Rights Institutions
author: Michael Kremer, Jessica Leino, Edward Miguel, Alix Peterson Zwane
context: The paper studies a randomized phased rollout (2005–2007) of NGO-funded spring protection in rural western Kenya (Busia and Butere-Mumias districts). Units are naturally occurring springs, linked households, and young children; data include baseline and three follow-up surveys and water quality tests. The institutional background features customary/common-property water rights that typically prevent charging for spring water, local cost-sharing for protection, and heterogeneous nearby water sources, which the authors exploit to analyze health impacts, revealed valuations, and alternative property-rights regimes.

title: Teacher Performance Pay: Experimental Evidence from India
author: Karthik Muralidharan, Venkatesh Sundararaman
context: This paper reports a randomized evaluation (2005–07) of teacher performance pay in rural Andhra Pradesh, India. The authors randomized 500 sampled government primary schools (focus on 300 schools: 100 group-incentive, 100 individual-incentive, 100 control) across 50 mandals, following baseline tests in June–July 2005 and endline tests in March–April 2006 and 2007. Units are pupils (grades 1–5), teachers, and schools. The intervention paid teacher bonuses (≈3% of annual pay) based on average student test-score improvements, in a setting with low learning, high teacher absence, and civil-service pay rules.

title: Exports and Financial Shocks
author: Mary Amiti, David E. Weinstein
outcome: Exports of firms with foreign affiliates
context: This paper uses Japanese firm-level data spanning the financial crises roughly 1990–2010 to study how deteriorations in banks’ health affected exporters. The setting is Japan, exploiting matched exporter–bank relationships for listed manufacturing firms and detailed bank balance/market data. Units are firms (export and domestic sales) and their main banks; identification leverages within-industry-year variation and episodes including the 1990s banking turmoil and the 2008 Lehman shock. Key institutional details: trade finance instruments (letters of credit, foreign bills), bank market-to-book as bank health, and stable main-bank relationships.

title: Globalization, Markups and U.S. Welfare
author: Robert C. Feenstra, David E. Weinstein
context: This paper studies how globalization affected firm markups and U.S. welfare between 1992 and 2005, using U.S. import and domestic production data at HS 4-digit and firm-country-product (HS-10) levels. The setting is the U.S. merchandise market; units of observation include exporting countries, individual firms/products, and manufacturing sectors. Under a monopolistic-competition framework with translog preferences, the authors exploit changes in import shares, Herfindahl concentration, and product entry/exit to structurally estimate demand elasticities, markups, and welfare impacts.

title: Identifying Supply and Demand Elasticities of Agricultural Commodities: Implications for the US Ethanol Mandate
author: Michael J. Roberts, Wolfram Schlenker

title: What Goods Do Countries Trade? A Quantitative Exploration of Ricardo's Ideas
author: Arnaud Costinot, Dave Donaldson, Ivana Komunjer
context: Using cross-industry, bilateral trade and productivity data for the year 1997, this paper studies how country–industry productivity differences shape exports and welfare. The empirical sample covers 21 countries (18 European countries plus Japan, Korea, and the United States) and 13 manufacturing sectors (two-digit ISIC). Observations are exporter–importer–industry export flows, with productivity proxied by inverse producer-price indices (GGDC) and import openness from OECD STAN. The analysis rests on a multi-country multi-industry Ricardian model with intra-industry heterogeneity and conducts structural counterfactuals.

title: Competitive Equilibrium in Markets for Votes

context: This paper develops a theory of competitive vote markets and tests it in laboratory experiments conducted at Caltech (June 2009) with undergraduate subjects forming small committees (n=5 and n=9). title: Trade and the Global Recession
author: Jonathan Eaton, Samuel Kortum, Brent Neiman, John Romalis
context: This paper studies the global trade collapse around the Great Recession using quarterly data for 21 countries (including Rest-of-World) from 2000:Q1–2012:Q4, focusing on the recession window 2008:Q3–2009:Q2 and the 2009–2011 recovery. Units are country-sector-quarter observations (durable and nondurable manufacturing, construction, services) and bilateral trade flows, GDP, prices, production, and investment. A calibrated multi-sector multi-country general-equilibrium model (complete markets, perfect foresight) is used to back out country- and sector-specific shocks and run counterfactuals.

title: Trade Induced Technical Change? The Impact of Chinese Imports on Innovation, IT and Productivity
author: Nicholas Bloom, Mirko Draca, John Van Reenen
context: This paper uses firm- and plant-level panels (up to half a million firms; IT establishment sample ≈160,000) across 12 European countries over 1996–2007 to estimate how rising Chinese import competition — especially after China’s 2001 WTO accession and the phased abolition of textile/apparel quotas (MFA reforms in 2002 and 2005) — affected firm innovation (patents, R&D), IT adoption, TFP, employment and survival. title: The Network Structure of International Trade
author: Thomas Chaney
treatment: Average distance between target and firm's contacts
context: This paper develops a theoretical model of international exporter–importer network formation and tests it with French firm-level export data for 1986–1992. Empirical analyses use a panel of roughly 120–130k French exporters (to 210 foreign destinations) combined with country GDP, bilateral trade and distance data to study firms' country-entry dynamics. The setting assumes firms enter a destination only if they have a contact acquired either via random meetings or via contacts' contacts; estimations leverage changes in third-country trade, firm export histories, and cross-sectional patterns.

title: Going to a Better School: Effects and Behavioral Responses
author: Cristian Pop-Eleches, Miguel Urquiola
context: This paper uses administrative and survey data from Romania (admission cohorts 2001–2007, with surveys of 2005–2007 cohorts) to estimate effects of access to higher-achieving high schools/tracks on student outcomes. title: Going to a Better School: Effects and Behavioral Responses
author: Cristian Pop-Eleches, Miguel Urquiola
context: This triplet concerns within-track, class-level variation in Romania using the surveyed cohorts (students entering high school in 2005–2007 in the sampled towns). For tracks whose pre-announced slot offerings were multiples of 28 and were completely filled, students were ranked by their transition score and class cutoffs set at the 28th/56th/84th… student's score. The unit is individual students near these class cutoffs; identification exploits discontinuities in assignment to higher-ranked classes (RD), typically estimated using observations within ±1 transition-score point of the cutoff.
identification_methods: RDD

title: Selection on Moral Hazard in Health Insurance

title: Reshaping Institutions: Evidence on Aid Impacts Using a Pre-Analysis Plan
author: Katherine Casey, Rachel Glennerster, Edward Miguel
context: This paper evaluates the causal impact of the GoBifo community-driven development (CDD) program in Sierra Leone using a village-level randomized rollout. Baseline surveys were collected in 2005, the program ran 2006–2009 (block grants of roughly $4,667 per village with participation requirements for women and youth), and follow-up and structured community activities were fielded in 2009 across 236 villages and about 2,832 households in Bombali and Bonthe districts. Units of analysis are villages and households in a post-conflict decentralization setting where VDCs, bank accounts, and participatory rules were introduced to reshape local institutions.

title: Should Unemployment Insurance Vary With the Unemployment Rate? Theory and Evidence
author: Kory Kroft, Matthew J. Notowidigdo
outcome: Moral hazard cost of unemployment insurance
context: The paper analyzes U.S. unemployment insurance using state-level policy variation and local labor-market conditions. title: Credit Market Consequences of Improved Personal Identification: Field Experimental Evidence from Malawi
author: Xavier Giné, Jessica Goldberg, Dean Yang
context: This randomized field experiment (baseline Sept 2007; treatment and loan season 2007–08; follow-up Aug–Nov 2008) was conducted in rural Malawi (Dedza, Mchinji, Dowa, Kasungu) among smallholder farmers organized in clubs applying for in-kind paprika input loans (3,206 applicants; 1,147 borrowers). Partner institutions were the Malawi Rural Finance Corporation (lender) and Cheetah Paprika (buyer). In this setting with weak formal identification and limited formal credit, fingerprinting of applicants aimed to strengthen identification and the credibility of lenders’ dynamic (future-credit) incentives; the reported effect on loan size is conditional on borrowers who took loans.
identification_methods: RCT

title: The Long-Run Effects of the Scramble for Africa
author: Stelios Michalopoulos, Elias Papaioannou
context: This empirical study evaluates long-run effects of the Scramble for Africa (late 19th-century colonial border drawing) by comparing historical ethnic homelands (Murdock 1959) that were split by modern borders to those that were not. title: Aiding Conflict: The Impact of U.S. Food Aid on Civil War
author: Nathan Nunn, Nancy Qian
context: This paper uses annual country‑year data for 134 non‑OECD countries from 1972–2006 to estimate how U.S. wheat food aid (PL‑480/USDA shipments) affects civil conflict incidence, onset and duration. Identification exploits exogenous year‑to‑year variation in U.S. wheat production (weather‑driven) interacting with each country's historical propensity to receive U.S. food aid, controlling for country fixed effects and region‑year shocks. Outcomes are civil and interstate armed conflict (UCDP/PRIO); analyses include panel regressions, IV 2SLS, and hazard models for conflict duration.

title: Ambiguous Business Cycles
author: Cosmin Ilut, Martin Schneider
context: This paper estimates a medium-scale DSGE model for the United States using quarterly macro data (1984Q1–2010Q1) to quantify how time-varying ambiguity (agents’ changing confidence about productivity) drives business cycles. The unit of analysis is aggregate US macro variables (GDP, consumption, investment, hours, inflation, short-term rate, investment price). Theoretical setting features representative ambiguity-averse households (recursive multiple-priors) who treat neutral productivity innovations as ambiguous; ambiguity shocks enter as time-varying belief-set widths and are estimated in a Bayesian state-space framework.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

context: This paper studies how the 1986–2000 expansion of export-oriented manufacturing in Mexico, driven by trade liberalization (GATT 1986, NAFTA 1994) and Maquiladora growth, affected schooling of youth cohorts. Using 1985–1999 IMSS firm-level employment data matched to a 10% sample of the 2000 Mexican census, the author analyzes non-migrant cohorts (focus on age-16 exposure) across 1,808 commuting zones, exploiting the legal factory-work age (16), compulsory schooling norms (grade 9), and formal-sector IMSS coverage to identify cohort schooling responses to local export job shocks.
identification_methods: DiD; IV; event studies; other panel regressions

title: The Cyclicality of Sales, Regular and Effective Prices: Business Cycle and Policy Implications
author: Olivier Coibion, Yuriy Gorodnichenko, Gee Hee Hong
context: Using weekly UPC‑level scanner prices and quantities from IRI across 50 U.S. metropolitan areas (2001–2007) and a household panel in Eau Claire, WI and Pittsfield, MA, the paper studies how local business conditions (monthly local unemployment rates) affect posted prices, sales (frequency/size), and quantity‑weighted effective prices. Units are store×UPC×week and household×month observations. Identification relies on within‑market/category and time variation in unemployment, exploiting store and household panels to trace expenditure reallocation across retailers during business‑cycle fluctuations.

title: Private Information and Insurance Rejections
author: Nathaniel Hendren
context: This paper studies U.S. non-group long-term care, disability, and life insurance markets using individual-level data from the Health and Retirement Study (1993–2008). title: Behavioral Hazard in Health Insurance
author: Katherine Baicker, Sendhil Mullainathan, Joshua Schwartzstein
context: The paper develops a theoretical model of health insurance with behavioral biases and calibrates its implications using U.S.-based empirical evidence: historical randomized studies (RAND Health Insurance Experiment), recent randomized trial evidence (Choudhry et al. 2011 eliminating copays for post–myocardial infarction medications), and quasi-experimental work on copay changes. Units are individual patients/enrollees (often with chronic conditions) and insurance contracts; the institutional setting is U.S. health insurance markets with copay cost-sharing and insurer tools (prices, nudges, defaults) that affect adherence and utilization.

title: Early and Late Human Capital Investments, Borrowing Constraints, and the Family
author: Elizabeth M. Caucutt, Lance Lochner
treatment: Increase borrowing limits for college students
context: Using U.S. data (Children of the NLSY79, NLSY79 cohort and CPS benchmarks, samples through ~2010 and 2006), the paper studies children and households to assess how parental resources and credit constraints shape early (ages 0–11) versus late (ages 12–23) human capital investments and later earnings. The institutional setting emphasizes U.S. schooling (public K–12, subsidized postsecondary education and student loans), young parents’ labor income profiles, and imperfect credit markets. The authors combine reduced-form regressions with a calibrated dynastic lifecycle model to evaluate policy interventions (subsidies, loans, transfers).

title: Workplace Heterogeneity and the Rise of West German Wage Inequality
author: David Card, Jörg Heining, Patrick Kline
context: Using matched employer–employee administrative data for West Germany (1985–2009), the paper analyzes annual person–establishment observations (full-time men, age 20–60) and roughly 0.8M establishment identifiers to examine how establishment-specific wage premiums, worker heterogeneity, and their sorting explain rising wage inequality. The analysis spans reunification, a decline in sectoral collective bargaining, mid-1990s labor-market reforms and the Hartz reforms, and exploits variation in job-to-job transitions and within-panel worker/establishment fixed effects.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Dollar Funding and the Lending Behavior of Global Banks
author: Victoria Ivashina, David S. Scharfstein, Jeremy C. Stein

title: Chiefs: Elite Control of Civil Society and Economic Development in Sierra Leone
author: Daron Acemoglu, Tristan Reed, James A. Robinson
context: This paper studies long-run effects of colonial chieftaincy institutions in Sierra Leone by exploiting variation in the number of “ruling families” per chiefdom set under British indirect rule around 1896–1920. The analysis uses 149 chiefdoms and individuals (households, children) matched to chiefdoms, drawing on the 2004 and 1963 censuses, 2008 DHS, 2007 NPS and 1898–1902 tax records. The institutional setting centers on lifetime paramount chiefs, tribal authorities, land custodianship and civil‑society capture; the authors argue historical family counts are plausibly exogenous and estimate effects on education, health, employment and social capital.

title: Working Over Time: Dynamic Inconsistency in Real Effort Tasks
author: Ned Augenblick, Muriel Niederle, Charles Sprenger
treatment: Present bias in the allocation of work
context: A seven-week longitudinal laboratory experiment (recruitment Feb 2012) run with UC Berkeley XLab subjects (n≈102; final sample ≈80 individuals) who made incentivized intertemporal allocations of real-effort (Greek transcription, partial Tetris) and monetary payments. The unit of observation is the individual in repeated in‑lab and online weekly sessions.

title: Subways, Strikes, and Slowdowns: The Impacts of Public Transit on Traffic Congestion
author: Michael L. Anderson
context: This study analyzes the short-run impact of a 35-day Los Angeles County MTA strike (Oct 14–Nov 18, 2003) that halted bus and rail service. Using hourly loop-detector data on freeway speeds and minutes-per-mile delay across major Los Angeles freeways during weekday peak hours, the paper studies detector-by-hour outcomes to estimate how ceased transit service affected congestion. It combines a calibrated commuter-choice model (Los Angeles parameters) with a regression-discontinuity design using date as the running variable, detector fixed effects, and falsification/placebo tests against nearby counties and a 2004 placebo period.

title: Bowling for Fascism: Social Capital and the Rise of the Nazi Party
author: Shanker Satyanath, Nico Voigtlaender, Hans-Joachim Voth
context: The paper studies the rise of the Nazi Party in Weimar Germany, focusing on 229 towns and cities on modern‑day German territory during the interwar period (primarily the 1920s up to January 1933). Unit-level outcomes are individual Nazi Party entries and city-level vote shares; the key exposure is association density measured from 1920s city directories. The analysis exploits historical instruments (1860s gymnast/singers data), panel variation, and cross‑state contrasts in political stability (e.g., Prussia vs. other Länder) to assess how civic networks aided recruitment.

title: Family Welfare Cultures
author: Gordon B. Dahl, Andreas Ravndal Kostol, Magne Mogstad
context: This paper studies Norway's Disability Insurance (DI) system using linked administrative registers (1967–2010) and appeals data (1989–2005) for parent–child pairs. It focuses on parents (≤55) who appealed an initial DI denial and their adult children (18+), exploiting randomized assignment of Administrative Law Judges in Oslo to the written appeal process. The institutional setting features centralized, non-specialized judges whose leniency variation exogenously shifts parental DI awards, enabling causal estimates of parental DI receipt on children’s DI application, receipt, labor, and education outcomes.
identification_methods: IV; event studies

title: Overconfidence in Political Behavior
author: Pietro Ortoleva, Erik Snowberg
context: The paper combines a theoretical model with empirical tests using nationally representative U.S. survey data (Harvard/Caltech modules of the 2010 CCES, and a 2011 CCES robustness sample). author: Raj Chetty, John N. Friedman, Jonah E. Rockoff
context: This paper uses administrative data from a large U.S. urban school district (student test scores and teacher assignments spanning ~1989–2009) linked to federal tax records on parents (1996–2011) for over one million children in grades 3–8. title: Buy, Keep or Sell: Economic Growth and the Market for Ideas
author: Ufuk Akcigit, Murat Alp Celik, Jeremy Greenwood
context: This paper studies the U.S. market for patented ideas using patent grant data (USPTO/NBER PDP, 1976–2006), patent reassignment records (USPTO assignment files, 1980–2011), and Compustat firm data (1974–2006). context: This triplet is estimated in a cluster-randomized field experiment in rural Sri Lanka (Bandarawela and Mahiyangana, 2010–2013) where the National Savings Bank offered weekly door-to-door POS deposit collection (5% interest) to unbanked adults; the sample targeted individuals living 5–15 km from branches with one respondent per household. The outcome is total household income (monthly inflows from earnings, remittances, loans, etc.), measured in household-level high-frequency surveys (monthly pre-treatment Aug–Nov 2010, monthly for 13 months post-treatment, with follow-ups through Jan 2013) and analyzed with household/individual fixed-effects panel regressions.
identification_methods: RCT; DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Transition to Clean Technology
author: Daron Acemoglu, Ufuk Akcigit, Douglas Hanley, William Kerr
context: This paper combines a micro-founded endogenous-growth model with firm-level estimation using U.S. energy-sector microdata from 1975–2004. It analyzes 1,576 innovative firms (6,228 firm-period observations) using Census LBD and Economic Census records, NSF R&D survey data, and USPTO patents to study firm R&D, patents, production, employment, entry/exit, and emissions. The structural model contrasts clean versus fossil-fuel (dirty) technologies, is calibrated to carbon-cycle dynamics, and evaluates policy counterfactuals (carbon taxes and clean-research subsidies) for production, innovation direction, and welfare.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; others

context: Analyzes the U.S. family medicine residency market (approximately 430 programs and ~3,000 residents per year) over 2003–2010 (with 2011–12 out-of-sample validation). title: Demand Analysis using Strategic Reports: An application to a school choice mechanism
author: Nikhil Agarwal, Paulo Somaini
context: Analyzes elementary school admissions in Cambridge, MA (Controlled Choice Plan) over 2004–2009, using individual kindergarten applicants (≈400/year, 13 schools) and submitted rank-order lists. The institutional setting is an Immediate Acceptance (Boston) mechanism with proximity and sibling priorities and free/reduced-lunch program quotas. author: Amy Finkelstein, Matthew Gentzkow, Heidi Williams

title: Quantifying Confidence
author: George-Marios Angeletos, Fabrice Collard, Harris Dellas
context: This paper evaluates whether autonomous swings in higher‑order beliefs (“confidence shocks”) can drive U.S. business‑cycle fluctuations. Using quarterly U.S. macro data (1960Q1–2007Q4) on GDP, consumption, investment, hours, inflation, and the federal funds rate, the authors estimate and simulate augmented RBC and New Keynesian DSGE models, apply frequency‑domain Bayesian/MCMC estimation, and remove identified technology shocks (regression on Fernald TFP and SVAR long‑run identification) to analyze business‑cycle (6–32 quarter) dynamics of aggregate macro series.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: The Effects of Youth Employment: Evidence from New York City Summer Youth Employment Program Lotteries
author: Alexander Gelber, Adam Isen, Judd B. Kessler
context: This paper analyzes causal effects of New York City’s Summer Youth Employment Program (SYEP) lotteries from 2005–2008 on applicants (youth aged ~14–21) in NYC. It merges provider-level randomized lottery records to IRS tax data, New York State incarceration records, and NYC death records to estimate impacts on earnings, employment, college enrollment, incarceration, and mortality. title: The Skill Complementarity of Broadband Internet
author: Anders Akerman, Ingvil Gaarder, Magne Mogstad
context: This paper studies Norway during 2001–2007 (firm and worker data span 2000–2008), exploiting a government broadband rollout (Høykom) that progressively installed local access points across 428 municipalities. Using linked administrative employer–employee registers, firm surveys of joint-stock firms, and municipality-level household broadband availability, it examines how increased broadband availability and subsequent firm adoption affected wages, employment, and firm value added for skilled versus unskilled workers. The staged, Telenor-operated rollout with limited public funding provides plausibly exogenous spatial–temporal variation for causal identification.
identification_methods: DiD; IV; event studies; others

title: News Shocks in Open Economies: Evidence from Giant Oil Discoveries
author: Rabah Arezki, Valerie A. Ramey, Liugang Sheng
context: The paper uses a country-year panel (up to 130 countries, 1970–2012; baseline regressions 1980–2012), treating giant oil discovery announcements (NPV as percent of GDP) as plausibly exogenous news shocks with a typical 4–6 year lag and estimating dynamic responses via panel distributed-lag/event-study regressions with country and year fixed effects. For the real exchange rate specifically, the theoretical model omits a non-tradeable sector (so provides no formal prediction), and empirically the authors examine CPI- and GDP-deflator-based RERs, finding small, imprecise, statistically insignificant appreciation in the first five years after discovery.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions

title: Culture, Ethnicity and Diversity
author: Klaus Desmet, Ignacio Ortuño-Ortín, Romain Wacziarg
context: This paper uses individual-level World Values Survey/European Values Survey data (1981–2008, five waves) across 76 countries to measure cultural attitudes and respondents' ethnic/linguistic identity, constructing group-level overlap indices (chi-squared ϕ2 and cultural FST). author: Cemal Eren Arbatlı, Quamrul H. Ashraf, Oded Galor, Marc Klemp
context: This triplet refers to the country-level analysis of contemporary intrastate conflict across nations (baseline ~150 countries) over 1960–2017. title: Production Networks, Geography and Firm Performance
author: Andrew B. Bernard, Andreas Moxnes, Yukiko U. Saito
context: This paper studies how reduced person-to-person travel costs affect firm productivity and supplier links in Japan, exploiting the March 2004 Kyushu Shinkansen opening. title: Salience, Myopia, and Complex Dynamic Incentives: Evidence from Medicare Part D
author: Christina M. Dalton, Gautam Gowrisankaran, Robert Town
context: Using 2008 administrative claims from Express Scripts for U.S. employer-sponsored Medicare Part D plans, the paper studies prescription purchase behavior of beneficiaries (age 65+) at the weekly enrollee level. It exploits the nonlinear 2008 Part D benefit—standard coverage, a coverage gap (doughnut hole) beginning at $2,510, and catastrophic coverage—to analyze enrollees who early in the year have $2,000–$2,510 cumulative spending. title: The Efficiency of Race-Neutral Alternatives to Race-Based Affirmative Action: Evidence from Chicago's Exam Schools
author: Glenn Ellison, Parag A. Pathak
outcome: within-school racial gap in composite scores
context: Using 2013–14 Chicago Public Schools applicant data (≈16,818 applicants), this paper evaluates CPS’s 2010–2012 shift from race-based racial quotas to a race-neutral, place-based tier admissions system for selective exam high schools (notably Walter Payton and Northside). title: Long-Range Growth: Economic Development in the Global Network of Air Links
author: Filipe Campante, David Yanagizawa-Drott
context: Global empirical study of 819 major international airport cities (≈200 countries) using city‑pair, airport, grid‑cell and firm‑level units to measure effects on night‑lights, population, passenger flows, and foreign ownership. title: Parental Resources and College Attendance: Evidence from Lottery Wins
author: George Bulman, Robert Fairlie, Sarena Goodman, Adam Isen
context: Using U.S. administrative data, the paper studies children (units: individuals/household members) whose parents won state lotteries between 2000 and 2013 to estimate how parental financial shocks affect college attendance. It links state W-2G lottery reports to federal tax filings, Form 1098-T college enrollment records, and FAFSA/financial-aid data, comparing wins of varying sizes and timing relative to expected high-school graduation across states and cohorts. Institutional features exploited include third-party W-2G reporting and FAFSA rules that treat near-term windfalls as income but earlier wealth differently.

title: Subsidy Policies and Insurance Demand
author: Jing Cai, Alain de Janvry, Elisabeth Sadoulet
context: This estimate comes from the two-year (2010–2011) randomized field experiment in Jiangxi province on ~3,500 rice-farming households, focusing on the subset of households who paid for insurance in year 1 (non-free villages) or were willing to purchase in free villages. In 2010 about 59% of insured households received payouts; the analysis finds that receiving a payout in year 1 raises second-year take-up (≈+35 percentage points for those who paid). Robustness uses a regression-discontinuity approach instrumenting payout with the 30% loss-rate threshold.
identification_methods: RCT; IV; RDD; other panel regressions; others

title: Inattention and Switching Costs as Sources of Inertia in Medicare Part D
author: Florian Heiss, Daniel McFadden, Joachim Winter, Amelie Wuppermann, Bo Zhou
context: Using a 20% administrative sample of U.S. Medicare Part D claims (2007–2010), the paper analyzes annual plan‑choice decisions of individual beneficiaries (age 65+) enrolled in stand‑alone PDPs without low‑income subsidies. The authors exploit forced choosers (new enrollees or discontinued plans) and year‑to‑year plan changes to estimate a structural two‑stage attention-and-switching‑costs panel discrete‑choice model and simulate interventions.

title: The Mortality and Medical Costs of Air Pollution: Evidence from Changes in Wind Direction
author: Tatyana Deryugina, Garth Heutel, Nolan H. Miller, David Molitor, Julian Reif
context: This paper estimates causal effects of short-term fine particulate matter (PM2.5) on mortality, health care utilization, and medical costs among US elderly (Medicare beneficiaries aged 65–100) using daily county-level pollution and Medicare claims data for 1999–2013. Exploiting plausibly exogenous daily changes in local wind direction as an instrument for county-day PM2.5, and controlling flexibly for weather and high-dimensional fixed effects, the authors analyze three-day mortality windows, ER/hospital admissions, inpatient spending, and heterogeneity in life-years lost using machine-learning survival models.

author: Andrew Goodman-Bacon
context: This triplet examines how early-childhood Medicaid eligibility from the original U.S. Medicaid rollout (state implementation 1966–1970) affected adult disability transfer receipt for birth cohorts roughly 1936–1975. title: Interfirm Relationships and Business Performance
author: Jing Cai, Adam Szeidl
context: A large-scale field experiment in Nanchang, China (2013–2015) studied owner-managed micro, small and medium enterprises established within the prior three years. The program (run with the local CIIT) also randomized group composition, information shocks about financial products, and one-time cross-group meetings.

title: Subsidizing Health Insurance for Low-Income Adults: Evidence from Massachusetts
author: Amy Finkelstein, Nathaniel Hendren, Mark Shepard
context: This paper studies Massachusetts' subsidized insurance exchange "CommCare" from 2009–2013, focusing on fiscal year 2011. It uses individual-level administrative enrollment, claims, and reported income (% of FPL) for non-elderly adults (ages 19–64) eligible between 135–300% of the federal poverty level who lacked employer or Medicaid coverage. CommCare's subsidy schedule produced discrete premium jumps at 150%, 200%, and 250% FPL (and an individual mandate with penalties); these institutional discontinuities identify causal effects of enrollee premiums on take-up, selection, and insurer costs.

title: The Housing Boom and Bust: Model Meets Evidence
author: Greg Kaplan, Kurt Mitman, Giovanni L. Violante
context: This paper studies the U.S. housing boom and bust around the Great Recession (roughly 1997–2015), combining household-level lifecycle heterogeneous-agent data and aggregate time series. title: Are There Too Many Farms in the World? Labor-Market Transaction Costs, Machine Capacities and Optimal Farm Size
author: Andrew D. Foster, Mark R. Rosenzweig

context: The paper uses the India ICRISAT VLS panel (2009–2014, six rounds) covering 819 farm households in 18 villages across Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Karnataka, Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh. title: The Development Effects of the Extractive Colonial Economy: The Dutch Cultivation System in Java
author: Melissa Dell, Benjamin A. Olken
context: This paper examines the long-run local development effects of the Dutch 19th-century Cultivation System in Java (primarily the 1830s–1870s), centered on 94 colonial sugar factories and their contiguous catchment villages that were forced to grow cane. title: Missing Growth from Creative Destruction
author: Philippe Aghion, Antonin Bergeaud, Timo Boppart, Peter J. Klenow, Huiyu Li
context: The paper studies U.S. private nonfarm businesses from 1983–2013, using plant-level microdata (Longitudinal Business Database) and manufacturing subsamples to quantify measurement bias ('missing growth') from statistical imputation when products exit (creative destruction). title: Weak States: Causes and Consequences of the Sicilian Mafia
author: Daron Acemoglu, Giuseppe De Feo, Giacomo De Luca
context: The paper studies late-19th to 20th-century Sicily, focusing on municipalities (n≈333, sample ≈245) around the severe spring drought of 1893. In a weak-state environment, the drought amplified peasant mobilization via the Peasant Fasci in 1893–94, prompting landowners and local elites to enlist the Mafia; Mafia presence is measured in 1900 and outcomes (literacy, public goods, political competition) are followed in the 1910s–30s and into the 1960s–80s. Historical cadastral, rainfall, election, and vital-registration data provide the setting for the causal analysis.

title: Endogenous Production Networks
author: Daron Acemoglu, Pablo D. Azar
context: This paper develops a model of endogenous production networks and validates implications using input-output data (primarily U.S. detailed IO tables, e.g., 2007) and cross-country comparisons (Mexico 2008, Venezuela 1997). The unit of analysis is industries/products (firms/sectors), with contestable markets and Cobb–Douglas technologies; firms choose which other products to use as inputs. The empirical exercises structurally estimate model parameters from U.S. IO matrices and simulate counterfactuals on taxes, contracting frictions, and link restrictions affecting network density and aggregate productivity.

title: Inferring Inequality with Home Production
author: Job Boerma, Loukas Karabarbounis
context: This paper analyzes U.S. households (married/cohabiting heads aged 25–65) using CEX consumption data (1995–2016), ATUS time-use data (2003–2017) and CPS tax information to infer how home production affects welfare inequality. title: Quantitative Analysis of Multi-Party Tariff Negotiations
author: Kyle Bagwell, Robert W. Staiger, Ali Yurukoglu
treatment: GATT rounds up to Uruguay Round
context: The paper uses 1990 country–sector data (49 sectors) for the 25 largest countries by 1990 GDP plus five regional aggregates and compares 1990 applied MFN tariffs to 2000 applied tariffs as outcomes of the Uruguay Round (1986–1994). title: Wealth Taxation and Wealth Accumulation: Theory and Evidence from Denmark
author: Katrine Jakobsen, Kristian Jakobsen, Henrik Kleven, Gabriel Zucman
context: This paper studies causal effects of Danish wealth-tax reforms—chiefly the 1989 cut from 2.2% to 1% and subsequent threshold changes leading up to abolition by 1997—using full-population administrative household wealth records (annual taxable wealth; causal analysis focuses on the 1980s–1990s, 1986–1996 event window). Units are individuals/households (emphasis on top percentiles, e.g., top 1% and 98–99th percentiles). Identification exploits institutional features: a horizontal tax ceiling, exemption thresholds (singles vs couples), third‑party reporting, and gradual reform timing.

title: Trade with Correlation
author: Nelson Lind, Natalia Ramondo
context: This paper develops and estimates a Ricardian multi‑sector trade model using bilateral sectoral trade and expenditure data across countries. Units of observation are country-destination pairs (and sectors), within a CES-preferences framework and Fréchet-distributed productivities that may be spatially correlated (correlation allowed to vary with geographic proximity). The authors structurally estimate correlation parameters and perform counterfactuals—including gains-from-trade relative to autarky—highlighting how technological similarity between countries shapes trade outcomes.

context: This paper uses two survey waves of New Zealand firms (initial: 2017Q4–2018Q1, follow‑up: 2018Q1–2018Q2) with a fresh sample of 1,025 firm managers (≥6 employees) and 515 reinterviews three months later. Respondents across manufacturing, professional/financial services and other sectors received randomized information treatments (average first‑order beliefs, average higher‑order beliefs, both, or past inflation). The study measures causal effects of these RCT treatments on managers’ first‑ and higher‑order inflation expectations and, via IV and panel regressions, on firm decisions (employment, investment, prices, wages).
identification_methods: RCT; IV; other panel regressions
question:
# Role
You are an expert economist.

# Task
Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This paper uses two survey waves of New Zealand firms (initial: 2017Q4–2018Q1, follow‑up: 2018Q1–2018Q2) with a fresh sample of 1,025 firm managers (≥6 employees) and 515 reinterviews three months later. Respondents across manufacturing, professional/financial services and other sectors received randomized information treatments (average first‑order beliefs, average higher‑order beliefs, both, or past inflation). The study measures causal effects of these RCT treatments on managers’ first‑ and higher‑order inflation expectations and, via IV and panel regressions, on firm decisions (employment, investment, prices, wages).

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Increase in inflation expectations
Outcome: Employment

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Who Profits from Patents? Rent-Sharing at Innovative Firms
author: Patrick Kline, Neviana Petkova, Heidi Williams, Owen Zidar
treatment: Initial allowance of an ex-ante valuable patent
context: This paper studies US firms and their workers using linked USPTO patent applications (published 2001–2011, analysis up to 2010 filings) and US Treasury business and W2/1099 tax records (1997–2014). The unit of analysis is patent-applying firms (EINs), typically small newly-innovative firms (median ~17 employees), and their employees. It exploits USPTO initial allowance versus rejection decisions (within art-unit/year) and predicted ex-ante patent value to identify how patent-induced productivity and rents affect firm outcomes, wages, hiring, and retention in the U.S. patent institutional setting.
identification_methods: event studies; DiD; IV; other panel regressions

title: Reshaping Adolescents' Gender Attitudes: Evidence from a School-Based Experiment in India
author: Diva Dhar, Tarun Jain, Seema Jayachandran
outcome: Perceived community support for female employment
context: This randomized evaluation studies cohorts of students who were in grades 6–7 at baseline (2013–14) in government secondary schools in four districts of Haryana, India. title: What is a Good School, and Can Parents Tell? Evidence on the Multidimensionality of School Output
author: Diether Beuermann, C. Kirabo Jackson, Laia Navarro-Sola, Francisco Pardo
context: This paper studies all applicants to public secondary schools in Trinidad and Tobago (SEA cohorts 1995–2012), following individual students through administrative exam, arrest, birth‑registry, and social‑security records to 2017. The unit is the individual student (and their parents' ranked school choices); students are assigned via a deferred‑acceptance algorithm using SEA scores across ~132 public secondary schools. For this triplet, high‑school dropout is measured as not being registered for the NCSE exam around age 14.
