title: From Population Growth to Firm Demographics: Implications for Concentration, Entrepreneurship and the Labor Share
author: Hugo Hopenhayn, Julian Neira, Rish Singhania
treatment: Pre-1978 rise in labor force growth
outcome: Magnitude of subsequent entry rate decline
context: The paper studies U.S. private-sector firms over the long run (feeding civilian labor-force growth from the 1940s through 2014 and firm-level data 1977–2014) to link changes in population/labor-force growth—largely driven by the baby boom—to firm entry, firm-age composition, employment concentration, and the aggregate labor share. Units are firms and firm-age cohorts (Business Dynamics Statistics, BLS, Census data). It combines age-by-size empirical aggregates and panel regressions with a calibrated dynamic general-equilibrium firm-dynamics model (Hopenhayn-style) with overhead labor to quantify causal transitional effects.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; others

title: Inflation Expectations and Firm Decisions: New Causal Evidence
author: Olivier Coibion, Yuriy Gorodnichenko, Tiziano Ropele
context: Using the Bank of Italy quarterly Survey on Inflation and Growth Expectations (SIGE) and linked administrative data (CCR, INPS, CADS), the paper studies a panel of Italian non-financial firms (50+ employees) from 2012 onward (treatment introduced in 2012Q3; ELB-focused subperiod 2014Q4–2018Q2). context: Using de-identified JPMorgan Chase monthly bank-account data from January 2014–June 2016 across 20 U.S. states, the paper studies roughly 182,000 households who received unemployment insurance (UI) by direct deposit. title: The Origins of Firm Heterogeneity: A Production Network Approach
author: Andrew B. Bernard, Emmanuel Dhyne, Glenn Magerman, Kalina Manova, Andreas Moxnes
context: This paper analyzes the origins of firm size heterogeneity using the universe of domestic firm-to-firm transactions in Belgium, focusing on the 2014 cross-section with robustness checks over 2002–2014. The unit of observation is firms and directed seller–buyer transactions, linked to firm balance sheets, VAT records and industry (NACE) codes; the B2B dataset records essentially all domestic inter-firm sales above €250. The analysis conditions on the observed equilibrium production network and combines high-dimensional two-way fixed-effects estimation with a structural mapping and general-equilibrium counterfactuals.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Employment Structure and the Rise of the Modern Tax System
author: Anders Jensen
context: The paper combines recent cross-country household surveys (100 countries) and long-run U.S. microdata (1870–2010) with a causal analysis of U.S. states in the 1950s–1960s. The main causal test exploits variation in the timing of state Industrial Development Bonds (IDB) implementation—specifically the lag between legislative vote-in and state supreme-court upholding—to estimate effects on individual employment structure, the personal income tax exemption threshold, and state income tax revenue. Units are individuals/households for distributional profiles and U.S. states for the policy-event analysis; key institutions include revenue bonds and IRS information-exchange agreements.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions

title: The Welfare Effects of Social Media
author: Hunt Allcott, Luca Braghieri, Sarah Eichmeyer, Matthew Gentzkow
context: This paper reports a randomized evaluation (and associated IV analysis) of deactivating Facebook among US users in the four weeks surrounding the November 2018 US midterm elections. The unit is individual Facebook users recruited via Facebook ads, who were paid (BDM) to deactivate for four weeks (Oct–Nov 2018); researchers verified deactivation via public profile checks and measured outcomes via surveys, daily texts, administrative voting records, and platform activity, focusing on time use, news knowledge, polarization, subjective well‑being, and post‑treatment demand.

title: Strict ID Laws Don’t Stop Voters: Evidence from a U.S. Nationwide Panel, 2008–2018
author: Enrico Cantoni, Vincent Pons
context: This paper estimates the impact of state-level strict voter identification laws on individuals' perceived election integrity using survey data (SPAE waves 2008–2016 and ANES waves 2004, 2012, 2016). title: Estimating the Effect of Treatments Allocated by Randomized Waiting Lists.
author: Clément de Chaisemartin, Luc Behaghel
context: This paper studies causal inference for oversubscribed treatments allocated by randomized waiting lists: applicants are randomly ranked within waitlists and offers are sequentially made until available seats are filled, in settings with capacity constraints and “non-takers.” The unit of observation is individual applicants across many waitlists (e.g., schools or training sites). The authors derive estimator properties, propose a doubly-reweighted ever-offer estimator, and illustrate empirically using Blattman & Annan’s randomized agricultural-training program for Liberian ex-combatants (70 waitlists).

The authors derive estimator properties, propose a doubly-reweighted ever-offer estimator, and illustrate empirically using Blattman & Annan’s randomized agricultural-training program for Liberian ex-combatants (70 waitlists).

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Agricultural training
Outcome: Income index

title: Labor in the Boardroom
author: Simon Jäger, Benjamin Schoefer, Jörg Heining
context: This paper exploits the August 10, 1994 German reform that abolished the one‑third worker‑representative mandate on supervisory boards for stock corporations incorporated on/after that date (grandfathering older cohorts). title: General Equilibrium Effects of Cash Transfers: Experimental Evidence from Kenya
author: Dennis Egger, Johannes Haushofer, Edward Miguel, Paul Niehaus, Michael W. Walker
context: This paper analyzes the local general-equilibrium effects of large one-time cash transfers delivered by GiveDirectly to over 10,500 poor households across 653 villages (84 sublocations) in rural Siaya County, western Kenya. Transfers (≈USD 1,000 per eligible household, mid-2014 to early‑2017) amounted to roughly 15–24% of local GDP during rollout. The study uses household and enterprise censuses (≈65,000 households, 12,095 firms), representative household and enterprise surveys, and monthly market price data to trace impacts on consumption, assets, firm revenue, wages, and prices across households, firms, villages, and markets.

title: Factor Market Failures and the Adoption of Irrigation in Rwanda
author: Maria Jones, Florence Kondylis, John Loeser, Jeremy Magruder
context: This paper evaluates government-built hillside irrigation schemes in Karongi and Nyanza districts of Rwanda (construction 2009–2014) using plot- and household-level panel surveys (baseline 2015 with follow-ups through 2018). The unit of analysis is cultivator households and their plots near a gravity-fed canal ‘command area’ on terraced hillsides. title: Using Disasters to Estimate the Impact of Uncertainty
author: Scott R. Baker, Nicholas Bloom, Stephen J. Terry
context: This paper analyzes quarterly country-level data for 59 countries from 1970Q1 to 2020Q1, using country-quarter observations of GDP growth, national stock-market returns and volatility. The authors exploit exogenous shocks — natural disasters, terrorist attacks, coups and revolutions — weighted by short-run jumps in U.S. newspaper coverage to instrument first- and second-moment (level and uncertainty) shocks in asset returns. The setting spans advanced and emerging economies, linking financial-market moments to short-run macro outcomes while accounting for spatial spillovers, alternative uncertainty proxies, and model-based simulations.
identification_methods: event studies

title: Building Resilient Health Systems: Experimental Evidence from Sierra Leone and the 2014 Ebola Outbreak
author: Darin Christensen, Oeindrila Dube, Johannes Haushofer, Bilal Siddiqi, Maarten J. Voors
context: This paper reports a cluster randomized field experiment implemented in 2011–2013 across 254 government-run peripheral health clinics in four Sierra Leone districts (Bombali, Tonkolili, Bo, Kenema), with surveys of ~5,080 households, clinics, and communities. Two accountability interventions (community monitoring and non‑financial awards) were randomized at the clinic level. The authors later link clinic treatment status to 2014–15 Ebola case (VHF) data aggregated to section-weeks to estimate longer-run effects on reporting and Ebola mortality.
identification_methods: RCT; IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

context: This paper combines theoretical modeling with empirical analysis of U.S. grocery retail data from 2006–2014 to estimate how county- and state-level sales-tax changes affect prices, quantities, and consumer tax salience. title: How the Other Half Died: Immigration and Mortality in US Cities
author: Philipp Ager, James J. Feigenbaum, Casper Worm Hansen, Hui Ren Tan
context: Empirical study of U.S. cities from 1900–1937 (348 cities) estimating how the 1921 and 1924 national immigration quota acts changed city-level mortality. context: This triplet refers to a theoretical experiment in the paper’s heterogeneous-agent small open-economy model. The unit of analysis is the household (with idiosyncratic income µit) facing a riskless bond and a borrowing limit; the experiment imposes an unexpected, permanent contraction in aggregate income (Yt+h = Yt < Yss) while borrowing limits are unchanged (f(Yt)=1) and κ is assumed sufficiently large. The outcome is households’ optimal consumption responses to that permanent aggregate shock.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

# Context
This triplet refers to a theoretical experiment in the paper’s heterogeneous-agent small open-economy model. The unit of analysis is the household (with idiosyncratic income µit) facing a riskless bond and a borrowing limit; the experiment imposes an unexpected, permanent contraction in aggregate income (Yt+h = Yt < Yss) while borrowing limits are unchanged (f(Yt)=1) and κ is assumed sufficiently large. The outcome is households’ optimal consumption responses to that permanent aggregate shock.

title: Answering the Call of Automation: How the Labor Market Adjusted to Mechanizing Telephone Operation
author: James Feigenbaum, Daniel P. Gross
context: This triplet examines city-level cutovers to mechanical (rotary-dial) switching in the United States during 1910–1940 and their effect on the number of telephone operators among 16–25-year-old women. Using city cutover dates merged with complete-count decennial censuses in a city-by-age panel, the paper documents an immediate and persistent 50–80% decline in young women employed as telephone operators after local mechanization.
identification_methods: event studies; DiD; other panel regressions; PSM; IV

title: Social Positions and Fairness Views on Inequality
author: Kristoffer B. Hvidberg, Claus Kreiner, Stefanie Stantcheva
context: This paper links a large Feb–Mar 2019 survey of Danish-born individuals (born 1969–1973, aged 45–50) to administrative tax, employment, schooling, and parental records across Denmark. Using detailed income histories and mapped reference groups (cohort, municipality, education, sector, workplace, neighbors, schoolmates), the authors analyze perceptions and fairness views of within-group inequality, exploit life‑events (unemployment, promotions, health shocks) in registers to study changes over time, and implement a preregistered randomized information treatment revealing true social positions.
identification_methods: RCT; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Granular Instrumental Variables
author: Xavier Gabaix, Ralph S. J. Koijen
context: The paper develops a method (Granular Instrumental Variables) that uses idiosyncratic shocks of large actors (firms, industries, or countries) as instruments for aggregate endogenous variables, and applies it to sovereign bond markets in the Eurozone. The empirical application uses daily 10‑year sovereign yield spreads for 11 countries from 2009–2018, with countries as units and size weights (debt-at-risk), controlling for common factors via factor models to estimate spillovers and multipliers of idiosyncratic yield shocks.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: Prep School for Poor Kids: The Long-Run Impacts of Head Start on Human Capital and Economic Self-Sufficiency
author: Martha J. Bailey, Shuqiao Sun, Brenden D. Timpe
context: This study estimates long-run effects of Head Start’s county-level rollout in the United States (1965–1980) on cohorts born 1950–1980, using linked 2000 Census and 2001–2018 ACS data merged to the SSA Numident. The unit is individuals (adults observed at ages 25–54), and identification exploits county Head Start launch dates combined with school-entry age eligibility (ages 3–5 vs age 6+), controlling for county fixed effects and state-by-birth-year trends. title: Globalization, Trade Imbalances and Labor Market Adjustment
author: Rafael Dix-Carneiro, João Paulo Pessoa, Ricardo M. Reyes-Heroles, Sharon Traiberman
context: A quantitative study of globalization’s labor-market effects using a structural multi-country, multi-sector general equilibrium model estimated to 2000 cross‑sectional and time‑series moments. Focus on the global economy (US, China, Europe, Asia/Oceania, Americas, Rest of World) across six sectors; units are countries, sectoral employment, households, and workers. Authors analyze China’s productivity, trade-cost, and saving shocks—especially 2000–2014—using WIOD, CPS and micro datasets to quantify effects on US manufacturing employment, unemployment, trade imbalances, and consumption under endogenous international borrowing and sectoral search frictions.
identification_methods: others

title: The Supply-Side Effects of Monetary Policy
author: David Baqaee, Emmanuel Farhi, Kunal Sangani
context: The paper examines how monetary policy shocks change aggregate TFP and resource allocation by reallocating inputs across heterogeneous firms. Empirical analyses use identified monetary shocks (Romer and Romer; high-frequency shocks) in U.S. time-series and panel contexts, and firm-level data (Compustat for U.S. public firms; Belgian firm-level pass-through estimates) across industries and years. Units are the aggregate economy and firms. The setting emphasizes nominal rigidities (Calvo/menu costs), heterogeneous markups and pass-throughs, and monetary and discount-factor shocks as exogenous demand disturbances.
identification_methods: event studies; other time-series regressions; other panel regressions

title: Changes in Social Network Structure in Response to Exposure to Formal Credit Markets
author: Abhijit Banerjee, Emily Breza, Arun G. Chandrasekhar, Esther Duflo, Matthew O. Jackson, Cynthia Kinnan
context: This paper studies how microfinance entry changed household social, informational, and financial networks in India. It uses a 2006 baseline and follow-up field panel of 75 villages in Karnataka (BSS entry between 2007–2010, Wave 2 in 2012) and an RCT roll-out across 104 Hyderabad neighborhoods (Spandana) with surveys through 2012. Units are households and their network links; identification exploits staggered MFI exposure due to halted expansion and randomized neighborhood entry, with rich network and borrowing data and ARD-based network measures in Hyderabad.
identification_methods: DiD; RCT

title: Exchange Rates and Prices: Evidence from the 2015 Swiss Franc Appreciation
author: Raphael Auer, Ariel Burstein, Sarah M. Lein
context: This paper studies how the abrupt January 15, 2015 removal of the EUR/CHF floor and ensuing >20% Swiss franc appreciation affected border import prices, retail prices, and household expenditures in Switzerland. Using quarterly SFSO import-price microdata and Nielsen homescan scanner data on retail prices and purchases for households and products across 2013–2016, the authors exploit cross-product variation in currency-of-invoicing and import shares to identify price pass-through, pricing complementarities, and expenditure switching in a stable Swiss economy after a policy-driven external shock.
identification_methods: event studies; IV; other panel regressions

title: Partisanship and Fiscal Policy in Economic Unions: Evidence from U.S. States
author: Gerald Carlino, Thorsten Drautzburg, Robert P. Inman, Nicholas Zarra
treatment: Increase in share of Republican governors
context: This paper studies U.S. states (state-year observations) from roughly 1983–2014 (with some analyses 1968–2014) to estimate how gubernatorial partisanship affects the marginal propensity to spend federal intergovernmental (IG) transfers. Using state fiscal and political data, the authors focus on non‑welfare IG grants, exploit close gubernatorial elections and state/year fixed‑effects to identify partisan differences, and place results in a New Keynesian two‑region model to quantify aggregate multipliers amid rising post‑Reagan political polarization.
identification_methods: RDD; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: The Economic Geography of Global Warming
author: José-Luis Cruz, Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
context: The paper builds a global spatial dynamic assessment model quantified at 1°×1° grid cells using G-Econ, HDI, and other datasets to estimate how temperature changes (historical decades 1990–2005 for damage estimation, natality calibrated back to 1950–1999) affect local fundamental productivity, amenities, and natality. Units are grid-cell locations (population, wages, energy use) worldwide. The model combines empirical panel estimation of temperature damage functions with structural inversion, carbon-cycle calibration and climate downscaling to simulate migration, trade, innovation and policy counterfactuals from 2000 forward (projections to 2400).
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: The Mortgage Piggy Bank: Building Wealth through Amortization
author: Asaf Bernstein, Peter Koudijs
context: Using linked Dutch administrative data (2006–2017), the paper studies households (first-time homebuyers) affected by a January 1, 2013 mortgage reform that required fully amortizing 30-year mortgages for tax deductibility and insurance. title: Dynamic Bank Expansion: Spatial Growth, Financial Access, and Inequality
author: Yan Ji, Songyuan Teng, Robert Townsend
context: The paper evaluates causal effects of commercial bank branch expansion in Thailand during 1986–1996, exploiting the late-1980s relaxation of branching and bond-holding requirements that triggered a surge in new branches. It uses GIS-defined local spatial markets (≈1,000+ markets), village and household census data, and Bank of Thailand branch records to study how branch openings affected local employment, income, entrepreneurship, and credit/deposit access. Units of analysis include local markets and heterogeneous households; branch placement is endogenous but timing and location variation are used for identification.
identification_methods: others

title: The Voice of Monetary Policy
author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko, Tho Pham, Oleksandr Talavera
context: This paper analyzes U.S. Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meetings and press conferences from 2011 through June 2019 (67 meetings, 36 press conferences), using 692 Chair Q&A answers by Ben Bernanke, Janet Yellen, and Jerome Powell. It quantifies vocal emotions via a custom deep‑learning speech classifier and textual sentiment, and links variation in voice tone to daily financial market responses (equity, volatility, bond and corporate ETFs, inflation expectations, and exchange rates), controlling for identified intraday policy shocks and the shadow federal funds rate.
identification_methods: event studies; other time-series regressions

title: Patent Publication and Innovation
author: Deepak Hegde, Kyle F. Herkenhoff, Chenqi Zhu
context: The paper studies the effect of the American Inventors Protection Act (AIPA) of 1999—which required U.S. patent applications filed on or after Nov 29, 2000 to be published 18 months after filing—on innovation and knowledge diffusion. Using patent applications filed 1998–2003 across the U.S., the European Patent Office (and Japanese Patent Office) and firm-level R&D, the authors compare U.S. patents to “twin” foreign equivalents and exploit variation in pre-AIPA grant delays, opt-out rates, and firm technology exposure to estimate impacts on citations, citation speed, similarity, abandonments, claims, and R&D.

title: Does Welfare Prevent Crime? The Criminal Justice Outcomes of Youth Removed From SSI
author: Manasi Deshpande, Michael G. Mueller-Smith
context: This paper estimates effects of losing Supplemental Security Income (SSI) at age 18 due to the 1996 federal welfare reform (PRWORA) medical‑review rule that applied adult eligibility criteria to children with 18th birthdays after August 22, 1996. Using U.S. Social Security administrative records (SSI receipt, earnings, family measures) linked to Criminal Justice Administrative Records System (CJARS) court and corrections data, the authors follow SSI‑recipient children (1976–98 birth cohorts) in jurisdictions with CJARS coverage from ages 18–38 (1997–2017) to study criminal charges, incarceration, employment, and Medicaid channels.

title: Indirect Effects of Access to Finance
author: Jing Cai, Adam Szeidl
context: This paper reports a field experiment in Jiangxi province, China, around a new no-collateral SME loan introduced in 2013. The authors randomized monthly loan-officer outreach to 3,173 small and medium retail and service firms clustered in 78 local geographic “markets” (treatment intensity: 0%, 50%, 80%), collected baseline data in summer 2013 and followed firms in 2015, 2016 and a 2020 follow-up. The institutional setting features concentrated local retail markets, pervasive credit constraints, and bank-mediated loan approval with standardized terms.

title: Estimation of a Life-Cycle Model with Human Capital, Labor Supply and Retirement
author: Xiaodong Fan, Ananth Seshadri, Christopher R. Taber
context: This paper uses U.S. microdata (SIPP panels 1984–2008 and CPS panels 1979–2018) to estimate a structural life-cycle model of consumption, human-capital investment, labor supply and Social Security claiming. Focusing on male high-school graduates (individual-level units, estimation from ages ~22 up to 80), it models U.S. Social Security rules (claiming from age 62, normal retirement 65, using 2004 rules) and simulates counterfactual benefit and tax changes. Estimation employs indirect inference to match life-cycle employment and measured-wage profiles; extensions include health shocks and part-time work.
identification_methods: others

title: Increasing the Demand for Workers with a Criminal Record
author: Zoe B. Cullen, Will S. Dobbie, Mitchell Hoffman
outcome: Willingness to hire workers with criminal record
context: This paper uses a randomized field experiment conducted March–April 2020 on a large U.S. nationwide staffing platform to measure employer demand for workers with criminal records. title: Dividend Taxes, Firm Growth, and the Allocation of Capital
author: Adrien Matray
context: This paper studies the 2013 French dividend payroll-tax reform that tripled the tax rate on dividends to owner-managers of SARL firms (from 15.5% to 46%). It uses administrative tax and accounting panel data covering the universe of private firms over 2008–2017. The unit of analysis is closely-held firms/owner-managers (SARL treated, SAS controls), exploiting legal-status variation and staggered fiscal-year treatment timing to estimate effects on payouts, retained earnings, capital and labor accumulation, revenues, and exit.

title: Wealth of Two Nations: The U.S. Racial Wealth Gap, 1860-2020
author: Ellora Derenoncourt, Chi Hyun Kim, Moritz Kuhn, Moritz Schularick
context: This paper constructs a continuous national series of white-to-Black per-capita wealth ratios in the United States from 1860 to 2020, using historical complete-count censuses, southern state tax records, Monroe Work’s Negro Year Book, and the Survey of Consumer Finances. The unit of analysis is racial groups’ per-capita (and household-level) wealth nationally. The analysis situates wealth dynamics in institutional contexts—slavery, Emancipation, Reconstruction, Jim Crow, New Deal, the Civil Rights era, and post-1980 asset-price booms—and examines how initial conditions, income growth, savings behavior, and capital gains shaped long-run convergence and divergence.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Wealth of Two Nations: The U.S. Racial Wealth Gap, 1860-2020
author: Ellora Derenoncourt, Chi Hyun Kim, Moritz Kuhn, Moritz Schularick
context: This paper constructs a continuous national series of white-to-Black per-capita wealth ratios in the United States from 1860 to 2020, using historical complete-count censuses, southern state tax records, Monroe Work’s Negro Year Book, and the Survey of Consumer Finances. The unit of analysis is racial groups’ per-capita (and household-level) wealth nationally. The analysis situates wealth dynamics in institutional contexts—slavery, Emancipation, Reconstruction, Jim Crow, New Deal, the Civil Rights era, and post-1980 asset-price booms—and examines how initial conditions, income growth, savings behavior, and capital gains shaped long-run convergence and divergence.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Pricing Power in Advertising Markets: Theory and Evidence
author: Matthew Gentzkow, Jesse M. Shapiro, Frank Yang, Ali Yurukoglu
context: The paper studies US advertising markets, primarily focusing on the linear television market in 2014–2019 with cross-sectional analyses centered on 2015. Units include television outlets (network×daypart), network owners, advertisers, and individual viewers from the 2015 GfK MRI survey; data sources include Nielsen Ad Intel and S&P/SNL ownership records. title: The Effect of Macroeconomic Uncertainty on Firm Decisions
author: Saten Kumar, Yuriy Gorodnichenko, Olivier Coibion
context: Using two survey waves in New Zealand (first wave June–Oct 2021, follow-up Nov 2021–Feb 2022), the authors survey ~4,000 firms (about 2,000 reinterviewed) employing ≥6 workers. title: Superiority-Seeking and the Preference for Exclusion
author: Alex Imas, Kristóf Madarász
context: This paper combines theoretical modeling with randomized laboratory and online experiments to test whether individuals value goods more when others are barred from obtaining them. title: New Frontiers: The Origins and Content of New Work, 1940–2018
author: David Autor, Caroline Chin, Anna M. Salomons, Bryan Seegmiller
context: Analyzes the United States, 1940–2018, linking decadal Census/ACS microdata on occupations and industry write-ins to a constructed database of new job micro‑titles and to the full text of U.S. utility patents. Units of observation are occupations and occupation×industry cells (decadal panels); key institutional features are the Census Alphabetical Index (CAI) and the Dictionary of Occupational Titles (DOT) used to map patents (via word‑embeddings) into augmentation vs. automation exposure. The paper leverages exogenous demand shocks (China import exposure, demographic shifts) and patent‑based instruments (breakthrough patents lagged two decades) to identify causal effects.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions

title: The Gift of a Lifetime: The Hospital, Modern Medicine, and Mortality
author: Alex Hollingsworth, Krzysztof Karbownik, Melissa A. Thomasson, Anthony Wray
context: This paper studies the causal impact of The Duke Endowment’s hospital modernization program (1927–1942) on hospital capacity, physician quality, infant mortality (birth cohorts 1922–1942) and long-run mortality (1932–1941 cohorts observed at ages 56–64) in North Carolina counties. title: The Economics of the Public Option: Evidence from Local Pharmaceutical Markets
author: Juan Pablo Atal, José Ignacio Cuesta, Felipe González, Cristóbal Otero
context: This paper studies the decentralized rollout of municipal public pharmacies in Chile from October 2015 to April 2018 (146 of 344 counties adopted). It analyzes county- and local-market outcomes using drug-level IQVIA data (2014–2018), municipal finance records (2013–2019), avoidable hospitalizations, and an individual-level informational field experiment conducted just before the October 2016 local election. The institutional setting is a highly concentrated private retail and wholesale pharmaceutical sector; public pharmacies are single municipal stores that procure via a public intermediary and target local residents, especially chronic-patient buyers.

context: This paper reports a randomized trial of READI Chicago (N=2,456 men) conducted with rolling referrals from August 2017–March 2020 and 20-month follow-ups through late 2021. It evaluates an 18-month bundled intervention (subsidized supported work, CBT, and outreach referrals) in five high-violence Chicago neighborhoods (e.g., Austin/West Garfield Park, North Lawndale, Englewood). Units are individual men identified by algorithmic, outreach, or re-entry pathways; outcomes come from Chicago police and administrative records.

title: Machine Learning as a Tool for Hypothesis Generation
author: Jens Ludwig, Sendhil Mullainathan
context: The paper studies judges’ pre-trial detention decisions in Mecklenburg County, North Carolina (Charlotte area), using arrest records and mugshots from January 18, 2017 to January 17, 2020. The unit is individual arrests/defendants whose 24–48 hour detention versus release decisions are recorded by judges; administrative data (charges, priors) are linked to mugshot images, supplemented with human labeling and a lab experiment that randomizes morphed facial images to probe causal effects of appearance.
identification_methods: RCT; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Children's Indirect Exposure to the U.S. Justice System: Evidence from Longitudinal Links between Survey and Administrative Data
author: Keith Finlay, Michael G. Mueller-Smith, Brittany Street
context: Using linked U.S. administrative and survey data (CJARS, IRS, Census/ACS, HUD, Medicaid, SSA), the study measures children’s indirect exposure to adult criminal-justice events across CJARS-covered U.S. states and counties for birth cohorts 1999–2005 (with an outcomes/movers analysis using 1993–1996 cohorts observed into their mid-20s). Units are children/households and counties. The setting is the decentralized U.S. criminal-justice system with large between-location variation in charges, convictions, and incarceration; exposure stems from biological parents and co-resident adults.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: How the 1963 Equal Pay Act and 1964 Civil Rights Act Shaped the Gender Gap in Pay
author: Martha J. Bailey, Thomas E. Helgerman, Bryan A. Stuart
treatment: Equal Pay Act and Title VII
context: Analyzes U.S. labor markets from the 1950s through the 1970s with emphasis on the 1960s, leveraging the passage and implementation of the 1963 Equal Pay Act and 1964 Civil Rights Act. Uses individual-level census and CPS ASEC data (ages 25–64) and aggregated industry-occupation-state-group cells across 21 state groups to compare states with and without pre-existing equal-pay laws and jobs with larger 1960 gender wage gaps. Institutional context includes FLSA coverage, WHD versus EEOC enforcement, and staggered state law variation.
identification_methods: event studies; DiD; IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: How the 1963 Equal Pay Act and 1964 Civil Rights Act Shaped the Gender Gap in Pay
author: Martha J. Bailey, Thomas E. Helgerman, Bryan A. Stuart
treatment: Equal Pay Act and Title VII
context: Estimates the impact of the 1963 Equal Pay Act (effective June 1964) and Title VII (1964) on the within-job gender pay gap in the U.S. between 1964 and 1968. Uses individual-level 1950–1960 Decennial Census and 1962–1975 CPS ASEC data and the 1963 Occupational Wage Survey, aggregating to industry-occupation-state-group cells (21 state groups) to compare job-level pay differences and state legal environments (pre-existing state equal-pay laws, FLSA coverage and WHD/EEOC enforcement). Units are workers ages 25–64 and narrowly defined job cells.
identification_methods: event studies; DiD; IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: The (Lack of) Anticipatory Effects of the Social Safety Net on Human Capital Investment
author: Manasi Deshpande, Rebecca Dizon-Ross
context: This paper reports a nationally drawn randomized controlled trial (Oct 2021–Jan 2022, U.S., with oversamples in Michigan, Wisconsin, and Massachusetts) of about 6,000 parents of 14–17-year-old children receiving Supplemental Security Income (SSI). Using SSA administrative data to predict each child’s probability of removal at the age-18 redetermination, the experiment randomized a video giving that prediction and measured parents’ belief updates and take-up of offered human-capital resources (tutoring, job training, math lessons). The institutional setting is the U.S. SSI program, where child and adult eligibility differ and many youth lose benefits at 18.
identification_methods: RCT

title: The Impact of Public School Choice: Evidence from Los Angeles' Zones of Choice
author: Christopher Campos, Caitlin Kearns
context: This paper studies Los Angeles Unified School District’s Zones of Choice (ZOC) reform—implemented starting around 2012–2013—using administrative data from roughly 2008–2019. It evaluates effects on high-school students (chiefly 11th graders and graduating cohorts) and market-level school outcomes across ZOC versus non-ZOC neighborhoods in Los Angeles. ZOC combined catchment areas, expanded within-district choice with centralized rank-ordered (immediate-acceptance) assignment and lotteries for oversubscription, thereby changing competitive incentives among attendance-zone schools.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; PSM; other panel regressions

It evaluates effects on high-school students (chiefly 11th graders and graduating cohorts) and market-level school outcomes across ZOC versus non-ZOC neighborhoods in Los Angeles. ZOC combined catchment areas, expanded within-district choice with centralized rank-ordered (immediate-acceptance) assignment and lotteries for oversubscription, thereby changing competitive incentives among attendance-zone schools.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; PSM; other panel regressions

title: Retirement Consumption and Pension Design
author: Jonas Kolsrud, Camille Landais, Daniel Reck, Johannes Spinnewijn
context: Using linked Swedish administrative registries and registry-based household consumption measures for cohorts born 1938–1943 (consumption observed circa 2000–2007), the paper studies individuals/households retiring between roughly ages 55–70. The institutional setting is Sweden’s public pension system (ATP→NDC transition), occupational pensions and social insurance (UI/DI), where benefits depend on retirement age, career length and earnings. The analysis exploits variation in actual retirement timing and rich panel covariates to relate consumption levels and dynamics around retirement to pension design.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Organized Crime and Economic Growth: Evidence from Municipalities Infiltrated by the Mafia
author: Alessandra Fenizia, Raffaele Saggio
context: This empirical study evaluates long-run effects of city-council dismissals (CCDs) for alleged Mafia infiltration in Italy, analyzing 245 CCD events from 1991–2016 across municipalities in ten regions. It uses administrative employer–employee social security data (1983–2017), real-estate, public-procurement, politician, and municipal finance records to measure impacts on firms, employment, wages, and real-estate. Institutional context: the central government investigates alleged Mafia ties and appoints commissioners to run dismissed municipalities for about two years before new elections, creating plausibly exogenous variation for causal analysis.
identification_methods: PSM; event studies; DiD

title: The Long-Run Effects of America's Largest Residential Racial Desegregation Program: Gautreaux
author: Eric Chyn, Robert Collinson, Danielle H. Sandler
outcome: Likelihood of marrying a white spouse
context: This paper analyzes long-run causal effects of the Gautreaux Assisted Housing Program (program operated 1976–1998; main sample 1982–1994) in the Chicago metropolitan area, linking historical placement records to administrative data through 2019/2020. Units are Black public-housing/voucher recipient households and their children. The program—created by a class-action settlement and a 1981 consent decree—placed families into “General” (<30% Black) or “Revitalizing” tracts based largely on registration order and unit availability. Authors use linked LEHD, MAF-ARF, Decennial Census and Numident data to estimate placement effects.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: The Staying Power of Leveraged Buyouts
author: Steven N. Kaplan
outcome: Probability of returning to public ownership
context: This study examines 183 large leveraged buyouts (LBOs) completed in the United States between 1979 and 1986, tracking their organizational status through August 1990. The unit of analysis is the buyout firm (and its assets), including both public-company and divisional buyouts valued over $100 million. The institutional setting is 1980s U.S. corporate finance, characterized by very high post-buyout leverage, concentrated manager/sponsor equity, and active LBO sponsors; the paper assesses timing and correlates of returns to public ownership and post-buyout capital structure.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

context: This triplet concerns the 183 U.S. leveraged buyouts completed in 1979–1986 (firm-level units, assets tracked through August 1990). title: What Moves the Stock and Bond Markets? A Variance Decomposition for Long-Term Asset Returns
author: John Y. Campbell, John Ammer
context: Using monthly U.S. data from the postwar period (1952:1–1987:2), this paper analyzes aggregate asset returns—value‑weighted NYSE/AMEX stock index returns and 10‑year Treasury zero‑coupon bond yields—at the market level. The institutional setting is the U.S. macrofinancial environment (inflation, short‑ and long‑term nominal interest rates, and changes in Fed operating procedures, notably post‑1979). The authors use CPI deflation and McCulloch zero‑coupon yields to decompose unexpected returns into news about future dividends, inflation, real rates, and excess returns, with subsample analyses (e.g., pre/post‑1973 and pre/post‑1979).
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Do Institutional Investors Destabilize Stock Prices? Evidence on Herding and Feedback Trading

context: This empirical study analyzes quarterly end-of-quarter holdings of 769 U.S. all-equity pension funds (aggregated to 341 money managers) from 1985:Q1 through 1989:Q4 across NYSE, AMEX and OTC equities. title: Do Bulls and Bears Move Across Borders? International Transmission of Stock Returns and Volatility as the World Turns
author: Wen-Ling Lin, Robert F. Engle, Takatoshi Ito
context: This triplet concerns intraday transmission from New York daytime S&P 500 returns to Tokyo overnight Nikkei 225 opening returns using intraday index data for September 1985–December 1989 (pre/around/post Oct 1987 Crash). Market-level daytime (open-to-close) and overnight (close-to-open) returns are measured with 10:00am openings to mitigate stale-quote bias. The paper finds a generally positive contemporaneous impact of New York daytime returns on Tokyo overnight returns over the full sample, but reports that this contemporaneous effect was not significant after the October 1987 Crash (with a separate lagged NY→Tokyo spillover appearing post‑Crash).
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; event studies; others

title: Peso Problems and Heterogeneous Trading: Evidence From Excess Returns in Foreign Exchange and Euromarkets
author: Martin D. Evans, Karen K. Lewis
context: This paper empirically examines whether excess returns on forward contracts contain permanent (unit-root) components using monthly spot and one-month forward exchange rates and short-term deposit yields for the U.S., U.K., Germany, and Japan over roughly 1975–1989. Units are currency exchange rates and Eurocurrency deposit forward contracts (data from Citicorp and Harris Bank). The authors estimate cointegrating relationships between spot and forward rates and decompose excess returns into permanent and transitory components to distinguish risk-premia from forecast-error or "peso"/noise-trader explanations.

title: Global Financial Markets and the Risk Premium on U.S. Equity
author: K.C. Chan, G. Andrew Karolyi, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper empirically examines daily excess returns on the U.S. market (S&P 500) and foreign equity indices—Japan's Nikkei 225 and Morgan Stanley Japan and EAFE—over 1978–1989 (1980–1989 for some indices) to test whether global market integration determines the U.S. equity risk premium. Using market-capitalization weights from Morgan Stanley, the authors model index-level daily returns under ICAPM/CAPM assumptions, account for non-synchronous trading and exchange-rate conversion, and estimate bivariate GARCH-in-mean dynamics relating conditional covariances/variances to expected excess returns.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Contrarian Investment, Extrapolation, and Risk
author: Josef Lakonishok, Robert W. Vishny, Andrei Shleifer
context: This empirical study analyzes U.S. common stocks (NYSE and AMEX) from April 1963–April 1990, forming annual portfolios beginning in April 1968 and following firms up to five years using CRSP and COMPUSTAT data. title: Jumps and Stochastic Volatility: Exchange Rate Processes Implicit in thePHLX Deutschemark Options
author: David S. Bates
context: Analyzes PHLX-traded Deutschemark option transactions and synchronous $/DM futures (Jan 1984–Jun 1991), using a weekly panel of option trades (morning Wednesdays; ~19,689 transactions) and noon futures quotes from the CME. title: Conditional Asset Allocation in Emerging Markets
author: Campbell R. Harvey
context: This paper analyzes monthly equity returns for 41 country markets (21 developed, 20 emerging) from 1976–1992 with out-of-sample portfolio evaluation over 1980.12–1992.06. title: Executive Pay and Performance: Evidence from the U.S. Banking Industry
author: R. Glenn Hubbard, Darius Palia
context: This paper analyzes U.S. commercial banks in the 1980s (roughly 1980–1989/1981–1990) using a panel of 147 publicly traded banks across 36 states and DC. It exploits staggered state-level interstate banking deregulation (changes in state laws permitting out-of-state entry) to study how increased corporate-control market competitiveness affected CEO pay levels, pay structure (equity/options), and turnover. Units of observation are banks and bank CEOs; identification leverages cross-state and over-time variation in regulatory regimes with bank- and CEO-fixed effects and year controls.

Units of observation are banks and bank CEOs; identification leverages cross-state and over-time variation in regulatory regimes with bank- and CEO-fixed effects and year controls.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Interstate banking deregulation
Outcome: CEO compensation level

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

context: This triplet analyzes CEO turnover in a subset of 125 publicly traded U.S. commercial banks (1980s) with complete CEO data. title: A Nonparametric Approach to Pricing and Hedging Derivative Securities   Via Learning Networks
author: James M. Hutchinson, Andrew W. Lo, Tomaso Poggio
context: This paper develops and evaluates nonparametric “learning network” pricing formulas (RBF, MLP, PPR) using Monte Carlo simulations calibrated to a typical NYSE stock (S0=$50, μ=10%, σ=20%) with two years of daily Black–Scholes option prices and six-month out-of-sample tests, and an empirical application to daily S&P 500 futures options from 1987–1991. Units are option contracts and underlying asset prices; institutional details include CBOE strike-introduction rules and discrete (daily) delta-hedging. The focus is on pricing accuracy and hedging performance in market data and simulated paths.
identification_methods: others

title: Testing Static Trade-off Against Pecking Order Models of Capital Structure
author: Lakshmi Shyam-Sunder, Stewart C. Myers
context: Analyzes U.S. publicly listed industrial firms (Compustat sample of 157 firms, excluding financials and utilities) over 1971–1989 to compare capital-structure theories. Units are firms observed annually with book debt ratios and detailed flow-of-funds components; most firms are large, typically investment-grade. The paper contrasts a pecking-order financing mechanism (debt issued to cover internal deficits) with static trade-off/target-adjustment models, using firm- and year-level regressions, instruments for anticipated deficits, panel and cross-sectional specifications, and simulation-based robustness checks.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; IV; other time-series regressions; others

title: Multifactor Models Do Not Explain Deviations from the CAPM
author: A. Craig MacKinlay
context: This paper examines U.S. equity returns (monthly July 1963–Dec 1991 and weekly July 1962–Dec 1992) using CRSP portfolios and broad indices (value‑weighted market, size/book‑sorted portfolios, S&P indices, and bond indices). Units are individual stocks and constructed portfolios (e.g., 32 portfolios, 33‑asset sets). The work contrasts CAPM and multifactor (APT/ICAPM) explanations with nonrisk alternatives (data‑snooping, sample selection, bid‑ask/frictions, investor irrationality), combining mean–variance theory, simulations, and empirical tests of pricing‑model intercepts.

title: Mark-Up Pricing in Mergers and Acquisitions
author: G. William Schwert
context: This empirical study analyzes 1,398 successful takeovers of NYSE- and Amex-listed target firms in the United States during 1975–1991 (main sample 1,173 deals consummated within a year). Using CRSP returns, Dow Jones/Wall Street Journal deal announcements and Comment’s M&A database, it studies pre-bid stock price runups, post-announcement markups, trading volume, and the role of insider trading and legal changes (Insider Trading Sanctions Act 1984, ITSFEA 1988) across deal types (tender offers, auctions, MBOs, cash/equity payments).
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Market Timing Ability and Volatility Implied in Investment Newletters'  Asset Allocation Recommendations
author: John R. Graham, Campbell R. Harvey
context: This paper studies 15,133 monthly asset-allocation recommendations from 237 U.S. investment newsletters (June 1980–Dec 1992). Observations are newsletter–months recommending equity vs. cash, converted into replicable S&P 500/cash portfolios. The authors test whether newsletters exhibit market-timing ability and persistence and whether cross-sectional dispersion of implied forecasts Granger-causes future realized and option-implied volatility and NYSE trading volume. They infer expected returns assuming exponential utility and use GARCH(1,1) volatility forecasts.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: How Different is Japanese Corporate Finance? An Investigation of the    Information Content of New Security Issues
author: Jun-Koo Kang, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper examines shareholder wealth effects around 875 domestic new security issues by Tokyo Stock Exchange–listed firms in Japan between January 1, 1985 and May 31, 1991. Using daily stock returns and announcement dates from the Nihon Keizai Shinbun, it analyzes public and private equity, rights offerings, straight, warrant and convertible debt amid 1980s deregulation and the late-1980s “bubble” (Nikkei surge and 1990–91 crash). Institutional features (Keiretsu links, bank financing, eligibility rules, credit ratings) and firm characteristics explain cross-sectional variation in announcement effects.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Explaining Forward Exchange Bias..Intraday
author: Richard K. Lyons, Andrew K. Rose
context: This paper tests whether zero intraday interest rates alter speculative behavior in the European Monetary System by analyzing intraday FX from March 13, 1979 to October 26, 1992. It examines French‑franc and Italian‑lira spot rates versus the German deutsche mark at intraday (market open to close) frequency using weekday observations. The study exploits EMS fixed‑rate tensions and high 30‑day euro‑currency interest differentials as a proxy for expected devaluation and evaluates how interest‑rate defenses affect intraday exchange‑rate returns.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Diversification, Integration and Emerging Market Closed-End Funds
author: Geert Bekaert, Michael S. Urias
context: This paper analyzes U.S. and U.K.-traded closed-end country funds (43 U.S., 37 U.K.) using weekly data from January 1986–August 1993 to assess diversification benefits and market integration of emerging equity markets. Units are fund share prices and NAVs and IFC investable indices for countries including Indonesia, Korea, Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand and Turkey. The institutional setting includes closed-end fund pricing puzzles, foreign ownership limits and capital‑market liberalizations (e.g. Taiwan Jan 1991, Korea Jan 1992), which create transaction costs and segmentation affecting global investors’ pricing kernels.

author: Geert Bekaert, Michael S. Urias
context: Using weekly U.S. and U.K.-traded closed-end country funds (Jan 1986–Aug 1993), the paper tests whether conditioning on lagged fund premiums (price minus NAV changes) alters measured diversification benefits. title: Trade Credit: Theories and Evidence

It analyzes cross-sectional relationships between firms’ accounts receivable/payable, credit purchases, and measures of access to institutional finance to infer how suppliers provide trade credit and how firms demand it, exploiting industry proxies and the survey’s firm-level financing, sales, and balance-sheet details.

title: Evidence on the Characteristics of Cross Sectional Variation in Stock Returns
author: Kent Daniel, Sheridan Titman
context: Using U.S. CRSP/Compustat data (primarily July 1963–December 1993, with many tests focused on 1973–1993), the paper analyzes individual common stocks (NYSE/AMEX/NASDAQ) and value‑weighted portfolios to test whether firm characteristics (size and book‑to‑market) or factor loadings (Fama–French Mkt, HML, SMB) drive cross‑sectional returns. Portfolios are formed on June/December accounting breakpoints, the analysis exploits January seasonality and five‑year pre/post formation windows, and units of observation are firms and characteristic‑sorted/zero‑investment portfolios.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Earnings and Expected Returns
author: Owen Lamont
context: This paper uses post‑war U.S. aggregate financial data (quarterly S&P Composite Index series from 1947–1994, with robustness checks using annual data 1871–1987) to study how the aggregate dividend payout ratio, dividend yield, and earnings predict future excess returns on stocks and corporate bonds. The unit of observation is the market aggregate (S&P Composite, bond portfolios). Analyses account for business‑cycle variables, interest‑rate spreads, inflation, and repurchases, and emphasize institutional episodes like the 1970s high‑inflation period and the 1980s repurchase expansion.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Heterogeneous Information Arrivals and Return Volatility Dynamics: Uncovering the Long-Run in High Frequency Returns
author: Torben G. Andersen, Tim Bollerslev
context: This paper analyzes one year (Oct 1, 1992–Sep 29, 1993) of high-frequency intraday five-minute Deutschemark–U.S. dollar exchange-rate returns (74,880 observations) constructed from Reuters interbank quotes. The unit is five-minute return intervals in the global FX interbank market, characterized by strong intraday seasonalities. Combining a theoretical mixture-of-distributions model with empirical spectral and time-series analysis, the authors estimate long-memory (fractional integration) in volatility and identify causal impacts of scheduled macroeconomic announcements (e.g., U.S. Employment, Bundesbank meetings, Durable Goods, Inventories) on volatility.
identification_methods: event studies; other time-series regressions

title: How Costly is Financial (not Economic) Distress? Evidence from Highly Leveraged Transactions that Became Distressed
author: Gregor Andrade, Steven N. Kaplan
context: Analyzes U.S. highly leveraged transactions (HLTs)—primarily management buyouts and leveraged recapitalizations completed in the 1980s (mostly after 1985)—following 31 firms from pre-transaction through financial distress resolution (through Dec 1995). Unit of observation is the firm; data come from SEC filings, CRSP, COMPUSTAT and Value Line industry benchmarks. The institutional setting emphasizes high leverage, junk bonds versus bank debt, and Chapter 11 restructurings, aiming to isolate costs of financial (not economic) distress by comparing firm outcomes to market and industry performance.

title: Financial Constraints and Stock Returns
author: Owen Lamont, Christopher Polk, Jesus Saa-Requejo
context: This paper studies US publicly traded firms (NYSE/AMEX/NASDAQ) from July 1968–December 1995, constructing firm-level portfolios sorted annually on financial-constraint measures (net cash flow, KZ index, interest coverage, dividend payout). Units are individual firms and zero-cost factor-mimicking portfolios whose monthly returns are analyzed to test whether financial constraints generate common covariation in stock returns. The setting links corporate-finance characteristics to macro shocks—monetary policy, credit spreads, and leading economic indicators—and examines IPOs and dividend omissions while controlling for size, book-to-market, industry, and exchange.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Option Hedging Using Empirical Pricing Kernels
author: Joshua V. Rosenberg, Robert F. Engle
context: This paper analyzes U.S. S&P500 index option prices and index returns using daily data over 1992–1996 (hedging tests on 839 hedging dates). Units of observation are S&P500 index returns and cross-sections of ATM and OTM option contracts. The authors recover daily empirical pricing kernels from option premia via a flexible risk-neutral density and estimate time-varying objective probabilities using a GARCH components-with-leverage model to simulate one-day-ahead derivative price distributions and evaluate minimum-variance hedges.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

Units of observation are S&P500 index returns and cross-sections of ATM and OTM option contracts. The authors recover daily empirical pricing kernels from option premia via a flexible risk-neutral density and estimate time-varying objective probabilities using a GARCH components-with-leverage model to simulate one-day-ahead derivative price distributions and evaluate minimum-variance hedges.

title: The Dark Side of Internal Capital Markets II: Evidence from Diversified Conglomerates
author: David S. Scharfstein
context: This paper empirically examines capital allocation within U.S. diversified conglomerates using a sample of 165 publicly traded conglomerates in 1979 (divisional observations) and follows outcomes through 1980–1994. It studies manufacturing divisions as units of observation, comparing divisional capital expenditures to stand-alone industry peers using three-digit industry Qs, and links investment distortions to managerial ownership (proxy statements) and FASB/SEC segment reporting rules that made segment data available. The setting is U.S. corporate internal capital markets across varied industries.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Do Foreign Investors Destabilize Stock Markets?  The Korean Experience  in 1997
author: Hyuk Choe, Bong-Chan Kho, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper examines how foreign investors traded and affected stock prices on the Korean Stock Exchange using transaction-level trades and daily foreign-ownership data from Nov 30, 1996 through Dec 1997 (covering the Oct–Dec 1997 Korean crisis). The units are trades and daily observations for 414 common stocks and investor classes (foreign, Korean individual, Korean institutional). The institutional setting includes KSE trading rules (two sessions, batch auctions), SSB foreign registration and binding foreign-ownership limits that changed in 1997; analyses use intraday (5-minute) and daily event windows.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

You are an expert economist.

# Task
Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This paper examines how foreign investors traded and affected stock prices on the Korean Stock Exchange using transaction-level trades and daily foreign-ownership data from Nov 30, 1996 through Dec 1997 (covering the Oct–Dec 1997 Korean crisis). The units are trades and daily observations for 414 common stocks and investor classes (foreign, Korean individual, Korean institutional). The institutional setting includes KSE trading rules (two sessions, batch auctions), SSB foreign registration and binding foreign-ownership limits that changed in 1997; analyses use intraday (5-minute) and daily event windows.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Foreign investors' trading
Outcome: Market destabilization

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Dating the Integration of World Equity Markets
author: Geert Bekaert, Campbell R. Harvey, Robin L. Lumsdaine
context: This paper studies capital‑market liberalizations in 20 emerging markets (monthly financial series and some annual indicators through the 1980s–mid‑1990s). Using country‑level time series — equity returns, dividend yields, market‑cap/GDP, trading turnover, net U.S. holdings and credit ratings — the authors date endogenous structural breaks in VARs and examine pre/post changes. The institutional setting comprises staggered policy reforms (ADRs, country funds, foreign‑ownership caps, exchange‑rate and regulatory reforms) associated with opening domestic equity markets to international investors.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other panel regressions

title: Global Diversification, Growth and Welfare with Imperfectly Integrated Markets for Goods
author: Bernard Dumas, Raman Uppal
context: This triplet refers to results from a two-country, one-good general-equilibrium model in which financial markets are complete and frictionless while goods markets are partially segmented via a proportional shipping cost. The unit of analysis is representative investors/countries and aggregate welfare. The authors calibrate the model to approximate integration between Western Europe and North America (τ=0.02; μ=0.08; σ=0.20; η=0.554) and report a 13% welfare gain from financial market integration.
identification_methods: others

title: Pairs Trading:  Performance of a Relative Value Arbitrage Rule
author: Evan G. Gatev, William N. Goetzmann, K. Geert Rouwenhorst
context: Using daily U.S. equity data from 1962–1997 (CRSP), the paper studies pairs trading across individual stocks (liquid CRSP-listed firms) to evaluate relative-price arbitrage. Pairs are formed on 12-month formation windows and traded over subsequent six-month horizons (monthly staggered starts). The institutional setting is the U.S. stock market with attention to market microstructure (bid–ask bounce, transaction costs), sector composition (utilities, financials, industrials, transportation), and the role of institutional/hedge-fund arbitrageurs in maintaining near–Law-of-One-Price pricing.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: International Asset Allocation with Time-Varying Correlations
author: Andrew Ang, Geert Bekaert
context: Using monthly MSCI total-return data from January 1970–December 1997 for US, UK and German equity markets (and US short rates and earnings yields), the paper studies dynamic international portfolio choice for a U.S. investor (CRRA preferences). It models asset returns and exchange-rate/hedged returns at the monthly level with two-state Markov regime‑switching processes (high‑ and low‑volatility regimes) to assess how time‑varying volatilities, correlations, and currency hedging affect optimal allocations and welfare.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: International Asset Allocation with Time-Varying Correlations
author: Andrew Ang, Geert Bekaert
context: For a U.S. CRRA investor using monthly MSCI total-return data (Jan 1970–Dec 1997) for the US, UK and Germany, the paper’s RS Beta (two-state Markov regime‑switching) models compare optimal portfolios with hedged versus unhedged foreign equity. Currency hedging benefits are measured by certainty-equivalent economic compensation: e.g., for a one‑year horizon with risk aversion y=5, failing to hedge costs about 70 basis points, and hedging delivers roughly half the total benefit of international diversification.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

# Role

# Task

- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
For a U.S. CRRA investor using monthly MSCI total-return data (Jan 1970–Dec 1997) for the US, UK and Germany, the paper’s RS Beta (two-state Markov regime‑switching) models compare optimal portfolios with hedged versus unhedged foreign equity. Currency hedging benefits are measured by certainty-equivalent economic compensation: e.g., for a one‑year horizon with risk aversion y=5, failing to hedge costs about 70 basis points, and hedging delivers roughly half the total benefit of international diversification.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Currency hedging
Outcome: International diversification benefit

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Hostility in Takeovers:  In the Eyes of the Beholder?
author: G. William Schwert
context: This paper empirically analyzes 2,346 takeover offers for U.S. exchange-listed target firms from 1975–1996. Units are takeover offers and the associated target and bidder firms; outcomes include deal success, auctions, premiums (runup and markup) and accounting performance. Hostility is measured via WSJ/DJNR and SDC classifications, unnegotiated tender offers, and pre-bid 13D/rumor activity. Data sources include CRSP (stock returns), Compustat (accounting), SDC, and press wire services, within the institutional setting of the U.S. corporate control market and evolving antitakeover defenses.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Profitability of Momentum Strategies:  An Evaluation of Alternative Explanations
author: Narasimhan Jegadeesh, Sheridan Titman
context: This paper empirically examines momentum profits in the U.S. stock market using NYSE/AMEX equities (excluding NASDAQ and stocks priced below $5) over January 1965–December 1997 (with subperiods 1965–1989 and 1990–1997). The unit of analysis is individual monthly stock returns and equal-weighted decile portfolios formed on 6-month past returns (held six months, overlapping). The study situates tests in a Fama–French factor framework, investigates January seasonality, evaluates behavioral vs cross-sectional/risk explanations, and analyzes post-formation returns up to 60 months, plus bootstrap simulations.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Behavioralize This!  International Evidence on Autocorrelation Patterns of Stock Index and Futures Returns
author: Dong-Hyun Ahn, Jacob Boudoukh, Matthew Richardson, Robert F. Whitelaw
context: This paper analyzes daily returns on stock indices and their corresponding futures contracts across 24 contracts in 15 countries, using contract-specific samples spanning primarily 1982–1999 (ending Feb 1999). The unit of observation is daily index and futures returns (with volume, open interest, interest/dividend data). The empirical setting exploits spot–futures no-arbitrage and variation in trading volume and transaction-cost bounds to test whether short-horizon positive autocorrelations arise from market microstructure (nonsynchronous trading, stale/bid–ask prices) or behavioral partial-adjustment models.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: On Mutual Fund Investment Styles
author: Louis K.C. Chan, Hsiu-Lang Chen, Josef Lakonishok
context: This analysis focuses on U.S. domestic equity mutual funds (Morningstar), but the growth-vs-value style performance test is conducted by annually sorting funds from 1984–1996 by average size and book‑to‑market into nine portfolios. context: This paper analyzes U.S. publicly listed firms (NYSE, AMEX, NASDAQ) over roughly 1975–1995, studying firm-level R&D and advertising expenditures under U.S. GAAP (where R&D is expensed) and their relation to subsequent stock returns and return volatility. Units are firms/stocks; portfolios are formed annually (end-April) with buy-and-hold returns tracked three years after formation. title: Explaining the Cross-Section of Stock Returns in Japan: Factors or Characteristics?
author: Kent Daniel, Sheridan Titman, K.C. John Wei
context: The paper studies monthly common-stock returns on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Japan, using firm-level data spanning the 1970s through December 1997 (returns available Jan 1971–Dec 1997; portfolio tests Oct 1975–Dec 1997). Units are individual listed firms and value-weighted portfolios sorted by market capitalization (size) and book-to-market. In the Japanese institutional setting the authors use annual unconsolidated book equity and market equity to form portfolios and test whether the observed size and value premiums arise from priced factor covariances (Fama–French factors) or direct characteristic effects.

title: No Contagion, Only Interdependence:  Measuring Stock Market Co-movements
author: Kristin Forbes, Roberto Rigobon
context: This paper empirically evaluates whether stock‑market contagion occurred around three major shocks—the October 1987 U.S. crash, the 1994 Mexican peso collapse, and the 1997 East Asian crises (notably the October 1997 Hong Kong crash). It uses daily aggregate national stock‑index returns (Datastream) for 28 countries (OECD and emerging markets), compares pre/post shock variance–covariance and correlations, and controls for short‑term interest rates to separate true changes in linkages (contagion) from heightened volatility and interdependence.
identification_methods: event studies; other time-series regressions

title: The Market for Catastrophe Risk:  A Clinical Examination
author: Kenneth A. Froot
context: This paper examines U.S. catastrophe (cat) insurance and reinsurance markets from 1970s–1990s with focus on 1992 (Hurricane Andrew) and 1996–1999 transactions (USAA’s Residential Re and CEA’s 1996 deal). Units are insurers, reinsurance treaties, and special-purpose noteholders; analyses use firm- and industry-level reinsurance contracts and premiums, AIR catastrophe-model outputs, and market outcomes across states (notably Florida and California) and Bermuda-based reinsurers. Institutional background includes regulatory guarantees, reinsurance market structure, cat-bond securitization, and post-event pricing cycles.

title: Bankers on Boards:  Monitoring, Conflicts of Interest, and Lender Liability
author: Randall S. Kroszner, Philip E. Strahan
context: This paper studies large U.S. non-financial firms (Forbes 500) around 1992, using firm-level Compustat/CRSP data and bank-firm loan data (LPC/Dealscan, covering lending from 1987 onward). Units are firms and their boards; key covariates include firm size, stock-return volatility (1988–1991), asset tangibility, and short-term debt. # Role
You are an expert economist.

# Task
Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This paper studies large U.S. non-financial firms (Forbes 500) around 1992, using firm-level Compustat/CRSP data and bank-firm loan data (LPC/Dealscan, covering lending from 1987 onward). Units are firms and their boards; key covariates include firm size, stock-return volatility (1988–1991), asset tangibility, and short-term debt. The analysis occurs within the U.S. legal and regulatory setting (Glass–Steagall limits on bank equity, equitable subordination and lender-liability doctrines) that may deter banks from active governance.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Tangible asset ratio
Outcome: Probability of banker on board

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: The Diversification Discount: Cash Flows vs. Returns
author: Owen Lamont, Christopher Polk
context: This paper examines U.S. publicly traded firms over 1979–1997 using Compustat segment data to compare multi‑segment (diversified) firms with portfolios of matched single‑segment firms (matched by 2/3/4‑digit SIC, excluding financial firms and sales <$20m). Units are firm‑years and matched portfolios; outcomes are market‑book (Q), market‑sales (M), and subsequent total returns (equity plus proxy bond returns). The study uses cross‑sectional and time‑series variation in the U.S. corporate sector to decompose the diversification discount into cash‑flow versus expected‑return components.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Investor Protection and Corporate Valuation
author: Rafael La Porta, Florencio Lopez-de-Silanes, Andrei Shleifer, Robert W. Vishny
treatment: Cash flow ownership of controlling shareholder
context: This paper studies how legal protection of minority shareholders and controlling shareholders’ cash-flow ownership affect corporate valuation using a cross-sectional sample of 371 large publicly traded firms from 27 wealthy countries in the late 1990s. It exploits cross-country institutional variation in shareholder rights, disclosure rules, and enforcement regimes; units are firms nested within countries. The authors develop a theoretical model and test it with firm-level regressions relating market valuation (Tobin’s q/market‑to‑book) to investor-protection indices and governance controls.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Do After-Tax Returns Affect Mutual Fund Inflows?
author: Daniel Bergstresser, James Poterba
context: This paper studies U.S. domestic equity mutual funds using fund-year data primarily from 1993–1998 (≈5,866 fund-years), with a smaller 1994–1998 sample for gross inflow/outflow analysis and an institutional-fund subsample. Units are individual mutual funds; data come from Morningstar and SEC filings. The institutional setting is the U.S. personal income tax system: authors construct after-tax (buy-and-hold) returns for hypothetical upper-income investors (assumed dividend/short-term tax 31%, long-term gains 20%, 10% effective accrual tax on unrealized gains) and analyze how after-tax returns and capital-gains overhangs predict fund inflows and redemptions.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Government Ownership of Banks
author: Rafael La Porta, Florencio Lopezde-Silanes, Andrei Shleifer
context: This paper analyzes 92 countries worldwide, using country-level measures of government ownership of the top-10 commercial and development banks (measured in the mid-1990s and pre-privatization circa 1985) and long-run outcomes over 1960–1995 and 1970–1995. The unit of observation is the country (aggregating bank-level equity shares to assets), and the institutional setting exploits cross-country variation in legal origins, privatization histories, property-rights protection, government intervention, and banking system development to study effects on subsequent financial development, productivity growth, and per-capita income growth.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Evaluating the Specification Errors of Asset Pricing Models
author: Robert J. Hodrick, Xiaoyan Zhang
context: This triplet examines whether scaling model factors by a January dummy (JAN = 1 for January months, 0 otherwise; for quarterly models JAN = 1 for the first quarter) affects HJ-distance when pricing the Fama–French 25 size–book-to-market portfolio excess returns and the Treasury bill. Estimation uses US monthly data 1952:01–1997:12 (quarterly 1953:Q1–1997:Q2), allowing the models' stochastic discount factor parameters to differ between January and other months.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Selling Company Shares to Reluctant Employees: France Telecom's Experience
author: Francois Degeorge, Dirk Jenter, Alberto Moel, Peter Tufano
context: Analyzes France Télécom's 1997 partial privatization share offers in France, using administrative data on 205,076 eligible current and former employees to study who participated, amounts invested, and plan choices. The institutional setting involved government-sanctioned employee offers—four plan types varying discounts, subsidized financing/leverage, holding periods, tax treatment, and downside protection—with eligibility rules, salary-linked investment caps, rationing potential, and differentiation between current employees, former employees, and retirees. Unit of observation: individual employees (current, former, retirees).
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Evaluating and Investing in Equity Mutual Funds
author: Lubos Pastor, Robert F. Stambaugh
outcome: Attainable Sharpe ratio relative to benchmarks
context: This paper empirically evaluates equity mutual fund performance and constructs optimal fund portfolios using US domestic equity mutual‑fund return data (CRSP Survivor‑Bias‑Free), with passive benchmark series from July 1963–December 1998 and fund histories through 1998. Unit of analysis is monthly fund returns (2,609 funds; investment‑universe subset of 505 no‑load funds). It compares alphas defined by CAPM, Fama–French (3‑factor) and Carhart (4‑factor) benchmarks, incorporates non‑benchmark passive assets (momentum, characteristic‑matched spreads, industry portfolios), and uses Bayesian/empirical‑Bayes and GMM estimation to account for parameter uncertainty.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

Unit of analysis is monthly fund returns (2,609 funds; investment‑universe subset of 505 no‑load funds). It compares alphas defined by CAPM, Fama–French (3‑factor) and Carhart (4‑factor) benchmarks, incorporates non‑benchmark passive assets (momentum, characteristic‑matched spreads, industry portfolios), and uses Bayesian/empirical‑Bayes and GMM estimation to account for parameter uncertainty.

Outcome: Attainable Sharpe ratio relative to benchmarks

- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Asset Liquidity and Segment Divestitures
author: Frederik P. Schlingemann, Rene M. Stulz, Ralph A. Walkling
context: This empirical study examines 325 U.S. publicly traded firms (assets > $100m) that first reduced their number of reported industry segments between 1979 and 1994. Using Compustat segment data, SDC M&A transactions, and press searches under the SFAS No.14 segment-reporting regime, the paper analyzes firm- and segment-level outcomes—performance, investment, diversification discounts, and an industry-level asset-liquidity index (two-digit SIC annual transaction value/industry assets)—to explain divestiture versus restructuring decisions. Units of observation are firms and business segments across U.S. industries.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: IPO Market Cycles: Bubbles or Sequential Learning?
author: Michelle Lowry, G. William Schwert
context: This empirical paper analyzes U.S. IPO market cycles using monthly aggregate and firm-level data (Ibbotson–Sindelar–Ritter, SDC, and CRSP), focusing on 1960–1997 for aggregate patterns and 1985–1997 for detailed firm-level analysis. Units are IPOs and issuing firms (monthly IPO counts, filings, withdrawals, registration lengths, and first-day returns). The institutional setting is the U.S. primary equity market and IPO pricing/book-building process, emphasizing underwriter behavior, information revealed during registration/roadshows, and investor sentiment/info spillovers across overlapping registration periods.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions
