title: Dividend Taxes and Share Prices: Evidence from Real Estate Investment Trusts
author: William M. Gentry, Deen Kemsley, Christopher J. Mayer
context: This empirical study analyzes US equity Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) from 1992–1999 (393 firm-year observations for 85 firms). It exploits REIT institutional features: exemption from corporate income tax, a requirement to distribute most taxable income as dividends (limited dividend discretion), and transparent analyst NAV appraisals. The authors regress REIT market equity values on market NAV and proxies for inside tax basis (book values) to test whether shareholder-level dividend tax benefits are capitalized into share prices.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Short Sale Constraints and Stock Returns
author: Charles M. Jones, Owen A. Lamont
context: This paper studies U.S. NYSE stocks from 1926–1933 using monthly stock-level data (CRSP) and daily loan rates published in the Wall Street Journal’s centralized NYSE “loan crowd” list. Units are individual stocks (211 ever-listed loan-crowd firms and the broader CRSP universe). The institutional setting features a public, centralized stock-loan market where loan/rebate rates reflect shorting costs; notable regime shifts (October 1930 anti-shorting pressure, March 1932 lending restrictions) affected supply and demand for lendable shares. Analyses link shorting costs and first appearances on the loan list to valuation and subsequent returns.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Cronyism and Capital Controls: Evidence from Malaysia
author: Simon Johnson, Todd Mitton
outcome: Stock price of Mahathir-connected firms without foreign listings
context: Analyzes how the 1997–98 Asian financial crisis and Malaysia’s September 1998 capital controls affected market valuations of 424 Malaysian listed firms. Using Gomez and Jomo’s coding of political ties (Mahathir- and Anwar-connected firms), the paper examines July 1997–August 1998 (crisis) and the September 1998 policy/political shock (capital controls and Anwar’s dismissal), exploiting variation in political connections, Bumiputera status, and prior foreign listings to infer changes in expected subsidies and access to international finance.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: A Multivariate Model of Strategic Asset Allocation
author: John Y. Campbell, Yeung Lewis Chan, Luis M. Viceira
context: This paper analyzes strategic asset allocation in US capital markets using two samples: postwar quarterly data (1952:2–1999:4) and long-run annual data (1890–1998). The unit of observation is asset returns (equities, long-term nominal Treasury bonds, short-term bills) and state variables (short-term nominal and real rates, dividend-price ratio, yield spread); the authors estimate VAR(1) dynamics, calibrate an Epstein–Zin infinite-horizon consumption–portfolio model, and construct hypothetical inflation-indexed bond returns to evaluate long-run portfolio choices.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Biases in the IPO Pricing Process
author: Michelle Lowry, G. William Schwert
context: This paper empirically analyzes U.S. initial public offerings (IPOs) during 1985–1999 (primary analyses focus on 1985–1997). Using firm-level IPOs from SDC/CRSP/EDGAR as units, it studies price updates between preliminary prospectus price ranges and final offer prices and subsequent first-day returns. title: Private Benefits of Control: An International Comparison
author: Alexander Dyck, Luigi Zingales
outcome: Percentage equity held by non-controlling shareholders
context: Using 412 firm-level control transactions from 1990–2000 across 39 countries, this paper estimates the value of private benefits of control (block-premia) and links those country-level measures to financial development outcomes. Units of observation include transaction-level blocks and firms, with country-level aggregates (ownership concentration, privatization methods, market capitalization/GDP). The institutional background exploits cross-country variation in shareholder legal rights (anti-director index), law enforcement, press diffusion, tax compliance, product-market competition, and privatization regimes to explain and instrument private benefits.
identification_methods: IV; event studies; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Stochastic Discount Factor Bounds with Conditioning Information
author: Wayne E. Ferson, Andrew Siegel
context: This paper evaluates Hansen–Jagannathan stochastic discount factor (SDF) variance bounds using US asset return data and simulations. It analyzes annual real stock and short-term interest returns (1891–1985), quarterly real Treasury-bill returns with per-capita consumption growth (1964Q3–1987Q4), and monthly returns on 25 value-weighted industry portfolios (1963–1994), conditioning on lagged instruments (Treasury-bill yields, dividend yield, lagged returns). Units are asset and portfolio returns; the study also estimates VARs and uses Monte Carlo/bootstrap simulations to assess finite-sample bias and derive bias-corrected bounds.

title: Who Underreacts to Cash-Flow News? Evidence from Trading between Individuals and Institutions
author: Randolph B. Cohen, Paul A. Gompers, Tuomo Vuolteenaho
context: Using US firm-level data (CRSP–Compustat matched firms combined with SPECTRUM institutional-holdings data), the paper analyzes 1983–1998 (23,501 firm-years) to study how stock prices and institutional vs. individual ownership respond to firm cash-flow news. The unit of observation is the firm (returns, book-to-market, ROE, and fraction institutional ownership), within the US equity market. The analysis rests on a present-value/Campbell decomposition of returns and considers institutional constraints (tracking error, transaction/short-sale costs) as mechanisms.

title: Confronting Information Asymmetries: Evidence from Real Estate Markets
author: Mark J. Garmaise, Tobias J. Moskowitz
context: This paper analyzes transaction-level commercial real estate sales across multiple U.S. local markets and states using the COMPS database. Units are individual commercial properties/transactions; the authors exploit exogenous cross-regional variation in property tax assessment quality as a proxy for local information availability. They test adverse-selection and signaling predictions by examining buyer origin (local vs. distant), income-history length, broker involvement, and financing choices to trace how information asymmetries affect participation, pricing, and deal structure in U.S. commercial real estate markets.

treatment: Increased use of S&P as a category

context: This paper studies comovement of US equities by analyzing S&P 500 inclusion and deletion events between 1976 and 2000 (inclusions Sept 22, 1976–Dec 31, 2000; deletions Jan 1, 1979–Dec 31, 2000). The unit of analysis is individual publicly traded US stocks (NYSE/AMEX/Nasdaq). It exploits index redefinitions—additions/removals that change a stock's category/habitat but not its fundamentals—using daily, weekly, and monthly return windows, matching, and calendar-time tests to infer trading-induced effects on betas, R2, and cross-category correlations.

title: Risk Reduction in Large Portfolios: Why Imposing the Wrong Constraints Helps
author: Ravi Jagannathan, Tongshu Ma

context: This paper examines how imposing portfolio weight constraints (no‑shorts, upper bounds) affects out‑of‑sample risk and estimation error for mean–variance portfolios. identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Law, Endowment, and Finance
author: Thorsten Beck, Asli Demirguc-Kunt, Ross Levine
context: This cross-country study of 70 former colonies examines how colonial legal origin (British Common law vs French Civil law) and initial endowments (log settler mortality from 17th–19th century sources, and latitude) explain contemporary financial development. Outcomes are measured primarily over 1990–95 (private credit/GDP, stock market capitalization/GDP) and property-rights indices. Units are countries/former colonies worldwide. Regressions control for religion, ethnic fractionalization, years since independence, region, and include robustness checks instrumenting political-structure measures.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; IV

title: International Joint Ventures and the Boundaries of the Firm
author: Mihir A. Desai, C. Fritz Foley, James R. Hines Jr.
outcome: Net income sensitivity to local tax rates
context: Uses BEA survey panel data on U.S. multinational parent firms and their foreign affiliates from 1982–1997 to study how parents choose ownership shares, intrafirm trade, royalties, and reported profits across countries and industries. Institutional features include changing ownership ceilings, international tax differentials, and technology-transfer incentives.

title: Spurious Regressions in Financial Economics?
author: Wayne E. Ferson, Sergei Sarkissian, Timothy Simin
context: This paper examines predictive regressions for monthly S&P 500 excess returns in the U.S., using historical samples from various subperiods (broadly 1926–1998) and a compiled set of monthly macro/financial instruments (e.g., yields, dividend yield, book-to-market). The authors calibrate Monte Carlo simulations to these data (and a sample of 500 potential instruments) and run univariate lagged-predictor time-series regressions to evaluate spurious-regression and data-mining biases in asset-pricing inference.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: The Illiquidity Puzzle: Theory and Evidence from Private Equity
author: Josh Lerner, Antoinetter Schoar
context: This paper studies U.S. private equity and venture‑capital funds (limited partnerships) in the late 1990s–early 2000s, using limited partnership agreements and investor lists to examine how sponsors choose contractual illiquidity (transfer restrictions) to screen investors. Units of observation are private equity partnerships/funds and their limited partners (endowments, foundations, institutional investors). The analyses compare later versus earlier funds by the same firm, the close‑knit California VC community, and industry‑specialized funds (pharmaceuticals versus computing) to link illiquidity provisions to investor composition and future fundraising costs.

title: Employee Stock Options, Corporate Taxes and Debt Policy
author: John R. Graham, Mark H. Lang, Douglas A. Shackelford
context: This paper empirically examines how U.S. corporate nonqualified employee stock option deductions affected firms' marginal corporate tax rates and leverage decisions around fiscal year‑end 2000. Using S&P 100 and Nasdaq 100 firms (190 firms observed as of July 17, 2001), the authors simulate taxable income and MTRs (accounting for 1998 two‑year carrybacks and 20‑year carryforwards through 2020) based on option footnote data, stock‑price simulations, and firm financials, and relate post‑option MTRs to capital structure (debt ratios) in cross‑sectional regressions controlling for firm size, profitability, R&D, tangibility and liquidity.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Mutual Fund Performance with Learning Across Funds
author: Christopher S. Jones, Jay Shanken
context: This paper studies U.S. active equity mutual funds using monthly CRSP returns (January 1961–June 2001), analyzing a sample of 5,136 domestic equity funds (average life ≈77 months). It estimates fund alphas from factor pricing models (CAPM, Fama–French, Carhart momentum, and additional industry factors) with a hierarchical Bayesian (Gibbs sampler) framework and Monte Carlo simulations to examine how dependent “learning” priors and survivorship (all vs. surviving funds) affect posterior beliefs about manager skill and optimal asset allocation.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: How is Macro News Transmitted to Exchange Rates?
author: Martin D. D. Evans, Richard K. Lyons
context: This paper empirically examines how macroeconomic news affects the DM/USD exchange rate by transmitting through order flow, using tick-by-tick transactions (marketmaker-to-marketmaker trades) and five-minute intervals from the Reuters Dealing 2000-1 system over May–August 1996. Daily and intraday analyses link Reuters Money Market Headline News arrivals (U.S. and German macro news) to signed order flow and price changes, estimating structural GMM models with state-dependent heteroskedasticity to distinguish direct and order-flow-mediated news effects in the major interbank spot DM/USD market.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Portfolio Choice and Health Status
author: Harvey S. Rosen, Stephen Wu
context: The paper uses four waves (1992, 1994, 1996, 1998) of the U.S. Health and Retirement Study, following cohorts born 1931–1941 (primary respondents aged ~51–61 at baseline). The unit of analysis is individuals and married households; the HRS provides detailed financial-asset holdings (checking/savings, CDs/T-bills, bonds, stocks/mutual funds, IRAs/Keoghs) and self-reported health. Working in the U.S. institutional setting where older households hold substantial wealth, the authors exploit panel variation in health while controlling for wealth, income and demographics to study health’s effect on portfolio composition.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Efficiency and the Bear: Short Sales and Markets around the World
author: William N. Goetzmann, Ning Zhu, Arturo Bris
context: This paper analyzes 1990–2001 equity market data from 47 countries worldwide, using firm-week and country-year observations (individual stocks and value‑weighted market indices) to study how legal and practical short‑selling restrictions and securities‑lending frictions affect price discovery, return synchronicity (MYY measures and R2), return skewness, volatility, and frequency of extreme negative returns. The empirical setting exploits cross‑country variation and several regulatory changes (e.g., Hong Kong, Sweden, Norway, Malaysia, Thailand) and controls for GDP per capita, industry concentration, governance, and year and country fixed effects.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Allowing and practicing short selling
Outcome: Price discovery efficiency

Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Do Asset Prices Reflect Fundamentals? Freshly Squeezed Evidence from the OJ Market
author: Jacob Boudoukh, Matthew Richardson, YuQing Shen, Robert F. Whitelaw
context: This triplet focuses on the impact of the USDA's mid‑October initial forecast of the upcoming season's U.S. orange production (the first official government forecast), using daily New York Cotton Exchange near‑maturity FCOJ futures returns over September 1967–December 1998. title: Do Asset Prices Reflect Fundamentals? Freshly Squeezed Evidence from the OJ Market
author: Jacob Boudoukh, Matthew Richardson, YuQing Shen, Robert F. Whitelaw
context: This triplet is assessed using daily FCOJ near‑maturity returns (New York Cotton Exchange) and classified Wall Street Journal articles over Jan 1, 1984–Nov 11, 1998. The paper leverages the geographic concentration of U.S. FCOJ supply around Orlando and shows that, of 384 WSJ stories, over 40% concerned U.S. production or Brazil; Brazil‑related stories are associated with return volatilities comparable to or greater than weather stories. The broader futures dataset spans Sept 1967–Dec 1998, but the Brazil‑news evidence uses the 1984–1998 WSJ sample.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; event studies

title: A Catering Theory of Dividends

context: The paper studies U.S. publicly traded firms (Compustat/CRSP firm-years) over roughly 1962–2000, and Citizens Utilities share classes 1956–1989, analyzing aggregate and firm-level dividend initiation/omission decisions and announcement returns. title: An Econometric Model of Serial Correlation and Illiquidity in Hedge Fund Returns
author: Mila Getmansky, Andrew W. Lo, Igor Makarov
context: This paper studies serial correlation in hedge-fund returns and the role of illiquidity by modeling and estimating smoothing in reported monthly returns for 908–909 hedge funds from the TASS database spanning November 1977–January 2001. The unit of observation is individual hedge funds (monthly returns and fund characteristics); the institutional setting is the hedge‑fund industry’s marking and valuation practices (broker‑dealer marks, mark‑to‑model, illiquid asset holdings) and fee structures (incentive fees/high‑water marks). The paper combines time‑series estimation of smoothing profiles with cross‑sectional analysis and simulations to link serial correlation to illiquidity exposure.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Financial Development and the Composition of Industrial Growth
author: Raymond Fisman, Inessa Love
treatment: Interaction of private bank credit and income similarity
context: This paper examines how financial development shapes intersectoral allocation by analyzing correlations in real value‑added growth across 37 manufacturing industries in 42 countries, using decade‑average growth (1980–1990). The unit is country‑pairs (861 pairs). Data combine UNCTAD industry growth, IFS macro series and La Porta et al. bank‑ownership measures (domestic credit, market cap, private bank credit). Identifying assumptions include global industry shocks and the Chenery hypothesis that countries with similar GDP per capita face similar growth opportunities; regressions control for trade, legal origin, and institutional variables.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Expected Returns and Expected Dividend Growth
author: Martin Lettau, Sydney Ludvigson
context: This paper uses U.S. annual per‑capita macro and financial data from 1948–2001 to study aggregate stock‑market valuation and expectations. The authors analyze consumption (nondurables & services), CRSP value‑weighted dividends (and repurchases in robustness), labor income, household wealth and excess stock returns to uncover time‑variation in expected dividend growth and expected excess returns at business‑cycle horizons (1–6 years). The approach relies on consumption‑based present‑value identities, cointegration, and VAR/time‑series forecasting to infer changing expectations in the U.S. aggregate stock market.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation of Latent Affine Processes
author: David S. Bates
context: This paper develops a maximum-likelihood, characteristic-function–based filtration for latent affine processes and applies it to 11,076 daily S&P 500 returns (United States) from 1953–1996. Observations are daily index returns; the economic setting is continuous-time stochastic volatility and jump-diffusion models used for asset pricing and option valuation. The study compares parameter and filtration estimates to prior EMM/SNP results, assesses time-varying volatility and jump intensities (including volatility-dependent arrival rates), and validates methods via Monte Carlo simulation.

title: A Multinational Perspective on Capital Structure Choice and Internal Capital Markets
author: Mihir A. Desai, C. Fritz Foley, James R. Hines, Jr.
context: This paper uses BEA Benchmark Survey data for 1982, 1989, and 1994 to analyze roughly 30,000 foreign affiliates of about 3,700 U.S. multinational firms operating in over 150 host countries. It examines how host-country corporate tax rates, capital market depth (private credit/GDP), creditor-rights indices, political risk and inflation affect affiliate leverage, interest rates, and the mix of parent-provided versus arm’s-length borrowing. Financials follow U.S. GAAP/FASB 52, enabling within-parent cross-country comparisons to isolate responses to local tax and contracting environments (1982–1994).
identification_methods: other panel regressions; IV

title: Asset Prices and Exchange Rates
author: Anna Pavlova, Roberto Rigobon
context: This paper develops a two-country, two-good general-equilibrium asset-pricing model linking terms of trade, exchange rates, and stock and bond prices, and tests its predictions using daily financial data for the US versus the UK (1988–2002) and Germany (1988–1998). Units are country-level asset prices: stock indices, three-month zero-coupon government bonds, and nominal exchange rates (converted to terms of trade via calibrated consumption shares). Key assumptions include stocks as claims to national output, real bonds, country-specific supply (output) shocks and demand/preference shocks, and identification through heteroskedastic latent-factor estimation.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Uncovering the Risk-Return Relation in the Stock Market
author: Hui Guo, Robert F. Whitelaw
outcome: Bias in estimated relative risk aversion
context: This paper empirically analyzes the US aggregate equity market using monthly and quarterly data: an implied-volatility sample (S&P100) from Nov 1983–May 1995 and longer realized-variance samples (market value-weighted CRSP) spanning Jan 1959–Dec 2000 and 1952Q3–2002Q3. Units are aggregate market returns and conditional variances; state variables include the consumption-wealth ratio (CAY) and a detrended short-term rate (RREL). Building on Merton’s ICAPM, the authors decompose expected returns into risk and hedge components and estimate a structural GMM system using option-implied volatility and lagged financial predictors.

title: Banks' Advantage in Hedging Liquidity Risk: Theory and Evidence from the Commercial Paper Market

context: The paper examines the US commercial paper market and banking system over 1988–2002 using weekly H.8 banking aggregates and a loan‑level Dealscan sample (1991–2002). title: The Conditional CAPM does not Explain Asset-Pricing Anamolies
author: Jonathan Lewellen, Stefan Nagel
context: This paper evaluates whether the conditional CAPM can explain cross-sectional return anomalies using U.S. equity data from July 1964–June 2001. The authors form value-weighted portfolios (NYSE and AMEX stocks) capturing size, book-to-market, and 6-month momentum strategies, use the CRSP value-weighted index as the market proxy, and adjust for microstructure (nonsynchronous trading). They estimate short-window CAPM regressions (daily/weekly/monthly) and predictive regressions with macro/business-cycle state variables to study time-varying betas and conditional alphas.

title: World Markets for Raising New Capital
author: Brian J. Henderson, Narasimhan Jegadeesh, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This paper analyzes global public security issuances by firms from 1990–2001 using SDC new-issues data (equity, nonconvertible debt, convertibles, preferreds) across countries and regions, with focused analyses on G7, the U.S., the U.K., and Eurobond markets. Units are firm-level/new-issue observations aggregated to country-region-months; auxiliary data include market-cap weighted returns, Euromoney openness/risk ratings, GDP, inflation and swap rates. title: The Declining Equity Premium: What Role Does Macroeconomic Risk Play?

title: Entry Regulation as a Barrier to Entrepreneurship
author: Leora Klapper, Luc Laeven, Raghuram Rajan
context: This paper analyzes firm incorporation, entrant size, and incumbent firm productivity across 47 two-digit industries in 21 European countries using firm-level Amadeus data for 1998–1999 (supplemented by Djankov et al. measures of entry costs and U.S. D&B industry entry rates). The units are limited-liability corporations (industry×country averages and firm cohorts by age). The study exploits cross-country variation in bureaucratic costs to register corporations, interacting these with industries’ "natural" propensity to enter, while controlling for financial development, labor rules, and intellectual property protection.

title: Investor Sentiment and the Cross-Section of Stock Returns
author: Malcolm Baker, Jeffrey Wurgler
context: This paper analyzes how investor sentiment influenced the cross-section of U.S. stock returns using monthly firm-level data (CRSP-Compustat) for nonfinancial common stocks over 1963–2001. The unit of observation is firm-months; sentiment is proxied by closed-end fund discounts, NYSE turnover, IPO activity, equity issuance share, a dividend premium, and a PCA-based composite, each orthogonalized to macroeconomic variables. The setting is the U.S. equity market across multiple bubbles and recessions, focusing on characteristics (size, age, volatility, profitability, dividends, growth, distress) predicted to be differentially affected by sentiment and arbitrage limits.

title: Corporate Tax Avoidance and High Powered Incentives
author: Mihir A. Desai, Dhammika Dharmapala
context: This analysis examines US publicly traded firms in 1993–2002 using Compustat and ExecuComp panel data, estimating within-firm (firm fixed effects) panel regressions. For the main full-sample tests of incentive pay effects, the authors use 6,816 firm-year observations on 1,381 firms (6,743 obs on 1,374 with controls), measuring tax sheltering as the residual book–tax gap after accounting for accruals and managerial incentives primarily via the Black–Scholes value of option grants as a share of total compensation. Year dummies and firm-clustered robust standard errors are used.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Are Perks Purely Managerial Excess?
author: Raghuram Rajan, Julie Wulf
context: Using a panel of more than 300 large U.S. publicly traded firms (primarily Fortune 500) over 1986–1999, the paper studies CEO and divisional-manager perquisite (perk) offerings. Unit of observation is firm-year and position (CEO or divisional manager), with rich Hewitt Associates compensation-survey data supplemented by Compustat, airport flight counts, county population/commute times, and state tax data. title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation of Stochastic Volatility Models
author: Yacine Ait-Sahalia, Robert Kimmel
context: This paper develops closed-form maximum-likelihood estimation for continuous-time stochastic-volatility diffusions and applies it to US S&P 500 index option markets. Empirical analyses use daily and weekly S&P 500 index levels and the CBOE VIX (a 30-day at‑the‑money implied‑volatility proxy) from January 2, 1990 to September 30, 2003 to estimate models (Heston, GARCH, lognormal, CEV). Units are daily/weekly market observations; option pricing and implied‑volatility inversion map observed prices into latent volatility for structural parameter identification. Monte Carlo simulations assess small-sample properties.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Can Interest Rate Volatility be Extracted from the Cross Section of Bond Yields?  An Investigation of Unspanned Stochastic Volatility
author: Pierre Collin-Dufresne, Christopher S. Jones, Robert S. Goldstein
outcome: Capture of time-series interest rate volatility
context: Using weekly U.S. LIBOR and swap data from January 1988–December 2004, the paper studies bootstrapped zero‑coupon yields (0.5–10 year maturities) to evaluate whether short‑rate volatility can be inferred from the cross‑section of bond prices. The unit is weekly yield observations across maturities; the setting is the U.S. interest‑rate swap/LIBOR market. The study compares affine term‑structure models (with and without unspanned stochastic volatility) to time‑series volatility measures (e.g., GARCH on the 6‑month rate) and estimates models by Bayesian MCMC with data augmentation.

title: Who Makes Acquisitions? CEO Overconfidence and the Market's Reaction
author: Ulrike Malmendier, Geoffrey Tate
outcome: Likelihood of cash or debt financing for mergers
context: This study analyzes large U.S. publicly traded firms (Forbes 500 sample) from 1980–1994 at the CEO–firm-year level. It links CEO overconfidence—measured via persistent late exercise of company stock options and press characterizations—to takeover behavior (merger incidence, diversification, financing choice) and announcement-period stock returns. title: Asset Pricing with Liquidity Risk
author: Viral V. Acharya, Lasse Heje Pedersen
context: The paper studies US equity markets (NYSE and AMEX) over the 1962/1964–1999 period using CRSP (daily returns and dollar volume) and Compustat book-to-market data. Units of observation are individual stocks and value- and equal-weighted portfolios (monthly and daily frequencies), sorted by illiquidity, illiquidity variation, size, and book-to-market. Theoretical background is an overlapping-generations asset-pricing model with time-varying per-share illiquidity costs; empirical work uses Amihud’s ILLIQ, AR models for illiquidity innovations, and portfolio cross-sectional tests of liquidity betas.

title: There is a Risk-Return Tradeoff After All
author: Eric Ghysels, Pedro Santa-Clara, Rossen Valkanov
context: This paper uses US aggregate equity returns (CRSP value-weighted index) at monthly and daily frequencies from January 1928–December 2000 to test Merton’s ICAPM relation between the conditional expected excess market return and conditional variance. The unit of observation is the aggregate market-month (monthly excess returns), with daily squared returns used to estimate month-ahead variance via the MIDAS mixed-frequency estimator (up to one year of lags). Analyses include symmetric and asymmetric variance specifications, comparisons to GARCH and rolling-window filters, and controls for business-cycle predictors.

question:
# Role
You are an expert economist.

# Task
Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This paper uses US aggregate equity returns (CRSP value-weighted index) at monthly and daily frequencies from January 1928–December 2000 to test Merton’s ICAPM relation between the conditional expected excess market return and conditional variance. The unit of observation is the aggregate market-month (monthly excess returns), with daily squared returns used to estimate month-ahead variance via the MIDAS mixed-frequency estimator (up to one year of lags). Analyses include symmetric and asymmetric variance specifications, comparisons to GARCH and rolling-window filters, and controls for business-cycle predictors.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Negative daily returns
Outcome: Short-term conditional variance

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Global Growth Opportunities and Market Integration
author: Geert Bekaert, Campbell R. Harvey, Christian Lundblad, Stephan Siegel
outcome: Ability to exploit global growth opportunities
context: This paper analyzes a panel of 50 countries (annual December observations broadly covering 1980–2002) using country-level units to test whether industry-weighted global price-earnings (P/E) ratios—combined with country industry weights (market cap or value-added)—predict five-year-ahead real GDP and investment growth. Data sources include Datastream, IFC, UNIDO and IMF. The authors exploit variation across countries and over time in financial openness (capital account, equity market, and banking liberalizations), include country fixed effects, and interact openness measures to assess whether openness enables exploitation of exogenous global growth opportunities.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Parametric Portfolio Policies: Exploiting Characteristics in the Cross Section of Equity Returns
author: Michael W. Brandt, Pedro Santa-Clara, Rossen Valkanov
context: This paper analyzes U.S. publicly listed stocks using CRSP-Compustat data from January 1964–December 2002. Unit of observation is individual firms (monthly returns; universe averages ~3,680 stocks; also analyses of the top 500). It models a CRRA investor choosing portfolio weights as functions of firm characteristics—size, book-to-market, and 12‑month momentum—under short-sale constraints, varying horizons, and conditional on the term spread, estimating parameters by maximizing sample-average utility with bootstrap inference.
identification_methods: others

title: Bank Mergers and Crime: The Real and Social Effects of Credit Market Competition
author: Mark J. Garmaise, Tobias J. Moskowitz
treatment: Decrease in bank competition (via large bank mergers)
context: Using U.S. microdata from the 1990s across 11 states and the District of Columbia, this analysis examines census-tract–level changes in median household income measured as the percent change from the 1990 to 2000 Censuses. The regressions relate that income change to merger-predicted changes in local bank concentration (∆BankHI1992:1999), constructed from mergers of large, non‑failing banks (≥ $1bn) during 1992–1999, with county fixed effects and local controls.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Labor Income Dynamics at Business-Cycle Frequencies: Implications for Portfolio Choice
author: Anthony W. Lynch, Sinan Tan
treatment: Temporary shocks to labor income growth
context: Using U.S. monthly data, the paper calibrates a life-cycle portfolio model for individual/household agents (working ages starting at 22 through retirement and death) to study how business-cycle predictability of labor-income growth affects stock holdings. It draws on market return and 12‑month dividend‑yield data (returns from 1927–2003) and aggregate labor‑income series (retail trade, total private, and nonfarm proprietor income from the 1959–2003/1964–2003 periods) and PSID-based permanent‑income volatility estimates to construct VARs and state‑dependent income shocks.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Internationalization and the Evolution of Corporate Valuation
author: Ross Levine, Sergio L. Schmukler
context: This paper analyzes the evolution of corporate valuation (Tobin’s q and its components) for 9,096 non-financial firms across 74 countries over 1989–2000. Firms are the unit of observation and “internationalization” is defined as cross-listing, issuing depositary receipts, or raising equity abroad (including U.S., LSE, and other major markets). The study compares firms that internationalize with domestic firms, using industry, country, and year controls to evaluate bonding, market segmentation, and market-timing explanations of valuation changes.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions

title: How Law and Institutions Shape Financial Contracts: The Case of Bank Loans
author: Jun Qian, Philip E. Strahan
context: This paper studies how laws and institutions shape bank loan contracts using a global sample of syndicated bank loans originated 1994–mid-2003 to large corporate borrowers in about 60 countries (excluding the U.S.). It links loan-level terms—interest spread over LIBOR, maturity, secured status—and ownership structure to country-level measures of creditor rights (disaggregated into ability to seize collateral vs. oust management), property rights, legal formalism, corruption, legal origin, and financial/economic development, controlling for borrower, loan, industry, and year effects.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Private Credit in 129 Countries
author: Simeon Djankov, Caralee McLiesh, Andrei Shleifer
context: This paper studies how legal creditor rights and information-sharing institutions affect private credit across 129 countries using annual country-level data from 1978–2003. The unit of analysis is the country (country-year), the outcome is private credit-to-GDP (IMF), and key treatments are an annual creditor-rights index and the presence/introduction of public and private credit registries. Analyses control for enforcement (days to enforce a contract), GDP, legal origin, and exploit cross-sectional variation, within-country reforms, and panel year effects to assess causal impacts on credit development.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; DiD; other panel regressions; IV

title: Explaining Returns with Cash-Flow Proxies
author: Peter Hecht, Tuomo Vuolteenaho
context: This empirical study analyzes U.S. equity returns using annual aggregate data (primarily 1881–2001, with VAR estimations often through 1998) and firm‑level panel data from CRSP‑Compustat (1954–1998). Units are the aggregate market index (S&P/CRSP value‑weight) and individual publicly traded U.S. firms. Using Campbell‑Shiller log‑linear present‑value identities and VAR decompositions, the paper assesses how cash‑flow proxies (dividend and earnings growth, dividend/earnings yields, term and default spreads) relate to one‑period expected returns, cash‑flow news, and expected‑return news.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: Volatility in an Era of Reduced Uncertainty: Lessons from Pax Britannica
author: William O. Brown, Richard C. K. Burdekin, Marc D. Weidenmier
context: This study uses monthly British 3% consol prices (end-of-month, Sept 1729–Dec 1959) to analyze changes in bond-market volatility across historical regimes. The unit is monthly consol returns for the UK, with comparisons to French 3% rentes. Key episodes include the Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815), Pax Britannica (1816–1913), the classical gold-standard era (1880–1913), WWI and WWII. The analysis controls for inflation, recessions, a callability premium and applies structural-break tests to link political/institutional stability to reduced financial volatility.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Expected Returns, Yield Spreads, and Asset Pricing Tests
author: Murillo Campello, Long Chen, Lu Zhang
context: This paper uses US firm-level corporate bond and equity data (Lehman Brothers, CRSP, Compustat) for 1,023 non‑financial firms from January 1973 to March 1998 to estimate ex‑ante equity risk premia inferred from bond yield spreads (adjusting for default, rating transitions, duration/convexity, and tax effects) and to test asset‑pricing cross‑sectional relations (market beta, size, book‑to‑market, momentum) and business‑cycle variation. The setting is the US corporate bond and equity markets; analyses exploit firm‑month panels, rolling time‑series regressions, and Fama‑MacBeth cross‑sectional tests.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Optimism and Economic Choice
author: Manju Puri, David Robinson
context: This paper uses individual-level data from the U.S. Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF) waves (mid-1990s–2001) to link respondents' subjective life-expectancy beliefs to economic choices. Units are SCF respondents (individuals/households) across the United States. The authors benchmark self-reported expected age at death against actuarial life tables adjusted for age, sex, race, smoking, and education, and analyze associations with self-employment, hours and retirement plans, remarriage, and portfolio allocation while accounting for SCF multiple-imputation and demographic controls.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

context: This paper uses individual-level data from the U.S. Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF) waves (mid-1990s–2001) to link respondents' subjective life-expectancy beliefs to economic choices. Units are SCF respondents (individuals/households) across the United States. The authors benchmark self-reported expected age at death against actuarial life tables adjusted for age, sex, race, smoking, and education, and analyze associations with self-employment, hours and retirement plans, remarriage, and portfolio allocation while accounting for SCF multiple-imputation and demographic controls.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

This paper uses individual-level data from the U.S. Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF) waves (mid-1990s–2001) to link respondents' subjective life-expectancy beliefs to economic choices. Units are SCF respondents (individuals/households) across the United States. The authors benchmark self-reported expected age at death against actuarial life tables adjusted for age, sex, race, smoking, and education, and analyze associations with self-employment, hours and retirement plans, remarriage, and portfolio allocation while accounting for SCF multiple-imputation and demographic controls.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair

title: Venture Capital Investment Cycles: The Impact of Public Markets
author: Paul Gompers, Anna Kovner, Josh Lerner, David Scharfstein
outcome: Investment by experienced venture capital firms
context: The paper analyzes US venture capital investments from 1975–1998 using Thomson Venture Economics data on 42,559 VC–company first-investment pairs across nine broad industries. It studies how public market signals (industry Q and venture-backed IPO activity) affect VC investment intensity and success, exploiting industry-year variation and lagged public-market measures. Units are industry-year aggregates and VC firm–industry–year observations; outcomes include number of investments and successful exits (IPO/registration or M&A). Regressions include industry and year fixed effects, detrending, and firm-level experience and specialization interactions.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Employee Sentiment and Stock Option Compensation
author: Nittai K. Bergman, Dirk Jenter
context: Analyzes US publicly traded firms (unbalanced panel from ExecuComp/CRSP/Compustat) over 1992–2003 to study non-executive employee stock option grants at the firm-year level. The paper combines a theoretical model with empirical tests linking prior stock performance, measures of managerial beliefs (discretionary accruals, insider trades, buybacks), and firm characteristics (cash, investment, leverage) to broad-based option use, emphasizing “new‑economy” firms and the late‑1990s tech‑bubble period as institutional background.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Liquidity and Expected Returns: Lessons From Emerging Markets
author: Geert Bekaert, Campbell R. Harvey, Christian Lundblad
context: This paper examines monthly excess equity returns and firm-level daily returns across 19 emerging equity markets (primarily January 1993–December 2003), using S&P/IFC indices and Datastream firm prices, to study whether liquidity (proportion of zero daily returns and price-impact measures) and equity market liberalization (an investability ratio capturing foreign access) affect expected returns. Units of observation are country equity indices and aggregated firms; analyses contrast segmented versus integrated regimes, validate liquidity proxies against limited bid-ask/turnover data and compare results to U.S. evidence.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Caught On Tape: Institutional Order Flow and Stock Returns
author: John Y. Campbell, Tarun Ramadorai, Tuomo O. Vuolteenaho
context: This empirical study uses U.S. equity transaction and holdings data from 1993–2000 (TAQ trades, CRSP securities, and Spectrum/13‑F institutional filings) for NYSE and AMEX-listed common stocks to infer daily institutional flows from quarterly 13‑F reports. Units of observation include stocks (quarterly and daily), individual trades, and institutional holdings. The analysis exploits trade-size patterns, panel controls, and time-series dynamics to link inferred institutional buy/sell flows to short‑term return movements and liquidity provision by non‑13F market participants.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Multifrequency News and Stock Returns
author: Laurent E. Calvet, Adlai J. Fisher
context: The paper develops and structurally estimates a multifrequency regime‑switching equilibrium model using daily U.S. excess equity returns (a Schwert/CRSP value‑weighted splice) over 1926–2003 (and a 1952–2003 postwar subsample). The unit of observation is the aggregate U.S. stock market (daily index); dividends are modeled with Markov‑switching multifractal volatility and investors have Epstein‑Zin preferences and possibly noisy signals about latent volatility. The setting permits analysis of volatility‑feedback, investor learning, and higher‑moment dynamics in long‑run U.S. equity data.
identification_methods: others

title: Trusting the Stock Market
author: Luigi Guiso, Paola Sapienza, Luigi Zingales
outcome: Share of financial wealth in stocks
context: Combining a theoretical model and empirical tests, the paper studies how subjective trust (perceived probability of being cheated) affects stock-market participation and portfolio shares. Empirical analyses use individual/household data (Dutch DNB household survey, Fall 2003, ~1,943 households), an Italian bank-customer survey (early 2000s, ~1,834 customers), firm-level data from the 1999 Italian Survey of Manufacturing Firms, and cross-country comparisons (World Values Survey and market ownership data). Units of analysis include individuals/households, firms, and countries; institutional context emphasizes investor protection, intermediaries, and country-level cultural trust differences.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Do Local Analysts Know More? A Cross-Country Study of the Performance of Local Analysts and Foreign Analysts
author: Kee-Hong Bae, Rene M. Stulz, Hongping Tan
treatment: Higher market R2 (market return explanatory power)
context: Using I/B/E/S annual earnings forecasts matched to analyst locations (via Nelson’s Directory) and S&P Transparency & Disclosure scores, the paper studies 20,425 analyst–firm forecasts for 611 large non‑U.S. firms across 32 countries during 2001–2003. The unit of observation is the analyst–firm–year forecast. The institutional backdrop leverages cross‑country variation in firm disclosure, accounting transparency, insider ownership, investor protection, U.S. investor holdings, and cross‑listing status to evaluate whether resident (local) analysts produce more precise earnings forecasts than foreign analysts.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Unobserved Actions of Mutual Funds

title: Securitization and the Declining Impact of Bank Finance on Loan Supply: Evidence from Mortgage Acceptance Rates
author: Elena Loutskina, Philip E. Strahan
treatment: Increasing depth of mortgage secondary market
outcome: Impact of local funding shocks on credit supply
context: This empirical study analyzes U.S. mortgage applications merged with bank Call Report data from 1992–2003. title: The Expected Value Premium
author: Long Chen, Ralitsa Petkova, Lu Zhang
context: This paper studies U.S. equity markets from 1941–2002 (with robustness checks for 1963–2002 and 1980–2002) using CRSP/Compustat and Moody’s data. The unit of observation is annually rebalanced, value-weighted stock portfolios sorted by book-to-market (quintiles and 2×3 size×B/M). It decomposes the ex-ante value (HML) premium into expected dividend-to-price and long-run dividend-growth components via Gordon-growth based predictive regressions, event-time analyses of firm payouts, VARs with macro indicators (consumption, investment, default spread), and checks including share repurchases.
identification_methods: event studies; other time-series regressions

title: Redistribution by Insurance Market Regulation: Analyzing a Ban on Gender-Based Retirement Annuities
author: Amy Finkelstein, James Poterba, Casey Rothschild
context: This paper analyzes the U.K. retirement annuity market using individual-level data on compulsory single-life annuity purchases (age 65) from a large insurer between 1981–1998 (12,160 annuitants). The institutional setting mandates annuitization of defined-contribution pension balances; insurers price primarily by age and gender and offer a menu of contract profiles. The authors jointly estimate a two-type Gompertz mortality-mixture model, calibrate a lifecycle utility/contract model that allows unobservable saving, and simulate the distributional and efficiency effects of banning gender-based (unisex) annuity pricing.
identification_methods: others

title: Managing Bank Liquidity Risk: How Deposit-Loan Synergies Vary with Market Conditions
author: Evan Gatev, Til Schuermann, Philip E. Strahan
context: This paper empirically analyzes large U.S. banks from 1990–2002, using weekly stock-return volatility (GARCH/realized) for top publicly traded domestic banks (about 170 firms, ~50,000 bank-week observations) matched to prior-quarter call-report balances (unused loan commitments, transactions deposits, liquidity and capital ratios). It leverages panel variation, cross-sectional comparisons, and market-wide episodes of tight short-term funding—proxied by the commercial paper–T-bill spread (notably the 1998 liquidity shock)—within the U.S. institutional setting of deposit insurance and central-bank backstops.

title: Flight-to-Quality or Flight-to-Liquidity? Evidence From the Euro-Area Bond Market
author: Alessandro Beber, Michael W. Brandt, Kenneth A. Kavajecz
outcome: Investors' preference for liquidity over credit quality
context: This paper analyzes daily intraday transactions, quotes, limit order books and net orderflow for Euro-area government bonds from April 2003 to December 2004 across 10 EMU countries (Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain). Units are country–maturity sovereign securities and daily net orderflow shares on the MTS interdealer platform, combined with CDS spreads and swaption/implied volatility. The stated “market stress” episodes are operationalized as periods of heightened market uncertainty: low bond-market liquidity (below median), high equity volatility (VIX/VSTOXX above median), high swaption implied volatility (above median), or days with unusually large net orderflow (top/bottom quartile).
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Why do firms hold so much cash? A tax-based explanation
author: C. Fritz Foley, Jay C. Hartzell, Sheridan Titman, Garry Twite
context: This paper studies U.S. multinational corporations using Compustat panel data from 1982–2004 and detailed BEA affiliate benchmark data (1982, 1989, 1994, 1999). The units are U.S. parent firms and their foreign affiliates. The institutional setting is the U.S. worldwide tax system—allowing deferral of U.S. tax on incorporated foreign earnings (with Subpart F and marginal/statutory rate considerations)—so repatriation tax burdens vary with host-country tax rates. The authors exploit cross-firm and within-firm (affiliate) variation to link repatriation tax costs to consolidated, domestic, and foreign cash holdings.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Information Cascades: Evidence from An Experiment with Financial Market Professionals
author: Jonathan E. Alevy, Michael S. Haigh, John List
context: This paper analyzes controlled laboratory experiments (early 2000s) run with 109 subjects—55 market professionals recruited from the Chicago Board of Trade floor and 54 undergraduates at the University of Maryland—who each played 15-round information-cascade games. Sessions varied urn informativeness (symmetric vs asymmetric) and the payoff domain (gains vs losses), with random assignment of choice order and treatments. Round-level individual decisions are used to study how private-signal strength, public-signal quality, and trader experience affect cascade formation and Bayesian updating.
identification_methods: RCT; other panel regressions; others

context: This empirical paper studies valuation of the U.S. nonfarm, nonfinancial corporate sector using annual Flow of Funds data extended back to 1926 through 2004 and Compustat firm-level aggregates (1971–2004). Units of observation are aggregate corporate assets and firm-level equity/debt cash flows; the institutional setting is the U.S. corporate sector across major macro episodes (Great Depression, postwar, 1980s repurchase wave). Cash flow is defined as net payout (dividends, interest, net equity and debt repurchases/issuance) and valuations are analyzed under a log-linear present-value/cointegration framework.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Do Analysts Herd? An Analysis of Recommendations and Market Reactions
author: Narasimhan Jegadeesh, Woojin Kim
context: This paper studies US sell-side analysts’ stock recommendation revisions and subsequent stock price reactions using IBES and CRSP data from November 1993–December 2005. Observations are analyst-stock-day recommendation revisions (upgrades/downgrades) with at least two other active analysts, focusing on one-level changes. The setting is US equity markets; the model assumes efficient prices incorporate public consensus and revisions. Cross-sectional variation includes analyst experience, brokerage size, and pre-revision dispersion; event windows around revision dates (and earnings) are used to infer market interpretation of herding incentives.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Who Blows the Whistle on Corporate Fraud?

title: Who Blows the Whistle on Corporate Fraud?
author: Alexander Dyck, Adair Morse, Luigi Zingales
context: Using the paper's sample of alleged corporate frauds in large U.S. public firms (assets > $750M; cases ending 1996–2004), the short-seller analysis compiles monthly firm-level short-interest (from Bloomberg, normalized by shares) and examines monthly dates 1994–2004. The unit of observation is the firm-month; the authors estimate logistic models (with firm fixed-effect specifications as a robustness check) predicting whether a fraud is detected in a given month as a function of lagged short interest and aggregate short activity.

title: The Term Structure of Real Rates and Expected Inflation
author: Andrew Ang, Geert Bekaert, Min Wei
context: Analyzes U.S. quarterly nominal zero-coupon Treasury yields and CPI inflation from 1952:Q2–2004:Q4. The unit of observation is aggregate quarterly financial/macro series (short- and long-maturity yields and CPI inflation). Using a no-arbitrage, regime-switching term structure model with time-varying prices of risk, the paper decomposes nominal yields into real yields, expected inflation, and an inflation risk premium across monetary-regime episodes (e.g., 1979–82 monetary targeting, Volcker disinflation) and addresses identification limits of inflation-indexed bonds.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Creative Destruction and Firm-Specific Performance Heterogeneity
author: Hyunbae Chun, Jung-Wook Kim, Randall Morck, Bernard Yeung
context: Using U.S. industry panels from 1971–2000, the paper analyzes publicly traded firms in 41 traditional two-digit manufacturing and non‑manufacturing industries (Compustat/CRSP firms) to link industry IT capital intensity to firm‑specific stock‑return and sales‑growth heterogeneity and subsequent five‑year TFP growth. The setting is the late‑20th‑century U.S. economy during rapid IT diffusion amid deregulation, trade liberalization, and evolving financial markets; IT‑producing and financial sectors are excluded and analyses condition on industry and time fixed effects with controls for firm demography, competition, R&D, and finance.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions

title: Why Do Private Acquirers Pay So Little Compared to Public Acquirers?

context: The paper studies 1,292 completed cash acquisitions of U.S. public target firms by U.S. bidders (private and public) during 1990–2005. title: Has New York Become Less Competitive in Global Markets? Evaluating Foreign Listing Choices Over Time

title: Has New York Become Less Competitive in Global Markets? Evaluating Foreign Listing Choices Over Time
author: Craig Doidge, G. Andrew Karolyi, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper studies non-U.S. firms’ foreign listing choices, valuations, and capital-raising from 1990–2005, comparing New York venues (NYSE, AMEX, NASDAQ, OTC/Rule 144a) to London markets (LSE Main Market, AIM). Using firm-level panel data on listings, Tobin’s q, ownership, and country legal/institutional variables, it evaluates whether regulatory changes—notably Sarbanes–Oxley (2002) and differing U.K. listing regimes—altered firms’ propensity to list, listing premia, and post-listing financing.

title: Do Security Analysts Speak in Two Tongues?
author: Ulrike Malmendier, Devin Shanthikumar
context: This empirical study examines U.S. security analysts’ recommendations and annual earnings forecasts using IBES data (primarily 1994–2008) and NYSE TAQ trading data (1993–2002). The units are analyst–stock–day observations and investor trades (small vs. large) for U.S.-listed firms (NYSE, Amex, NASDAQ). The institutional setting emphasizes incentives from underwriter affiliation, investment-banking pressure, reputational capital, and the post-2001 analyst conflicts-of-interest spotlight, exploiting earnings-announcement and recommendation/forecast update windows.

title: Neighbors Matter: Causal Community Effects and Stock Market Participation
author: Jeffrey R. Brown, Zoran Ivkovich, Paul A. Smith, Scott Weisbenner
context: This paper uses a 1987–1996 panel of U.S. federal tax returns (zip-code/MSA identifiers) to estimate whether community stock-market participation causes individual taxable stock ownership. The unit is taxpayers/households in 337 U.S. MSAs, with the core sample restricted to “natives” who remain in the same MSA and birth state. The analysis merges Census, Compustat/CRSP, and DDB sociability data and focuses on equity ownership in taxable accounts, exploiting Social Security birth-state information to build instruments for neighbor ownership while controlling for rich time-varying and fixed effects.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions

# Role

title: Financial Literacy and Stock Market Participation
author: Maarten van Rooij, Annamaria Lusardi, Rob Alessie
context: Using 2005–2006 modules of the DNB Household Survey, this paper studies Dutch households (respondents aged ~22–90) to assess how financial literacy influences household stock-market participation. title: When Does a Mutual Fund's Trade Reveal its Skill?
author: Zhi Da, Pengjie Gao, Ravi Jagannathan
context: This paper studies US active equity mutual funds and the stocks they trade using quarterly holdings and tick-by-tick transactions from 1983–2004. Units are mutual fund-quarter observations and individual stocks (NYSE, AMEX, NASDAQ). The authors infer trades from quarter-end holdings, measure information-events with the probability of informed trading (PIN) and alternative measures, and evaluate fund performance using Carhart four-factor alphas and characteristics-based (DGTW) selectivity, controlling for PIN risk to examine how trading in high-PIN stocks reveals manager skill and persistence.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Corporate Misreporting and Bank Loan Contracting
author: John R. Graham, Si Li, Jiaping Qiu
context: This paper analyzes U.S. publicly listed firms that announced financial restatements (GAO database) between January 1997 and June 2002, using 237 restating firms and 2,451 bank-loan observations from Dealscan spanning 1989–2004. The unit of analysis is the loan (facility/tranche) and firm; the institutional setting is U.S. private bank lending (syndicated and bilateral loans priced over LIBOR) where contract features (spread, maturity, collateral, covenants, syndicate structure) reflect credit risk and information asymmetry after disclosure of restatements (including fraud and SEC actions).

author: Marianne Bertrand, Simon Johnson, Krislert Samphantharak, Antoinette Schoar
outcome: Fraction of ownership held by sons
context: This paper studies nearly 100 of Thailand’s largest family business groups using hand-collected family trees and firm-level ownership, board and financial data for 1996 (pre-1997 Asian crisis). title: High Idiosyncratic Volatility and Low Returns: International and Further U.S. Evidence
author: Andrew Ang, Robert J. Hodrick, Yuhang Xing, Xiaoyan Zhang
context: This paper studies the cross-sectional relation between lagged idiosyncratic stock-return volatility and subsequent average returns using firm-level daily and monthly returns from July 1963–December 2003 for the U.S. and January 1980–December 2003 for 23 developed markets (G7 and other developed countries). Units are individual publicly listed firms/stocks; returns and volatility are measured in USD and local currency using local, regional and world Fama–French models. Analyses use monthly portfolio sorts and cross-sectional/time-series regressions controlling for size, value, momentum and trading/information frictions.

title: Catering Through Nominal Share Prices
author: Malcolm Baker, Robin Greenwood, Jeffrey Wurgler
context: The paper analyzes U.S. publicly traded firms using CRSP/Compustat and IPO data (1963–2006) to study how corporate stock-split and IPO pricing decisions respond to time-varying investor preferences for low-priced and small-cap stocks. title: Common Risk Factors in Currency Markets
author: Hanno Lustig, Nikolai Roussanov, Adrien Verdelhan
context: This paper analyzes monthly spot and one-month forward exchange rates for 37 developed and emerging currencies from November 1983 to March 2008, from the perspective of a U.S. investor. It forms six portfolios sorted by forward discounts (interest differentials), accounts for bid–ask transaction costs, and links cross-sectional carry-trade returns and time-series predictability to a common global stochastic discount factor. The analysis situates currency risk premia in a no-arbitrage affine asset-pricing framework and relates them to U.S. macrofinancial indicators (industrial production, payrolls, VIX).
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: Fooling Some of the People All of the Time: The Inefficient Performance and Persistence of Commodity Trading Advisors
author: Geetesh Bhardwaj, Gary B. Gorton, K. Geert Rouwenhorst
context: Using Lipper-TASS performance data for commodity trading advisors (CTAs) reporting in the U.S. markets, the paper studies CTA performance, fees, and persistence over 1994–2007. The unit of observation is individual CTA funds (and equally-weighted CTA indices); the institutional setting emphasizes voluntary reporting to vendor databases, resulting in backfill, survivorship and look-back biases, and a regulatory/background comparison to earlier publicly-offered commodity pools. Analyses adjust for fees (estimating gross returns) and benchmark CTA returns to public dynamic futures-based strategies.

title: Individual Investor Mutual-Fund Flows
author: Zoran Ivkovich, Scott Weisbenner
treatment: Change in fund NAV since purchase
context: This triplet refers to household-level mutual-fund purchases by individual U.S. investors in the brokerage sample (Jan 1991–Nov 1996; ~78,000 households, ~325,000 purchases across ~1,100 funds) and, specifically, holdings in taxable accounts. The outcome is the monthly probability of sale in months since purchase; the treatment is NAV_RETURN (change in fund NAV since purchase, i.e., total returns minus distributions). Estimates come from a Cox proportional-hazards model with nonparametric baseline hazards for each investor–mutual-fund-type (objective × index status × family).

title: Individual Investor Mutual-Fund Flows
author: Zoran Ivkovich, Scott Weisbenner
context: This paper examines individual U.S. investors’ mutual-fund trading using detailed brokerage transactions for ~78,000 households from January 1991–November 1996 (over 325,000 purchases across ~1,100 funds). Units are household-level fund purchases/sales and monthly fund-level inflows/outflows, with holdings split into taxable and tax-deferred accounts. Fund characteristics come from CRSP and Morningstar. The institutional setting includes U.S. realization-based capital-gains taxation, fund expense ratios and loads, allowing within-investor and within-fund comparisons to identify tax-motivated trading and cost sensitivities.

title: Private Equity and Long-Run Investment: The Case of Innovation
author: Josh Lerner, Morten Sørensen, Per Strömberg
context: This empirical study examines how private equity (primarily leveraged buyouts) affects firms’ long‑run innovative investment by linking Capital IQ transactions (closed 1980–2005) to U.S. USPTO patent grants observed through May 2007. The units are firms (495 private equity‑backed entities) and their patents (≈6,938 grants); analyses focus on event windows three years before to five years after a transaction. The setting evaluates changes in patent counts, citations, originality, generality, and portfolio concentration using patent‑class/year controls and firm/year fixed effects, while noting selection and causation limits.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions

title: What Segments Equity Markets?
author: Geert Bekaert, Campbell R. Harvey, Christian Lundblad, Stephan Siegel
context: The study analyzes monthly and annual country‑level data (primarily 1980–2005, with monthly series from 1973–2005) for 50 countries (developed and emerging). title: Does Corporate Governance Matter in Competitive Industries?
author: Xavier Giroud, Holger M. Mueller
context: Using U.S. firm-year panel data (Compustat) from 1976–1995, the paper studies how staggered passage of 30 state business combination (BC) laws (primarily 1985–1991) affected firm performance. Units are U.S. firms defined by state of incorporation and state of location, with industry competition measured by HHIs (3-digit SIC). BC laws constrained hostile takeovers by moratoria on business combinations; identification exploits variation in adoption timing and incorporation-location mismatches, with event dates from contemporary newspaper reports.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Why Did Some Banks Perform Better During the Credit Crisis? A Cross-Country Study of the Impact of Governance and Regulation
author: Andrea Beltratti, René M. Stulz
context: This paper analyzes cross-country variation in buy-and-hold stock returns for 98 large deposit-taking banks (assets >$50bn) across about 20 countries during the 2007–2008 global credit crisis (main window July 2007–Dec 2008 and the Lehman month Sep 12–Oct 10, 2008). It links pre-crisis (2006) bank-level governance (RiskMetrics/CGQ), ownership, balance-sheet and profitability metrics (Tier 1, deposits, loans, liquidity), and country-level regulation and institutions (Caprio/Barth/Levine indices, Kaufmann governance) to differential bank performance.

title: Banking Deregulations, Financing Constraints, and Firm Entry Size

title: Trust and Delegation
author: Stephen Brown, William Goetzmann, Bing Liang, Christopher Schwarz
context: The paper analyzes 444 hedge-fund due-diligence (DD) reports on 403 advisors compiled by a private DD firm from 2003–2008 (with survival follow-up into 2009) in the U.S. hedge fund industry (including onshore and offshore vehicles). title: A Reference Point Theory of Mergers and Acquisitions
author: Malcolm Baker, Xin Pan, Jeffrey Wurgler
context: Analyzes U.S. public-target mergers and acquisitions announced between 1984 and 2007 (primary samples of 7,498 deals, with 5,135 completed deals), merging Thomson Financial deal records with CRSP/Compustat. title: Creditor rights and corporate risk-taking
author: Viral V. Acharya, Yakov Amihud, Lubomir Litov
context: This paper analyzes how cross-country variation in bankruptcy creditor-rights influences firms’ risk-taking using legal measures from La Porta et al. title: How Do Retirees Value Life Annuities? Evidence from Public Employees
author: John Chalmers, Jonathan Reuter
context: This paper studies 32,060 retirements in the Oregon Public Employees Retirement System (PERS) from January 1990 to June 2002. Each retiree (ages roughly 50–70) chose between a total life annuity and a lump-sum; PERS computes benefits using DC, DB, and DCDB formulas with fixed conversion factors, making PERS annuities substantially more generous than private TIAA annuities. The institutional setting includes 6% employee contributions, regular/variable account investments, no default payout, and time-series variation from 10-year Treasury yields and equity-market shocks (S&P, NASDAQ, VIX).

title: Bankruptcy and the Collateral Channel
author: Efraim Benmelech, Nittai K. Bergman
context: This paper studies U.S. airlines during 1994–2007 using tranche-level transactions in aircraft-backed securities (ETCs/EETCs/PTCs). The unit of observation is tranche transactions (127 tranches, 18,327 trades) issued by airlines; collateral is identified via aircraft serial numbers and model types. The institutional setting features Section 1110 protections, Chapter 11/7 bankruptcies, liquidity facilities/credit enhancers, and relatively illiquid secondary markets for used aircraft. Identification exploits time-series variation in airline bankruptcies and cross-sectional overlap between tranche collateral and bankrupt airlines’ fleets to estimate effects on credit spreads.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Stressed not Frozen: The Fed Funds Market in the Financial Crisis
author: Gara Afonso, Anna Kovner, Antoinette Schoar
context: This paper studies US overnight federal funds transactions around the 2008 financial crisis, focusing on the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy (September 15, 2008) and subsequent policy actions (AIG bailout Sept 16, IOR Oct 9, CPP Oct 14). Using proprietary Fedwire transaction-level data aggregated to bank holding companies (daily borrower- and lender-level observations; ~360 borrowers, ~274 lenders) from April 1, 2008–Feb 28, 2009, it examines how bank size, performance (NPLs, ROA), and pre-crisis repo reliance affected fed funds access, rates, and counterparties within the institutional setting of Fed facilities, the discount window, and a disrupted repo market.

identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Information, analysts, and stock return comovement
author: Allaudeen Hameed, Randall Morck, Jianfeng Shen, Bernard Yeung
treatment: Forecast revision dispersion for prominent firms
context: This empirical study analyzes U.S. public firms listed on NYSE, AMEX and NASDAQ over 1984–2007 across 69 GICS industries. The unit of observation is individual firms/stocks, using weekly returns (CRSP), quarterly fundamentals (Compustat ROA) and analyst coverage and EPS forecast revisions (I/B/E/S). The institutional setting is U.S. equity markets with heterogeneous analyst attention creating “prominent” (heavily followed) and “neglected” firms; the paper leverages industry peer structures and forecast-revision events (bellwether stocks) to test unidirectional information spillovers from prominent to neglected stocks.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Corporate Bond Default Risk: A 150-Year Perspective
author: Kay Giesecke, Francis A. Longstaff, Stephen Schaefer, Ilya Strebulaev
context: This paper analyzes U.S. corporate bond default rates and credit spreads for nonfinancial firms using a newly compiled annual value-weighted dataset covering 1866–2008. The primary unit is the annual value-weighted default rate (par value) of domestic nonfinancial corporate bonds; auxiliary series include aggregate stock returns, interest rates, corporate yields, and NBER recession indicators. The institutional background spans 19th–20th century bankruptcy/receivership regimes, evolving bond-market structure, and recovery practices. Analyses study long-run determinants of defaults, clustering of default cycles, and whether spreads price realized default losses.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Modeling Financial Contagion Using Mutually Exciting Jump Processes
author: Yacine Aït-Sahalia, Julio Cacho-Diaz, Roger J.A. Laeven
context: This paper models and estimates cross‑market jump contagion in international equity indices (daily MSCI log‑returns) across six world regions (US, UK, Developed Europe, Japan, Emerging Asia, Latin America) using data mostly from January 1980–December 2008 (some series begin in 1988). The unit of observation is regional daily stock‑index returns; the setting emphasizes rare large jumps and crisis episodes (e.g., 1987, 1998, 2008). title: Measurement Errors in Investment Equations
author: Heitor Almeida, Murillo Campello, Antonio F. Galvao Jr.
context: This paper examines measurement error in firm-level investment equations using a COMPUSTAT panel of U.S. manufacturing firms (1970–2005). The unit of observation is the firm-year; the study focuses on how measurement error in Tobin’s q (average vs. marginal q) biases estimates of investment–cash‑flow sensitivities. The authors compare higher‑order‑moment (Erickson‑Whited) estimators with IV strategies (OLS‑IV, Arellano–Bond GMM), account for firm fixed effects, autocorrelation, and heteroskedasticity, and evaluate implications for financing‑friction interpretations of investment.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: The Effect of Housing on Portfolio Choice

context: Using seven SIPP panels covering roughly 1990–2004 (home purchases observed since 1975) in the United States, the paper analyzes roughly 64,000 homeowner households to estimate how property values, mortgage debt, and home equity affect the share of liquid wealth held in stocks. title: The Capital Structure Decisions of New Firms
author: Alicia M. Robb, David T. Robinson
context: This study analyzes capital-structure choices of U.S. startups identified at founding in 2004 using the Kauffman Firm Survey (≈4,928 firms; analytic sample ≈3,972) followed through 2007. The unit is the nascent firm (and primary owner), observed across industries and MSAs. The paper exploits cross-sectional and short-panel variation—including Saiz (housing supply elasticity) at the MSA level and state bankruptcy homestead exemptions—to infer how pledgeable collateral and credit conditions affect initial bank debt, trade credit, insider funding, and subsequent survival, employment, and profit growth.

title: The Effects of Stock Lending on Security Prices:  An Experiment
author: Steven N. Kaplan, Tobias J. Moskowitz, Berk A. Sensoy
context: This paper reports a randomized lending experiment with a large anonymous money manager (> $15bn AUM) who randomly made two-thirds of its high-loan-fee U.S. small- and mid-cap equity holdings available for securities lending and withheld the remainder. title: How did increased competition affect credit ratings?

context: This empirical study examines how the rise of Fitch as a third credit rater affected incumbent ratings quality in the U.S. corporate bond market, using issuer- and issue-level data from roughly 1995–2006 (with discussion through 2007). title: Snow and Leverage
author: Xavier Giroud, Holger M. Mueller, Alex Stomper, Arne Westerkamp
context: This empirical study examines 115 highly leveraged Austrian ski hotels that underwent debt restructurings between 1998 and 2005 (with a control sample of 2,095 hotels). The Austrian Hotel- and Tourism Bank (AHTB) mediated restructurings under eligibility rules for “structurally important” hotels; data include pre- and post-restructuring accounting and local weather. The authors use two-year Unexpected Snow (relative to a ten-year average) to distinguish liquidity versus strategic distress and to instrument reductions in leverage, estimating effects on ROA, margins, costs, and sales.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: The European Union, the Euro, and Equity Market Integration
author: Geert Bekaert, Campbell R. Harvey, Christian T. Lundblad, Stephan Siegel
context: Using monthly firm-level data (1980–2007) for 33 European countries, the paper studies bilateral country-pair-year equity valuation differentials (industry earnings yields) to evaluate how EU membership and Euro adoption affected cross-border equity market integration. Units are country-pairs constructed from value-weighted industry portfolios. The institutional setting is European market liberalization, regulatory harmonization, Maastricht/Euro accession, and varying exchange-rate regimes. The analysis exploits time variation in membership, country-pair and year effects, and instruments (distance to Brussels) while examining channels like trade, FDI, regulation, and interest-rate convergence.

title: Capital-Market Effects of Securities Regulation: Prior Conditions, Implementation, and Enforcement
author: Hans B. Christensen, Luzi Hail, Christian Leuz
context: The paper studies firm-level stock-market liquidity across 26 European countries from 2001–2011 (about 112,260 firm-quarter observations, ~4,846 firms), exploiting staggered national transposition dates of two EU directives—the Market Abuse Directive (MAD) and the Transparency Directive (TPD)—that tightened insider-trading and disclosure rules. title: Margin-Based Asset Pricing and Deviations from the Law of One Price
author: Nicolae Gârleanu, Lasse Heje Pedersen
context: In the paper’s theoretical continuous-time general-equilibrium model, heterogeneous agents (relatively risk-averse and risk-tolerant investors) trade risky securities that have security-specific margin (haircut) requirements. Negative shocks to fundamentals (falls in dividends/aggregate consumption) reduce leveraged agents’ wealth and raise their shadow cost of funding, causing margin constraints to bind and thereby lowering collateralized risk-free rates while raising risk premia and Sharpe ratios, particularly for high-margin securities.
