title: Does Aggregated Returns Disclosure Increase Portfolio Risk-Taking?
author: John Beshears, James J. Choi, David Laibson, Brigitte C. Madrian
context: This paper evaluates whether aggregating investment-return disclosures affects portfolio risk-taking using randomized experiments. Primary evidence comes from a year‑long online field RCT (summer 2008–2009) in which 597 U.S. adult participants allocated $325 among four real mutual funds (U.S. equity, international equity, bonds, money market) and were randomized to weekly vs biannual return viewings, portfolio‑ vs asset‑level reporting, and historical‑return graph treatments. The authors supplement this with laboratory and post‑lab experiments (2013) on students and mixed samples to probe mechanisms and robustness.

title: Adoptive Expectations: Rising Sons in Japanese Family Firms
author: Vikas Mehrotra, Randall Morck, Jungwook Shim, Yupana Wiwattanakantang
context: This paper studies nearly the population of Japanese non-financial firms that listed between 1949–1970 (sample ~1,367 firms) and follows firm-year data from 1962 through 2000. It examines intergenerational succession events and performance for founders, biological heirs, and non-blood (adopted/son-in-law) heirs in postwar Japan, emphasizing institutional practices of adult adoption (yōshi) and arranged marriage that shape succession. title: Global Crises and Equity Market Contagion

context: This paper analyzes transmission of the 2007–09 global financial crisis using weekly US-dollar returns for 415 country-sector equity portfolios across 55 countries from Jan 1995–Mar 2009 (crisis defined Aug 7, 2007; robustness to Lehman Sept 15, 2008). title: Are Corporate Default Probabilities Consistent with the Static Tradeoff Theory?
author: Armen Hovakimian, Ayla Kayhan, Sheridan Titman
context: This empirical study analyzes US nonfinancial firms (firm-year observations) from 1985–2008 (46,219 obs), testing whether firm default probabilities (S&P issuer ratings and Moody’s KMV EDF) reflect static tradeoff predictions. Using Compustat/CRSP financials, simulated marginal tax rates, and Moody’s EDF, the authors examine how firm size, asset tangibility, R&D, profitability, and market shocks relate to default risk, account for selection into ratings (visibility instruments: NYSE listing, S&P indexes, industry-rated share), and exploit panel variation and regime-switching to assess dynamic responses to shocks.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: The Effect of Providing Peer Information on Retirement Savings Decisions
author: John Beshears, James J. Choi, David Laibson, Brigitte C. Madrian, Katherine L. Milkman
context: A randomized field experiment conducted in 2008 at a large U.S. manufacturing firm (~15,000 employees) evaluates how disseminating age‑bracket peer 401(k) information affects individual savings choices. Between July and September 2008, non‑participants and low‑saving employees aged 20–69 received Quick Enrollment or Easy Escalation mailings that were randomly assigned to include no peer data or peer participation rates for 5‑ or 10‑year age brackets. The design exploits variation in union status, automatic‑enrollment defaults, and employer match thresholds to assess enrollment and contribution responses.
identification_methods: RCT

title: Mutual Fund Performance and the Incentive to Generate Alpha
author: Diane Del Guercio, Jonathan Reuter
context: This paper uses U.S. retail mutual fund data from 1992–2004 to examine how distribution channels shape incentives to generate alpha. title: The Out of Sample" Performance of Long-run Risk Models"
author: Wayne E. Ferson, Suresh K. Nallareddy, Biqin Xie
context: This paper evaluates long-run risk asset-pricing models for the United States using annual data spanning 1931–2009. Units of analysis include aggregate consumption and dividend series and excess returns on portfolios (size, book-to-market, momentum deciles), the market portfolio, and bonds of varying maturities and credit quality. It compares stationary and cointegrated Bansal–Yaron–style specifications, estimating parameters (via GMM and related methods) with lagged state variables (risk-free rate, log price/dividend) and rolling out-of-sample prediction to assess pricing of unconditional expected returns and risk premiums.

title: The Cost of Friendship
author: Paul Gompers, Vladimir Mukharlyamov, Yuhai Xuan
context: This paper studies U.S. venture capital syndication during 1975–2003 using 3,510 individual venture capitalists and 11,895 portfolio-company investments. Units of analysis are person-investments and VC dyads (founding and follow-on partners). The institutional setting is private U.S. venture investing, with hand-collected biographic data (education, ethnicity, prior employers), and success measured by IPO outcomes. context: This paper analyzes daily US quotes on zero‑coupon inflation caps and floors from October 6, 2009 to March 27, 2012 to recover option‑implied probability densities for average CPI inflation at 1, 3, 5, 7 and 10‑year horizons. The units are inter‑dealer option quotes and derived risk‑neutral probabilities. The sample spans the post‑financial‑crisis, zero‑lower‑bound period, encompassing Federal Reserve unconventional policies (LSAP‑2), FOMC announcements, and interactions with the TIPS and inflation‑swap markets.
identification_methods: event studies; other time-series regressions

This paper analyzes daily US quotes on zero‑coupon inflation caps and floors from October 6, 2009 to March 27, 2012 to recover option‑implied probability densities for average CPI inflation at 1, 3, 5, 7 and 10‑year horizons. title: Target Revaluation after Failed Takeover Attempts – Cash versus Stock
author: Ulrike Malmendier, Marcus Matthias Opp, Farzad Saidi
context: This paper examines unsuccessful U.S. merger bids and tender offers for publicly traded targets from 1980–2008, merging SDC deal records with CRSP/Compustat and hand-collected LexisNexis failure reasons. Unit of observation are target (and acquirer) firms; main analyses compare short-run cumulative abnormal returns (25-day windows) and longer-horizon valuation, subsequent takeover hazard and operational outcomes for cash- versus stock-financed offers. The institutional setting includes regulatory interventions, market/industry shocks, and differences in bidder financing revealed by the medium of exchange.

title: As Certain as Debt and Taxes: Estimating the Tax Sensitivity of Leverage from Exogenous State Tax Changes
author: Florian Heider, Alexander Ljungqvist
context: Using firm-level panel data on publicly traded U.S. nonfinancial firms from 1989–2011, the paper exploits 121 staggered changes in state corporate income tax rates across U.S. states to identify tax effects on capital structure. It focuses on firms' long-term leverage, leveraging firms' headquarters' state exposure (apportionment rules, nexus) and includes industry-year fixed effects, firm controls, neighboring-state border comparisons, and treatment reversals to isolate tax-driven changes in debt policy.

title: Systematic Risk, Debt Maturity, and the Term Structure of Credit Spreads
author: Hui Chen, Yu Xu, Jun Yang
context: This paper studies US nonfinancial firms’ debt-maturity choices and the term structure of credit spreads over the business cycle by combining a dynamic capital-structure model with empirical tests. It uses aggregate Flow of Funds evidence (1952–2010), firm-level Compustat/CRSP panel data (1974–2010), and corporate bond/CDS data (2004–2010) to analyze firms (the unit) in US corporate debt markets. The setting exploits variation in macro states (expansions vs. recessions), firms’ systematic risk (asset betas), leverage, and bond liquidity to study causal links between beta, maturity choice, and credit spreads.

title: An Intertemporal CAPM with Stochastic Volatility
author: John Y. Campbell, Stefano Giglio, Christopher Polk, Robert Turley
context: This paper studies U.S. equity markets using quarterly data from 1926:2 through 2011:4. Units of analysis include the aggregate CRSP value‑weighted market return, realized (daily) market variance, financial state variables (price‑smoothed P/E, default spread, Treasury bill rate), and cross‑sections of stock portfolios (size and BE/ME and beta‑sorted portfolios). The setting is the historical U.S. stock and corporate bond markets; the authors model long‑horizon intertemporal hedging for Epstein‑Zin long‑term investors and estimate a VAR with affine stochastic volatility and GMM cross‑sectional pricing.

title: Wrongful Discharge Laws and Innovation
author: Viral V. Acharya, Ramin P. Baghai, Krishnamurthy V. Subramanian
context: This study analyzes the effect of state-level wrongful discharge laws (public-policy, implied-contract, and especially the good-faith exception) on firm innovation and entrepreneurship in the U.S. using firm-year data from 1971–1999. Exploiting staggered, precedent-driven adoption of these common-law exceptions across states, the authors link USPTO patents (counts and citations) matched to Compustat firms, patents per employee/R&D, and Business Dynamics Statistics on new establishments and job creation to identify changes in innovative effort and start-up formation.

title: Speculative Betas
author: Harrison Hong, David Sraer
context: This paper studies U.S. equity markets (monthly data, mainly 1970–2010; analyst forecasts 1981–2010; short-interest 1988–2009) using individual stocks and 20 beta-sorted portfolios. It links stock-level outcomes (returns, turnover, short interest, analyst forecast dispersion) to aggregate disagreement and economic uncertainty. The institutional setting emphasizes heterogeneous investors (short-sale–constrained mutual funds vs unconstrained arbitrageurs/hedge funds) and short-sale constraints that may generate speculative overpricing of high‑beta stocks; aggregate disagreement is proxied by beta-weighted analyst LTG dispersion and Bloom’s plant-level uncertainty series.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Arbitrage Asymmetry and the Idiosyncratic Volatility Puzzle
author: Robert F. Stambaugh, Jianfeng Yu, Yu Yuan
context: This paper studies U.S. equity markets from August 1965 to January 2011, using individual common stocks and value-weighted portfolios to examine how idiosyncratic volatility relates to average returns. The authors combine 11 documented return anomalies to construct a cross-sectional mispricing ranking, adjust returns with Fama–French three-factor regressions, and use the Baker–Wurgler investor-sentiment index (and macro controls) to study time-varying mispricing and arbitrage asymmetry driven by short-sale impediments and arbitrage risk.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Do Acquisitions Relieve Target Firms' Financial Constraints?
author: Isil Erel, Yeejin Jang, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This study analyzes 5,187 acquisitions of European target firms completed between 2001 and 2008, using unconsolidated firm-year financial statements to observe targets before and after becoming wholly owned subsidiaries. context: This estimate focuses on acquiring firms in the paper's sample of European target acquisitions (completed 2001–2008). Using consolidated financial statements for the subsample of 1,215 acquirers, the authors estimate panel regressions with firm fixed effects, year dummies, and country-level financing controls and find that acquirer cash holdings decline after acquisitions; they also construct an “adjusted” acquirer cash measure (adding back purchase price for deals with Zephyr deal values) to rule out payment-driven declines.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; event studies; others

# Context
This estimate focuses on acquiring firms in the paper's sample of European target acquisitions (completed 2001–2008). Using consolidated financial statements for the subsample of 1,215 acquirers, the authors estimate panel regressions with firm fixed effects, year dummies, and country-level financing controls and find that acquirer cash holdings decline after acquisitions; they also construct an “adjusted” acquirer cash measure (adding back purchase price for deals with Zephyr deal values) to rule out payment-driven declines.

title: Asset Quality Misrepresentation by Financial Intermediaries: Evidence from RMBS Market
author: Tomasz Piskorski, Amit Seru, James Witkin
context: Using matched BlackBox–Equifax loan-level data for U.S. non-agency RMBS originated 2005–2007, this paper studies mortgages and securitized pools (loans, borrowers, underwriters, trustees, institutional investors) across U.S. MSAs during the housing boom and early crash. It evaluates contractual disclosure (prospectus representations and warranties) and misreporting of owner-occupancy and simultaneous second-lien status, links misrepresentation prevalence to local house-price and origination booms, and analyzes loan- and pool-level outcomes (defaults, pricing, and potential repurchase exposure) within the securitization institutional setting.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: Learning about CEO Ability and Stock Return Volatility
author: Yihui Pan, Tracy Yue Wang, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This paper examines market learning about CEO ability using 1,873 CEO turnovers at 1,582 U.S. publicly traded firms between 1992 and 2006 (volatility data through 2009). The unit of analysis is firm-months and firm-CEO pairs, using monthly realized, idiosyncratic, and option-implied volatilities. A theoretical Bayesian learning model (dividend/earnings GBM, efficient markets) motivates tests; empirical analyses compare exogenous (death/retirement) vs forced turnovers and control for post-turnover actions, firm characteristics, and calendar effects.

title: Indirect Incentives of Hedge Fund Managers
author: Jongha Lim, Berk A. Sensoy, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This paper studies how hedge fund performance drives investor flows and managers’ lifetime compensation using a panel of 2,687 open-end hedge funds from the TASS database over 1995–2010, analyzed at monthly, quarterly and annual frequencies. The unit is fund-period observations (fund-year/quarter/month) in the hedge-fund industry, with rich contractual detail (management and incentive fees, high-water marks), fund age, and strategy (capacity-constrained vs scalable). The authors combine flow regressions with contingent-claims valuation to quantify direct and indirect pay-for-performance.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; event studies; others

title: 'Lucas' In The Laboratory
author: Elena Asparouhova, Peter Bossaerts, Nilanjan Roy, William Zame
context: Laboratory asset-market experiments run in multiple sessions at Caltech, UCLA and the University of Utah, with human subjects trading two long‑lived assets (a risky “Tree” with i.i.d. High/Low dividends and a consol Bond) under a controlled infinite‑horizon design (random termination, continuation probability β=5/6). Subjects received time‑varying private income, faced perishable cash except in the terminal period, and traded via an electronic continuous double‑auction (Flex‑E‑Markets). The study tests causal implications of the Lucas asset‑pricing model for prices, returns and consumption smoothing.
identification_methods: RCT; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Is a VC Partnership Greater than the Sum of its Partners?
author: Michael Ewens, Matthew Rhodes-Kropf
context: Using VentureSource and hand-collected data on US venture-backed financings from 1987–2012 (firms founded through 2005 for exit observation), the paper studies individual venture capital partners’ board-seat investments and firm exits (IPO, M&A, exit valuation). The analysis tracks 5,000+ partners, their employment histories, and movements across VC firms to disentangle partner human capital from VC firm organizational capital in the venture-capital industry, exploiting partner ‘mover’ episodes and exit outcomes to infer causal contributions to investment performance.

title: Time Varying Risk Aversion
author: Luigi Guiso, Paola Sapienza, Luigi Zingales
context: This paper studies changes in individual risk aversion around the 2008 financial crisis using a panel of clients of a large Italian bank surveyed in June–September 2007 and re-interviewed in June 2009 (≈666 respondents), merged with monthly administrative asset and trade records (Dec 2006–2009). It examines trading responses to the Sep 2008–Feb 2009 market collapse and tests a fear-based mechanism in a randomized laboratory experiment (March 2011) with 249 U.S. undergraduate subjects exposed to a horror-film treatment.

title: Combining Banking with Private Equity Investing
author: Lily Fang, Victoria Ivashina, Josh Lerner
treatment: Being a lender in a private equity deal
outcome: Odds of winning future lending mandates
context: This paper studies U.S. private-equity transactions and their syndicated loan financing from 1983–2009 (loan-level analyses mainly 1988–2008; CLO-flow analyses 2001–2008), comparing bank‑affiliated versus stand‑alone sponsors and parent‑financed deals. Units are private‑equity deals and associated loans, linking loan terms, syndicate retention, and ex‑post outcomes (downgrades, exits). Identification leverages credit‑cycle variation—predefined peak years (1985–89, 1998–2000, 2005–07) and CLO fund‑flow shocks—within the institutional setting of the U.S. syndicated loan market and post‑crisis regulation debates (e.g., the Volcker Rule).
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

author: Yihui Pan, Tracy Yue Wang, Michael S. Weisbach
treatment: Being in CEO's first three years
context: The paper analyzes U.S. publicly traded firms from roughly 1980 to 2009, studying 5,420 CEO appointments in 2,991 firms to estimate how investment, disinvestment, asset and employment growth evolve over CEO tenure. title: The Twilight Zone: OTC Regulatory Regimes and Market Quality
author: Ulf Brüggemann, Aditya Kaul, Christian Leuz, Ingrid M. Werner
context: This paper studies U.S. over-the-counter (OTC) equity markets from January 2001 through October 2010 using a panel of ≈10,583 domestic firms (firm-months ≈955,716). It exploits variation across OTC trading venues (NASDAQ Bulletin Board, OTC Pink tiers, Grey Market), firms’ SEC filing status, inclusion in securities manuals, and state “blue sky” merit-review regimes — including several Pink Sheets regulatory changes — to estimate effects on market quality (liquidity and crash risk). Identification leverages within-firm venue and reporting-status transitions, regulatory reforms, and cross-state institutional differences.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; PSM; other panel regressions

author: Hui Chen, Michael Michaux, Nikolai Roussanov

title: Advance Refundings of Municipal Bonds
author: Andrew Ang, Richard C. Green, Yuhang Xing
context: This paper analyzes US municipal bond advance-refundings over 1996–2009 (MSRB/Bloomberg trades), covering 148,961 CUSIPs (~$454 billion par, ~51% of traded pre-refunded bonds). Unit of observation: CUSIP-level bonds and issuer "deals" across the 50 U.S. states. Using institutional details of municipal call provisions, SLGS escrow rules, and balanced-budget restrictions, the authors model option values (Vasicek/Hull-White), quantify option value and fees lost to issuers, and relate cross-sectional variation (e.g., state governance) to losses.

title: Relationship and Transaction Lending in a Crisis
author: Patrick Bolton, Xavier Freixas, Leonardo Gambacorta, Paolo Emilio Mistrulli
context: This triplet is estimated using Italian Bank of Italy credit-registry data at the firm–bank loan level. The treatment is each firm’s share of transactional loans measured in 2008:q2 (pre-Lehman), and the outcome is the firm default probability observed over the six quarters following Lehman’s collapse (2008:q3–2010:q1). Units are firms (the sample covers many tens of thousands). Relationship vs. transaction banks are classified by geographic proximity. The main specification is a marginal probit (cross-sectional) with bank and industry fixed effects; robustness adds firm controls.

title: The Price of Political Uncertainty: Theory and Evidence from the Option Market
author: Bryan Kelly, Lubos Pastor, Pietro Veronesi
context: This paper studies how political uncertainty is priced in equity option markets by examining options whose maturities span national elections and economically-relevant global summits. It uses OptionMetrics and realized-variance data for index options across 20 countries (option samples mainly 2002–2012, with S&P 500 data back to 1990) and summit windows concentrated in 2007–2011. The unit of observation is country-level equity index options; analysis exploits scheduled event timing, poll spreads, and country-level macro indicators (GDP growth, IMF forecasts, CLI, recent market returns).

title: Misinformed Speculators and Mispricing in the Housing Market
author: Alex Chinco, Christopher Mayer
context: This paper analyzes transactions‑level county deeds and housing price/rent indices across 21 U.S. metropolitan areas during January 2000–December 2007 (with resale observations through 2008) to study how out‑of‑town second‑house buyers affected subsequent house price appreciation and implied‑to‑actual‑rent (IAR) mispricing during the mid‑2000s boom. The unit of observation is single‑family house purchases (classified by tax‑bill mailing address as owner‑occupant, local second‑house, or out‑of‑town second‑house). title: Can Taxes Shape an Industry? Evidence from the Implementation of the “Amazon Tax”
author: Brian Baugh, Itzhak Ben-David, Hoonsuk Park
context: This paper studies how state laws requiring Amazon to collect sales tax (“Amazon Tax”) affected consumer purchases. Using transaction-level data from an online account aggregator for about 275,000 U.S. households from January 2011–May 2015 across 19 treated and 31 control states, the authors analyze monthly tax-exclusive Amazon spending around staggered state implementation dates (2012–2015). The setting contrasts online retail (Amazon) with brick-and-mortar and other online competitors, exploiting variation in local sales tax rates and timing to estimate effects on total and large (≥$250) purchases and substitution to rivals like Newegg and Best Buy.

title: Do ETFs Increase Volatility?
author: Itzhak Ben-David, Francesco Franzoni, Rabih Moussawi
context: The paper studies U.S. equity markets from roughly 2000–2012, focusing on stocks (S&P 500 and Russell 3000 constituents) and 660 U.S. ‘‘plain vanilla’’ equity ETFs traded on U.S. exchanges. Using intraday TAQ data, monthly holdings, ETF AUM and NAVs, and stock lending fees, the authors examine how ETF ownership and arbitrage (creation/redemption and NAV mispricing) affect intraday and daily volatility and turnover. They exploit institutional details of ETF arbitrage and the annual Russell index reconstitution to identify causal effects.

title: Asset Pricing with Countercyclical Household Consumption Risk

title: Financing Constraints, Home Equity and Selection into Entrepreneurship
author: Thais Lærkholm Jensen, Søren Leth-Petersen, Ramana Nanda
context: This paper studies the 1992 Danish mortgage reform (implemented May 1992) using population‑level matched employer‑employee administrative data for a 25% sample of homeowners aged 25–50 over 1988–1996. The reform allowed homeowners to borrow against housing equity for non‑housing purposes (initial 60%, later 80% LTV limit) and extended mortgage maturities. Exploiting cross‑sectional variation in 1991 equity‑to‑value (driven by purchase timing), the authors analyze effects on household borrowing, entry into entrepreneurship (employers), pre‑entry incomes, and firm survival.

title: A Taxonomy of Anomalies and their Trading Costs
author: Robert Novy-Marx, Mihail Velikov
context: This paper empirically evaluates the post-1963 U.S. equity anomaly literature using monthly and annual stock-level data (primarily July 1963–December 2013, with some analyses from 1973 onward). Units are individual U.S. publicly traded firms across the market-cap spectrum. The authors estimate transaction costs (effective bid–ask spreads via Hasbrouck’s Bayesian/Gibbs estimator), compute factor alphas and portfolio performance for 23 anomalies (size, value, momentum, PEAD, etc.), and analyze turnover and trading-cost mitigation (low-cost universe, staggered rebalancing, buy/hold spread) in the U.S. market context.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions; event studies; others

title: Spare Tire? Stock Markets, Banking Crises, and Economic Recoveries
author: Ross Levine, Chen Lin, Wensi Xie
context: This paper examines how pre-crisis shareholder protection shapes firms' responses to systemic banking crises across 36 countries from 1990–2011. Using firm-level panel data on publicly listed manufacturing firms (≈3,600 firms; ≈23,000 firm-years), the authors link Laeven and Valencia’s crisis start dates to Djankov et al.’s Anti-self-dealing index to study profits, employment, equity issuances, and investment efficiency. The institutional setting contrasts countries’ shareholder-protection legal infrastructure and stock-market financing as a potential “spare tire” when bank credit contracts during systemic crises.
identification_methods: DiD; other panel regressions

title: The U.S. listing gap
author: Craig Doidge, G. Andrew Karolyi, René M. Stulz
context: This analysis focuses on U.S. exchange‑listed firms across the 49 Fama–French industries using CRSP data, comparing listings at the 1996 peak to counts through 2012 (post‑peak). title: The Price of Variance Risk

title: Socioeconomic Status and Learning from Financial Information
author: Camelia M. Kuhnen, Andrei C. Miu
context: This experimental study recruited 203 undergraduates at Babes-Bolyai University (Romania, mean age 21) with a 33-person replication at UNC Chapel Hill (U.S.). title: Labor-Force Heterogeneity and Asset Prices: the Importance of Skilled Labor
author: Frederico Belo, Xiaoji Lin, Jun Li, Xiaofei Zhao
context: This paper examines how industry-level labor-skill heterogeneity shapes firm risk and asset prices using U.S. publicly traded firms (mainly 1991–2012, with a longer 1963–2012 extension via imputed skills) and G7 international data (1992–2012). Units are firm-year observations and annually rebalanced July–June portfolios. Industries are classified by the fraction of high-skilled occupations (DOT SVP and BLS OES). Empirical tests relate firms’ hiring rates to future stock returns under a production-investment model that assumes higher labor adjustment costs for high-skilled workers.

author: Kristopher Gerardi, Kyle F. Herkenhoff, Lee E. Ohanian, Paul S. Willen

title: Enlarging the Contracting Space: Collateral Menus, Access to Credit, and Economic Activity
author: Murillo Campello, Mauricio Larrain
context: Focusing on economy-wide reallocation, the paper documents changes in the share of aggregate fixed assets allocated to sectors intensive in movable assets in Romania over 1996–2005, around Romania’s Law 99 (effective 2000). title: Specialization in Bank Lending: Evidence from Exporting Firms
author: Daniel Paravisini, Veronica Rappoport, Philipp Schnabl
treatment: Increase in firm exports to a country
outcome: Borrowing from banks specialized in that country
context: This paper studies bank specialization in lending across export markets using matched bank-loan and customs data for all Peruvian firms during 1994–2010, exploiting monthly loan-level data from the regulator (SBS) and firm-level export shipments. Units are firm–bank–country–year observations. The authors leverage cross-country export demand shocks (country GDP growth and real exchange rates) and the 2008 international capital-flow reversal (banks’ foreign-liability exposure) to isolate demand and supply effects in a bank-dependent Peruvian economy.

title: What do we learn from stock price reactions to China’s first announcement of anti-corruption reforms?
author: Chen Lin, Randall Morck, Bernard Yeung, Xiaofeng Zhao
context: The paper analyzes stock-market reactions to China’s December 4, 2012 “Eight‑Point Policy” anti‑corruption announcement. Using 2012–2013 event windows (3- and 5-day) for 2,260 firms listed on the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges and 81 mainland H‑shares in Hong Kong, the authors relate abnormal returns to firm-level 2011 characteristics (SOE status, entertainment & travel costs) and province-level Marketization indices to infer how curbing corruption differentially affects firms across institutional environments.

title: What Drives Racial and Ethnic Differences in High Cost Mortgages? The Role of High Risk Lenders
author: Patrick Bayer, Fernando Ferreira, Stephen L. Ross
outcome: Likelihood of a high cost loan
context: This paper examines racial and ethnic differences in the incidence of high‑cost (“rate‑spread”) mortgages using HMDA originations from 2004–2007 (May–August draws) linked to DataQuick property records and Experian archival credit reports across seven U.S. metropolitan areas (Chicago, Cleveland, Denver, Los Angeles, Miami–Palm Beach, Maryland counties excluding Baltimore City, and San Francisco). title: How Crashes Develop:  Intradaily Volatility and Crash Evolution
author: David S. Bates
treatment: Higher diffusive volatility and frequent intradaily jumps
context: This paper uses 15-minute S&P 500 futures transactions from the CME (1983–2008; out-of-sample tests 2009–2013) to study how major daily crashes develop. The unit of observation is intradaily and overnight futures returns (15-minute intervals) and derived realized variance. The institutional setting includes CME trading hours, tick-size changes, price-limit/circuit-breaker rules, and the shift from open-outcry to electronic Globex. The analysis estimates multifactor affine stochastic volatility–jump models to assess whether self-exciting intradaily volatility spikes produce large daily outliers.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: How Management Risk Affects Corporate Debt
author: Yihui Pan, Tracy Yue Wang, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This paper studies how uncertainty about management affects corporate default risk and debt pricing using U.S. publicly-traded firms (primarily S&P1500) over 1987–2012 (CDS data 2001–2012). The unit of observation is firm-level debt contracts and daily CDS spreads around CEO and CFO turnovers and over executives’ tenures. author: Yihui Pan, Tracy Yue Wang, Michael S. Weisbach
context: For loan spreads the paper analyzes loan‑level data from DealScan for U.S. publicly traded firms over 1987–2012. The unit of observation is newly‑initiated loans (annual frequency; ~17,076 loans across ~2,316 firms), and the dependent variable is the All‑in‑Drawn loan spread. Regressions relate loan spreads to CEO tenure (measured in years), using firm fixed effects, loan‑level controls (maturity, size, number of lenders, etc.) and credit‑market controls, with emphasis on the decline during the CEO’s first three years and on subsamples (e.g., non‑performance turnovers, refinancings).

title: Bankruptcy Spillovers
author: Shai Bernstein, Emanuele Colonnelli, Xavier Giroud, Benjamin Iverson
context: Using U.S. establishment-level data, the paper studies firms filing Chapter 11 between 1992 and 2005 (with five-year follow-up) across U.S. bankruptcy districts. The unit of analysis is bankrupt firm establishments and neighboring Census-block establishments matched from LexisNexis filings and the Census LBD. The institutional setting is the U.S. federal bankruptcy system—comparison of Chapter 11 reorganization versus Chapter 7 liquidation—with blind, within-division random assignment of cases to judges that creates exogenous variation in conversion propensity; outcomes are local employment and establishment entry/exit by sector.

title: Impulsive Consumption and Financial Wellbeing: Evidence from an Increase in the Availability of Alcohol
author: Itzhak Ben-David, Marieke Bos
context: Using the February 2000 Swedish policy experiment that opened state liquor stores (Systembolaget) on Saturdays in six treated counties (control and buffer counties excluded), the paper analyzes individual-level pawn and mainstream credit behavior and performance. Legal off‑site purchase age is 20; the reported effect is an increase in loan delinquencies for the 20–25 cohort.

title: Real Anomalies

title: Making the House a Home: The Stimulative Effect of Home Purchases on Consumption and Investment
author: Efraim Benmelech, Adam Guren, Brian T. Melzer
context: The paper analyzes U.S. homeowners and residential properties primarily over 2001–2013 (permit data 1994–2013) using monthly household panel data from the Consumer Expenditure Survey and property-level BuildFax permit records for ~9 million homes. title: Flood Risk Belief Heterogeneity and Coastal Home Price Dynamics: Going Under Water?
author: Laura A. Bakkensen, Lint Barrage

context: This triplet studies the CFTC’s announcement on January 20, 2010 that it intended to restrict retail forex leverage. The analysis uses myForexBook account-level monthly panel data (trader-month observations) for U.S. (treated) versus European (control) retail forex traders, with a sample window August 2009–July 2010. The outcome is monthly trading activity (log trading volume and log number of trades) evaluated in a pre/post framework around the announcement.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

This triplet studies the CFTC’s announcement on January 20, 2010 that it intended to restrict retail forex leverage. The analysis uses myForexBook account-level monthly panel data (trader-month observations) for U.S. (treated) versus European (control) retail forex traders, with a sample window August 2009–July 2010. title: Should Retail Investors' Leverage Be Limited?
author: Rawley Z. Heimer, Alp Simsek
context: This study evaluates the January–October 2010 regulatory episode when the CFTC capped leverage for U.S. retail forex traders (50:1 for major pairs, 20:1 for others). Using account-level trade data (2009–2012) for U.S. and European retail forex traders, monthly panel data on brokerages’ capital, and high-frequency interbank quotes, it compares U.S. (treated) versus European (control) traders, brokerages, and execution prices to estimate causal effects of the leverage constraint on trading volume, returns, broker capital, and spreads.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Liquidity Regimes and Optimal Dynamic Asset Allocation
author: Pierre Collin-Dufresne, Kent D. Daniel, Mehmet Saǧlam
context: This paper develops a regime-switching portfolio-choice model and implements it using U.S. equity market data and institutional execution records. The authors estimate four-state Markov-switching models on daily value-weighted CRSP market returns from 1967 Q3–2017 Q2, and calibrate state-dependent transaction-cost multipliers using 81,744 large-order executions (VWAP and PoV) on S&P 500 stocks from Jan 2011–Dec 2012. Units are daily market returns and dollar orders; the setting is U.S. equity markets with time-varying volatility, liquidity regimes, and institutional trading algorithms, used to evaluate in- and out-of-sample trading strategies.
identification_methods: others

title: Signaling Safety
author: Roni Michaely, Stefano Rossi, Michael Weber
context: U.S. publicly listed firms (NYSE, AMEX, NASDAQ) are analyzed around dividend and share-repurchase events from 1964–2013 (repurchases 1980–2013). The unit is individual firms and dividend/repurchase announcement events; the authors use firm-level monthly returns and quarterly accounting data and apply Campbell–Shiller return decompositions and VARs estimated on 60 months before/after each event. The institutional setting is corporate payout policy decisions (dividend increases/decreases, initiations, omissions, repurchase announcements), with attention to financial constraints and robustness to market-wide trends.

title: Decision Fatigue and Heuristic Analyst Forecasts
author: David Hirshleifer, Yaron Levi, Ben Lourie, Siew Hong Teoh
context: This paper studies sell-side analyst forecasting in U.S. equity markets using I/B/E/S forecast records for 2002–2015. Units are analyst–firm one-year-ahead EPS forecasts issued intra-day (9:00–19:00); the key institutional setting is sequential same-day forecast issuance by analysts who cover multiple firms. The authors measure decision fatigue as the number/order of an analyst’s forecasts per day and analyze effects on forecast accuracy, herding, reissuance, rounding, and investor reactions (3-day market-adjusted returns), controlling for analyst and analyst-day fixed effects and time-of-day.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; event studies

title: Uncertainty and Economic Activity: A Multi-Country Perspective
author: Ambrogio Cesa-Bianchi, M. Hashem Pesaran, Alessandro Rebucci
context: This paper analyzes quarterly country-level data on real GDP growth and realized equity-market volatility for 32 advanced and emerging economies (covering >90% of world GDP) over 1993:Q1–2011:Q2. Units are country-quarter observations. Combining a multi-country Lucas-tree model with empirical factor-augmented VARs and cross-sectional factor estimation, the study assumes a pervasive global ‘real’ growth factor and an additional common ‘financial’ factor in volatilities to separate global versus country-specific shocks and quantify their effects on growth and volatility.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions

title: The Capitalization of Consumer Financing into Durable Goods Prices
author: Bronson Argyle, Taylor D. Nadauld, Christopher Palmer, Ryan D. Pratt
context: This paper examines how individual consumer credit terms are capitalized into used-car prices in the U.S., using loan-level data on auto originations (2005–2017, concentrated 2011–2017) across hundreds of lenders and commuting zones. The unit is vehicle-level loan transactions (borrowers purchasing used cars). Identification exploits lender-specific, age-based maturity schedules—discrete drops in maximum offered loan maturity when cars nominally age on January 1—generating exogenous variation in maturity and interest terms across otherwise comparable buyers.

title: Initial Coin Offerings: Financing Growth with Cryptocurrency Token Sales
author: Sabrina T. Howell, Marina Niessner, David Yermack
context: This paper studies 1,520 ICOs worldwide, mostly issued in 2016–2018, tracking issuer-level outcomes (employment from LinkedIn in Nov 2018 and Jul 2019, and failure by Nov 2018) and token outcomes (exchange listing). title: Credit Supply and Housing Speculation
author: Atif Mian, Amir Sufi
context: This study examines U.S. housing markets during 2000–2010, centering on the late‑2003 surge in private‑label mortgage securitization and the 2003–2006 housing boom and subsequent bust. It exploits cross‑sectional and panel variation across lenders, zip codes, and MSAs—using 2002 non‑core‑liability (NCL) exposure—to trace credit‑supply effects on mortgage originations, speculative buyers, prices, construction, and delinquencies. Data sources include HMDA, TransUnion, CoreLogic transactions, and the Michigan Survey of Consumers.

title: Asset Insulators
author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich, Andra Ghent, Valentin Haddad
context: This paper studies U.S. life insurance companies using detailed NAIC regulatory holdings (2004–2014) and daily TRACE corporate bond prices to estimate how idiosyncratic bond price shocks pass through to insurer equity, with special focus on the 2008–2009 financial crisis (crisis window Jan 2008–Dec 2009). Units of observation include individual insurers (a publicly-traded subsample and the industry universe) and cusip-level bonds. The institutional setting emphasizes insurers’ general-account assets, long-term policy liabilities, state guaranty regimes, and binding capital/market frictions during the crisis.

title: Macroprudential FX Regulations: Shifting the Snowbanks of FX Vulnerability?
author: Toni Ahnert, Kristin Forbes, Christian Friedrich, Dennis Reinhardt
context: This paper analyzes the effects of macroprudential foreign-exchange (FX) regulations on bank and corporate FX borrowing across 48 countries (excluding reserve issuers) over 1995–2014. title: Volatility Risk Pass-through
author: Riccardo Colacito, Mariano Max Croce, Yang Liu, Ivan Shaliastovich
context: This paper studies international propagation of output volatility shocks across 17 major industrialized countries (G7 plus ten others) using quarterly per-capita real consumption and output data from 1971:Q1–2013:Q4 (OECD/FRED). title: Partisan Professionals: Evidence from Credit Rating Analysts
author: Elisabeth Kempf, Margarita Tsoutsoura
context: This paper examines U.S. corporate credit-rating analysts and their rating actions from 2000–2018. The authors link 557 analysts (primarily based in New York City and Chicago) to voter-registration party affiliations from Illinois, New Jersey, and New York City and their ratings of 1,984 U.S. firms at Fitch, Moody’s, and S&P. Exploiting variation in analysts’ alignment with the U.S. president’s party and presidential elections (notably 2016), the study compares analysts covering the same firm-quarter to estimate effects on rating changes, security prices, bond yields, and firm investment.

title: Naïve *Buying* Diversification and Narrow Framing by Individual Investors

title: The Leading Premium
author: M. Max Croce, Tatyana Marchuk, Christian Schlag
treatment: Advance information provided by leading industries
outcome: Conditional cash-flow uncertainty of lagging firms
context: Using US data from 1972–2012, the paper studies ∼17,000 publicly listed firms (aggregated into industry portfolios, typically 30 industries per Kenneth French) to measure lead–lag links between industry-level cash-flow/operating-income growth and aggregate GDP/consumption. It combines quarterly COMPUSTAT fundamentals, monthly CRSP returns, and NIPA aggregates to form rolling-window cross-correlograms and dynamic industry sorts. The institutional setting is the US macro-financial environment across multiple business cycles; key assumptions concern slow diffusion of sectoral growth-news shocks and pricing of advance information by agents.

title: The Term Structure of Equity Risk Premia
author: Ravi Bansal, Shane Miller, Dongho Song, Amir Yaron
outcome: Term structure slope of dividend risk premia
context: This paper studies traded equity dividend strips (futures) in the U.S., Europe (Eurostoxx), and Japan (Nikkei) over 2004–2017, using longer historical dividend/consumption data for forecasting (U.S. from 1979, Europe/Japan from 1994). Units are fixed-maturity dividend-strip contracts, aggregate dividends and consumption; the analysis contrasts term-structure behavior across business-cycle states (NBER/CEPR/ECRI recession dates) and accounts for market illiquidity (bid–ask spreads). The authors estimate Bayesian VAR forecasts of dividend growth and develop a regime-switching consumption-based asset-pricing model to interpret the results.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Asset Price Bubbles and Systemic Risk
author: Markus K. Brunnermeier, Simon C. Rother, Isabel Schnabel
outcome: Increase in systemic risk during real estate busts
context: The paper analyzes monthly bank‑level data on 1,264 listed financial institutions across 17 countries (Australia, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the UK, and the US) over roughly 1987–2015 (with price series back to the 1970s). It links stock‑market and real‑estate bubble episodes (identified via BSADF and a trend‑deviation approach) to bank‑level systemic risk (∆CoVaR and MES), distinguishing boom and bust phases and heterogeneity by bank size, loan growth, leverage, and maturity mismatch.

title: Bank Risk Dynamics and Distance to Default
author: Stefan Nagel, Amiyatosh Purnanandam
context: This triplet is a model-based implication from the paper’s structural model and simulation results: in a one-factor model of borrower collateral with staggered loan cohorts, simulated instantaneous bank-equity volatility (computed as the derivative of log equity with respect to the common-factor log W times √ρσ) falls toward zero when aggregate borrower asset values are high (see Figure 3, Panel b). It is a theoretical/simulation result for a representative bank in the calibrated structural setting, not a reduced-form empirical panel estimate.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; others

title: Communication within Banking Organizations and Small Business Lending
author: Ross Levine, Chen Lin, Qilin Peng, Wensi Xie
context: The paper examines how reductions in travel time between bank headquarters and branches affect small-business lending in the United States using bank–county–year data from 2000–2016. It links branch locations (SOD), CRA county-level small-business loan reports (loans ≤ $1M, emphasis on ≤ $100k), and airline T-100 route openings that shorten headquarters–branch travel. The unit of analysis is the bank–county (branch-county) year within the U.S. banking/CRA reporting environment, exploiting passenger route introductions as shocks to within-bank communication costs.

title: Employee Costs of Corporate Bankruptcy
author: John R. Graham, Hyunseob Kim, Si Li, Jiaping Qiu
context: This paper studies U.S. public-firm bankruptcies (primarily Chapter 11) using employer–employee LEHD data (earnings 1985–2008) merged to Compustat and the UCLA-LoPucki BRD, focusing on bankruptcy filings from roughly 1991–2005. The unit of analysis is individual workers matched to firms (about 140 bankrupt firms and ~277,000 affected workers), with attention to local labor-market thickness, firm size, and liquidation versus reorganization. Analyses control for industry×year and county×year shocks to isolate bankruptcy-related effects on worker earnings and implied wage premia for bankruptcy risk.

title: Venture Capital Contracts
author: Michael Ewens, Alexander S. Gorbenko, Arthur Korteweg
context: This paper analyzes U.S. VC-backed first financing rounds (seed/Series A) between 2002–2010 (exit follow-up through March 2018), using about 1,695–2,581 deals for U.S.-headquartered startups (mostly Delaware/California). The unit of observation is the entrepreneur–lead VC first-round match and its contract (convertible preferred equity terms such as investor equity share, participation, pay-to-play, and board seats). The setting is the U.S. venture capital market; the authors model bargaining and endogenous selection via a dynamic search-and-matching equilibrium to assess contract effects on startup outcomes.

title: The Deregulation of the Private Equity Markets and the Decline in IPOs
author: Michael Ewens, Joan Farre-Mensa
context: Analysis of U.S. SEC Form D filings for private issuers from 1992–1998 examines the immediate effect of NSMIA’s October 1996 passage. Unit of observation: U.S. private issuers filing Form D; institutional setting: NSMIA’s Rule 506 blue-sky preemption.

title: Why Do Firms Borrow Directly from Nonbanks?
author: Sergey Chernenko, Isil Erel, Robert Prilmeier
context: Using hand-collected SEC-filed loan contracts for U.S. publicly traded middle-market firms (annual revenues $10M–$1B) during 2010–2015, the paper estimates the local causal effect of borrowing from a nonbank lender on loan maturity. Identification exploits a fuzzy regression discontinuity at the zero-EBITDA cutoff—comparing firms just below versus just above zero EBITDA—to instrument for nonbank borrowing; the causal estimates therefore apply to loans for firms with EBITDA near zero and pertain to loan-level outcomes (maturity, covenants, pricing).

context: The paper studies individual Chinese retail investors by merging a nationwide September 2018 survey (≈11,000 responses, randomized across broker branches) with Shenzhen Stock Exchange account-level transactions from January 2018–June 2019 (primary post-survey window Oct 2018–Jun 2019). The setting is China’s high–retail-participation equity market (≈80% retail volume); the authors also randomized a nudge (salience of trading costs) to half the survey sample.

title: Do Investors Care about Carbon Risk?
author: Patrick Bolton, Marcin Kacperczyk
context: Using Trucost emissions matched to FactSet, this paper analyzes U.S.-listed firms from 2005–2017 to test whether firm-level carbon emissions (scope 1–3 levels and changes, and emission intensity) affect monthly stock returns and annual institutional holdings. The unit of observation is firms (monthly returns; firm-year ownership by investor type). Analyses exploit cross-sectional variation with firm controls, industry and time fixed effects, and asset-pricing factor adjustments in the backdrop of rising climate-policy salience (including the 2015 Paris Agreement) and heterogeneous corporate disclosure and exclusionary investor screening.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions; other panel regressions

title: Trade Credit and the Transmission of Unconventional Monetary Policy

context: This paper studies how the ECB’s Corporate Sector Purchase Program (CSPP), announced March 10, 2016 and implemented mid‑2016, affected trade credit and real activity across euro‑area firm supply chains. title: How Valuable is Financial Flexibility when Revenue Stops? Evidence from the COVID-19 Crisis
author: Rüdiger Fahlenbrach, Kevin Rageth, René M. Stulz
context: This paper studies how firm-level financial flexibility affected equity and credit-market reactions to the COVID-19 revenue shock in the United States, using 1,857 publicly listed non-financial U.S. firms (and a 512‑firm COVID‑exposed subset). title: Zombie Credit and (Dis-)Inflation: Evidence from Europe
author: Viral V. Acharya, Matteo Crosignani, Tim Eisert, Christian Eufinger
context: This paper studies the rise of “zombie credit” and its effect on inflation using firm-level (≈1.17 million firms) and product‑level CPI data across 65 industries in 12 European countries (Austria, Belgium, Germany, Denmark, Spain, Finland, France, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Sweden, Slovakia) roughly over 2009–2016 with emphasis on the post‑2012 period. The setting is post‑global financial and sovereign‑debt crises under ultra‑accommodative ECB policies (negative rates, asset purchases), where weakly‑capitalized banks and search‑for‑yield behavior provided cheap credit to impaired firms; units are firms and industry‑country “markets.”

title: Launching with a Parachute: The Gig Economy and New Business Formation
author: John M. Barrios, Yael V. Hochberg, Hanyi Yi
context: This empirical paper analyzes quarterly data from 2001–2016 for US incorporated places (population≥10,000), exploiting the staggered rollout of ridehailing services (UberX/Lyft) across cities as a proxy for the arrival of platform-enabled gig-economy opportunities. Units are cities/places (matched to DMAs/counties) and outcomes include new business registrations, SBA 7(a) loans to newly registered firms, and Google search interest. Identification relies on variation in treatment timing, city and quarter-year fixed effects, city-specific trends, and event-time dynamics; wage-growth volatility and credit proxies are used for heterogeneity tests.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Implications of Stochastic Transmission Rates for Managing Pandemic Risks
author: Harrison Hong, Neng Wang, Jinqiang Yang
context: The paper analyzes early COVID-19 dynamics using daily confirmed-case time series pooled from 16 high-risk countries/regions (including China, Japan, South Korea, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, UAE, Vietnam, Malaysia, Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, UK, and US) during January–February 2020 to estimate stochastic transmission parameters under an SIS framework (γ set to ≈1/14 days). Those estimates are embedded in a partial-equilibrium asset-pricing model with firm-level mitigation and a Poisson vaccine-arrival process (calibrated around 1/year) to study optimal mitigation and effects on firm valuations.

title: Barbarians at the Store? Private Equity, Products, and Consumers
author: Cesare Fracassi, Alessandro Previtero, Albert W. Sheen
context: This paper studies the effects of private-equity buyouts of 236 consumer-goods manufacturers in the United States using monthly Nielsen retail scanner data from 2006–2016, focusing on deals closed 2007–2015. Units of observation include firms, firm-category product lines, and individual UPCs sold in ~43,000 stores across 91 retail chains. title: Kicking the Can Down the Road: Government Interventions in the European Banking Sector
author: Viral V. Acharya, Lea Borchert, Maximilian Jager, Sascha Steffen
context: This paper studies eurozone bank-level interventions during the Global Financial Crisis and subsequent sovereign-debt shock, using hand-collected State Aid Register data on interventions from 2007–2009 and balance-sheet and loan-level outcomes through 2012. title: Out of Sight No More? The Effect of Fee Disclosures on 401(k) Investment Allocations

title: The Pass-Through of Uncertainty Shocks to Households
author: Marco Di Maggio, Amir Kermani, Rodney Ramcharan, Vincent Yao, Edison Yu
context: This empirical study uses employer-employee matched credit-bureau and stock-market data for U.S. public firms and their workers to estimate how firm-level idiosyncratic uncertainty affects household income, consumption, and credit outcomes. title: The Distributional Effects of Student Loan Forgiveness
author: Sylvain Catherine, Constantine Yannelis
context: This paper uses the 2019 Survey of Consumer Finances to analyze U.S. households (individuals aged 22–60) and their federal student loans, projecting repayment under federal programs (FFEL/DL) and Income-Driven Repayment plans (IBR, PAYE, REPAYE) that tie payments to 10–15% of discretionary income above 150% of the federal poverty line and forgive remaining balances after 20–25 years. title: Global Pricing of Carbon-Transition Risk
author: Patrick Bolton, Marcin Kacperczyk
context: This study analyzes firm-level financial and emissions data for 14,468 publicly listed companies in 77 countries over 2005–2018. title: Real and Private-Value Assets
author: William N. Goetzmann, Christophe Spaenjers, Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh
context: This paper synthesizes empirical analyses of real and private-value assets across historical and contemporary settings (long-run samples from the 19th–20th centuries through decades up to 2020), focused primarily on the U.S. but also drawing evidence from the U.K., France, Netherlands, and Singapore. Units of observation include individual residential and commercial properties, auctioned artworks and collectibles, non‑corporate firms, households, and institutional investors. The reviewed studies exploit institutional features (illiquid search/auction markets, REITs and private funds), regulatory shocks (e.g., downpayment rules), climate and mortality shocks, surveys, and experiments to study prices, returns, liquidity, and investor behavior.

title: The Labor Effects of Judicial Bias in Bankruptcy
author: Aloisio Araujo, Rafael Ferreira, Spyridon Lagaras, Flavio Moraes, Jacopo Ponticelli, Margarita Tsoutsoura
context: This paper analyzes bankruptcy cases filed in the State of São Paulo, Brazil between June 2005 and December 2015, linking court records to administrative RAIS employer–employee data to follow firms and workers up to five years after filing. title: Using Social Media to Identify the Effects of Congressional Viewpoints on Asset Prices
author: Francesco Bianchi, Roberto Gomez Cram, Howard Kung
context: This triplet concerns policy-revealing congressional tweets (about 43% of the ~11K tweets from January 2013–December 2020) that reference 454 Russell 3000 firms. Many policy-relevant tweets (≈58%) occur on House or Senate committee meeting days. Units are timestamped politician tweets linked to firms, merged with intraday NYSE TAQ trades and daily CRSP returns. The paper finds stock-price responses are substantially larger for policy-revealing tweets, particularly those from committee members on meeting days or whose text closely matches meeting topics, consistent with revealing future legislative action.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions

title: The Legal Origins of Financial Development: Evidence from the Shanghai Concessions
author: Ross Levine, Chen Lin, Chicheng Ma, Yuchen Xu
context: This paper studies how transplanting British common law versus French civil law affected financial development across Western concessions in China, focusing on Shanghai (1845–1936) and additional concessions in Tianjin, Hankou, and Guangzhou. Units are concession- and grid-cell-level observations and firms (banks, qianzhuang, stock companies, and stock returns). Key institutional shocks are the 1869 creation of Mixed Courts (strengthening British/French legal jurisdiction) and the 1926–27 rendition returning courts to Chinese authority; authors exploit these temporal and spatial discontinuities to identify causal effects.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Delayed Creative Destruction: How Uncertainty Shapes Corporate Assets
author: Murillo Campello, Gaurav Kankanhalli, Hyunseob Kim
context: This paper examines how business uncertainty affects capital allocation, asset composition, and productivity in the global commercial shipping industry using near-universal ship- and firm-subsector-quarter data (Clarksons) primarily from 2006–2019. Units are ships and shipping firms operating across segmented subsectors (size/route-restricted markets). The analysis exploits transaction margins (new orders, secondary purchases/sales, demolitions), measures uncertainty via option-implied and freight-derivative volatilities, and leverages the 2009–2011 Somali piracy spike (Suez-route size discontinuity) as a quasi-experimental shock.

title: Corporate Actions and the Manipulation of Retail Investors in China: An Analysis of Stock Splits
author: Sheridan Titman, Chishen Wei. Wei, Bin Zhao
context: This paper analyzes Chinese A‑share stock-split announcements from 1999–2015 (returns through 2016), focusing on non‑state‑owned firms listed on the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges. Units include firm-level split events, investor trading accounts (complete SSE account-level trades 1999–2015; a 2013–2015 account sample), block trades and share-pledge records (2006–2015), and online forum posts (2010–2013). The institutional setting features retail-dominated trading (~90% of volume), tight short-selling constraints, regulatory lockups and disclosure rules, and CSRC enforcement, which the authors exploit to assess temporary price inflation and insider exits.

title: Measuring the Welfare Cost of Asymmetric Information in Consumer Credit Markets
author: Anthony A. DeFusco, Huan Tang, Constantine Yannelis
context: This paper analyzes a randomized pricing experiment run by a large Chinese fintech lending platform during January–March 2018. The unit is ~11,000 pre‑approved individual loan applicants offered 12‑month unsecured installment loans; applicants were randomized to either the platform’s standard terms or substantially reduced borrowing costs (roughly 36% vs 21.5% total). The platform provides internal credit ratings (1–4), bundles loans for investors, and records take‑up, default (charge‑offs), and recovery outcomes to assess welfare losses from asymmetric information.
identification_methods: RCT; IV

title: Political Ideology and International Capital Allocation
author: Elisabeth Kempf, Mancy Luo, Larissa Schäfer, Margarita Tsoutsoura
context: This empirical paper examines how U.S. institutional investors’ political ideology affects cross-border capital allocation using syndicated corporate loans and U.S.-based international equity mutual funds between 2000–2018 (elections 2002–2018). The analysis focuses on U.S. banks and mutual-fund managers investing in ≈45 foreign destination countries, using investor×destination-country×half-year observations and exploiting changes in ideological distance—measured from the Manifesto Project and U.S. PAC/voter records—around foreign parliamentary elections while controlling for election×time and investor fixed effects.

title: CLO Performance
author: Larry Cordell, Michael R. Roberts, Michael Schwert
treatment: Higher returns on CLO debt tranches
context: This paper studies U.S. collateralized loan obligations (CLOs) and their tranches using near-comprehensive trustee-level data on 2,131 deals and cash flows from August 1997 to March 2021. title: Revealing Corruption: Firm and Worker Level Evidence from Brazil
author: Emanuele Colonnelli, Spyridon Lagaras, Jacopo Ponticelli, Mounu Prem, Margarita Tsoutsoura
context: This paper studies how randomized municipal audits by Brazil’s Office of the Comptroller General (CGU) during 2003–2014 affected firms and workers. The CGU ran televised lotteries selecting municipalities for audits of federally funded municipal procurement (covering contracts in the two prior years); auditors publicly listed firms implicated in irregularities. The unit of analysis is firm- and worker-level administrative data (matched RAIS, procurement, BNDES loans, and PIA investment) for firms—mostly outside audited municipalities—exposed by these audits across Brazilian municipalities.

title: Real Effects of Supplying Safe Private Money
author: Chenzi Xu, He Yang
context: The paper studies how introducing federally regulated “national” bank notes affected local economic development in the United States in the late 19th century (primarily changes from ~1875–1885 and outcomes through 1890, with dynamics to 1900). The unit of analysis is towns/counties (town populations and county-level agricultural and manufacturing outcomes). The institutional setting is the post‑Civil‑War dual banking system after the National Banking Act (1863–64), exploiting population‑based capital‑requirement thresholds for national charters and a derived county-level “monetary market access” measure to capture changes in monetary transaction frictions.
identification_methods: IV; DiD; event studies

title: Aggregate Lapsation Risk
author: Ralph S. J. Koijen, Hae Kang Lee, Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh
context: This paper studies aggregate and heterogeneous lapsation behavior in the U.S. life-insurance industry over 1996–2020, combining firm-year regulatory filings for the 30 largest life insurers with a proprietary policy-level panel of contracts (policies issued c.1998–2016) and county/ZIP-level data. It examines how lapsation co-moves with macro and financial conditions (interest rates, Baa spreads, GDP, employment), with emphasis on the Great Financial Crisis and COVID-19, and on policyholder heterogeneity (age, health, income, term vs whole life) for valuation and pricing implications.

title: The Virtue of Complexity in Return Prediction
author: Bryan T. Kelly, Semyon Malamud, Kangying Zhou
context: The paper analyzes US aggregate equity market return prediction and market-timing using theory plus extensive empirical experiments on monthly market returns (CRSP) spanning 1926–2020. The unit of observation is the single risky asset (market excess return); inputs are 15 standard predictors (Goyal and Welch, 2008) nonlinearly expanded via random features. The setting compares low- to high-complexity (P up to >10,000) ridge and ridgeless regressions with rolling out-of-sample evaluation, including performance around NBER recession dates.

title: Intermediary Balance Sheets and the Treasury Yield Curve
author: Wenxin Du, Benjamin M. Hébert, Wenhao Li
context: This paper studies the U.S. Treasury market across the pre- and post-Global Financial Crisis era through the March 2020 COVID episode (roughly 2000s–2020). It analyzes maturity-specific Treasury yields, OIS swap rates, cross-currency basis (CIP deviations), and primary dealers’ net Treasury positions (FR2004) as market-level time series and maturity buckets. The institutional setting includes post-GFC regulatory shifts (higher balance-sheet costs, SLR), large increases in Treasury issuance, and Fed policy interventions (asset purchases, swap lines). Dealers are treated as balance-sheet-constrained arbitrageurs.

author: Hans K. Hvide, Tom G. Meling, Magne Mogstad, Ola L. Vestad
context: This paper estimates effects of Norway’s broadband expansion (≈2000–2010) on household and individual investor outcomes. Exploiting municipality‑year variation from a government fiber‑optic roll‑out and linked administrative data (NCSD transactions, tax and demographic registers), the unit of analysis includes municipalities, households, and individuals. The reform ensured staged broadband coverage; the authors instrument municipality broadband use with prior‑year coverage to identify impacts on stock/fund participation, trading, portfolio diversification, and returns.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; event studies

author: Todd A. Gormley, Vishal K. Gupta, David A. Matsa, Sandra C. Mortal, Lukai Yang
context: This paper examines U.S. public corporations and individual directors over 2013–2019 (pre-period 2014–2016, post-period 2017–2019), exploiting the 2017–2018 gender-diversity campaigns by The Big Three (State Street, BlackRock, Vanguard). title: Sea Level Rise Exposure and Municipal Bond Yields
author: Paul Goldsmith-Pinkham, Matthew T. Gustafson, Ryan C. Lewis, Michael Schwert
context: The paper examines U.S. coastal school-district municipal bond markets from 2001–2017, using monthly bond trades for school-district issuers (property-tax‑backed) across coastal counties. It links district-level exposure to projected sea level rise (NOAA measures, primarily 6‑ft exposure) and changing scientific worst‑case projections/uncertainty (notably 2011–2015) to municipal credit spreads, exploiting within-county, over-time variation and calibrating economic magnitudes using a structural credit-risk model.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Monetary Tightening and U.S. Bank Fragility in 2023: Mark-to-Market Losses and Uninsured Depositor Runs?
author: Erica Xuewei Jiang, Gregor Matvos, Tomasz Piskorski, Amit Seru
context: This paper studies how the 2022–2023 U.S. monetary tightening (roughly Q1 2022–Q1 2023 Fed rate increases) affected balance-sheet valuations and run risk across U.S. FDIC‑insured banks. Using bank call‑report data and liquid market indexes, the authors mark-to-market long‑duration real‑estate loans, securities and Treasuries for thousands of banks (including GSIBs) to compute unrealized losses, uninsured‑deposit shares, and stress‑test counterfactuals; the analysis emphasizes deposit franchise, uninsured leverage, and FDIC resolution incentives.
identification_methods: others

title: Tracing the International Transmission of a Crisis Through Multinational Firms
author: Marcus Biermann, Kilian Huber
context: This paper studies transmission of a 2008–09 credit‑supply shock—Commerzbank’s lending cut during the global financial crisis—across German multinational parents and their international affiliates using firm‑level data (MiDi, Ustan) from roughly 2002–2015. Units are German parent firms and their foreign affiliates located worldwide. The identification exploits pre‑crisis parent reliance on Commerzbank within Germany’s relationship‑banking system to isolate an exogenous credit shock to parents and examines internal capital flows, affiliate sales and employment, and a contrasting non‑financial 2013 flood shock.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Tracing the International Transmission of a Crisis Through Multinational Firms
author: Marcus Biermann, Kilian Huber
context: This triplet concerns foreign (non-German) affiliates of German multinational parents in the MiDi/Ustan sample (panel 2002–2015), specifically those that had issued long-term loans to their German parent before 2008. The analysis focuses on the aftermath of Commerzbank’s 2008 lending cut: affiliates that increased internal long-term lending to their parent during 2008–2010 are compared (via affiliate-level panel/event‑study regressions with fixed effects) to affiliates without such pre‑existing long‑term loans to assess effects on affiliate sales.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

The identification exploits pre‑crisis parent reliance on Commerzbank within Germany’s relationship‑banking system to isolate an exogenous credit shock to parents and examines internal capital flows, affiliate sales and employment, and a contrasting non‑financial 2013 flood shock.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Commerzbank lending cut
Outcome: Affiliate external financing

- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Are Cryptos Different? Evidence from Retail Trading
author: Shimon Kogan, Igor Makarov, Marina Niessner, Antoinette Schoar
context: Using time-stamped trade and portfolio data from eToro between January 2015 and December 2019, the paper studies roughly 200,000 retail accounts (predominantly European) and daily trading in cryptocurrencies (mainly Bitcoin, Ethereum, Ripple), the top 200 stocks, and gold on the eToro platform (many trades via CFDs). title: The Credit Supply Channel of Monetary Policy Tightening and its Distributional Impacts
author: Joshua Bosshardt, Marco Di Maggio, Ali Kakhbod, Amir Kermani
context: This paper studies how the 2021–2022 U.S. monetary tightening—when the Federal Reserve raised short-term rates and mortgage rates jumped from roughly 3% to about 7%—affected purchase mortgage originations, house prices, and consumption across U.S. metropolitan statistical areas. Using a 5% National Mortgage Database sample (and HMDA), the authors analyze individual first-lien, single-family purchase loans and borrower groups (by race and income), exploiting fixed underwriting DTI thresholds (45%, 50%, 57%) for GSE, FHA, and VA programs to assess credit-supply constraints and regional spillovers.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: The Credit Supply Channel of Monetary Policy Tightening and its Distributional Impacts
author: Joshua Bosshardt, Marco Di Maggio, Ali Kakhbod, Amir Kermani
context: The analysis examines U.S. metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) over 2021–2022, testing whether the MSA-level "high-DTI share"—the fraction of 2019–2021 purchase originations that would have had counterfactual DTI >50% if originated in 2022—predicts changes in consumption. The outcome is the change from 2021 to 2022 in MSA-level credit and debit card spending (Chetty et al. Economic Tracker). Cross-sectional regressions across MSAs control for prior spending, employment growth, income per capita, and housing supply elasticity to link DTI-driven credit supply constraints to local spending declines.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Managing Mental Accounts: Payment Cards and Consumption Expenditures
author: Michael Gelman, Nikolai Roussanov
context: This study uses monthly proprietary card-transaction data (2010–2013) from Israel to analyze 13,291 retail store members (individuals) who exogenously received a new general-purpose store credit card when their three-year membership expired. A large Israeli retail chain required the new card to receive member discounts; cards were applied for in-store and mailed within 7–10 business days. The setting features staggered expiration timing, limited pre-2018 credit scoring, ubiquitous credit-card payments, and detailed per-card monthly spending, balances, and credit-line records.
identification_methods: DiD; RDD; event studies

title: Regulatory Arbitrage or Random Errors? Implications of Race Prediction Algorithms in Fair Lending Analysis
author: Daniel Greenwald, Sabrina T. Howell, Cangyuan Li, Emmanuel Yimfor
outcome: Measured racial disparities in loan approval rates
context: This paper studies how race-prediction algorithms (BISG) shape fair-lending measurement and lender incentives in U.S. small-business credit markets using Lendio loan application data (2017–2019) and Paycheck Protection Program first-draw loans (Apr 2020–Feb 2021). Units are individual applicants/borrowers and lenders. The authors construct an image-based race measure from LinkedIn photos, benchmark it to self-reported PPP race, estimate how BISG errors bias approval gaps and lender-level loan shares, and simulate counterfactual regulatory shifts from BISG to self-identified race under U.S. fair-lending rules.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: The Reserve Supply Channel of Unconventional Monetary Policy
author: William F. Diamond, Zhengyang Jiang, Yiming Ma
context: This paper studies how large Federal Reserve reserve injections from QE (primarily 2007–2018, focusing on the 2008–2017 QE episode) affected US commercial banks’ balance sheets and loan supply. Using U.S. bank-branch, county- and state-level data (2001–2017) on deposits, mortgages, syndicated loans, and Call Report balance sheets, the unit of analysis is banks/branches and local markets. The institutional setting is the U.S. banking system during post-crisis QE, exploiting internal capital market reallocation after local natural disasters, Bartik deposit-growth variation, and daily TGA shocks to identify causal effects of reserve supply.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; others

This paper studies how large Federal Reserve reserve injections from QE (primarily 2007–2018, focusing on the 2008–2017 QE episode) affected US commercial banks’ balance sheets and loan supply. title: The Economics of “Buy Now, Pay Later”: A Merchant’s Perspective
author: Tobias Berg, Valentin Burg, Jan Keil, Manju Puri
context: This paper studies the merchant economics of Buy-Now-Pay-Later (BNPL) using microdata from a German e-commerce furniture retailer. It combines an early-2022 randomized controlled trial that randomized display of a pay-in-30 BNPL option at checkout (~75k customers) with 2021 observational data on ~595k BNPL applications (customer credit scores, cart margins, approvals, defaults) and county-level panels (2016–2019) of checkouts to assess default cyclicality. Units include customers, shopping carts/transactions, BNPL applications, and counties; BNPL is offered in-house and subsidized by the merchant.
identification_methods: RCT; IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Financial Inclusion Across the United States
author: Motohiro Yogo, Andrew Whitten, Natalie Cox
treatment: Additional years of access to employer retirement plan
context: Using U.S. administrative tax and information returns (primarily 2006–2019, with 2015–2019 cross-sections), the paper studies retirement- and bank-account participation for the universe of U.S. households with a member aged 50–59 across ZIP Code Tabulation Areas (ZCTAs). It leverages employer-level timing (whether/when firms start retirement plans after a 2010 baseline) and plan features (automatic enrollment), merges Form W-2/1099/5498 with Form 5500 and state auto-IRA mandates, and examines geographic correlates of financial inclusion to evaluate causal effects of access to employer plans.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Financial Inclusion Across the United States
author: Motohiro Yogo, Andrew Whitten, Natalie Cox
treatment: Automatic enrollment in an employer retirement plan
context: Using U.S. administrative tax and information returns for households with a member aged 50–59, the paper estimates the causal effect of employer retirement plan features for workers who lacked access in 2010. It exploits employer timing of starting plans after a 2010 baseline (access measured 2011–2019) and an intent-to-treat IV based on counterfactual access had the worker remained with the 2010 employer. The reported estimate: automatic enrollment raises retirement-account participation by 28 percentage points in the lowest income quintile.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Public Goods Under Financial Distress
author: Pawel Janas
context: This paper studies U.S. municipalities during the Great Depression (annual data 1924–1943), focusing on cities (population >1,000 in five states and all cities >100k) and municipal bonds, and on individual local public-sector workers via linked census records. It exploits variation in pre-1929 municipal leverage and in bond maturity schedules amid a setting of minimal federal/state fiscal backstops, widespread banking panics (1930–33), and collapsing municipal credit to identify how debt-driven refinancing constraints affected local public spending, infrastructure investment, crime, health, and workforce composition.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions
